lessons.title: Topic 4.2 - Experimental Setup
lessons.content:
• determine what changes would improve experimental validity:
    • . These questions appear across all ACT Science passage types
    • asking you to analyze how experiments are structured
    • why specific procedures are followed
    • and what modifications would better test hypotheses or confounding variables
  • This lesson teaches you the fundamental components of scientific experiments and how to identify them in passages, explains the logic behind experimental controls and variable manipulation, provides strategies for recognizing flawed designs and suggesting improvements, and shows you how to match experimental procedures to research questions and hypotheses.

1. Core Components of Experimental Design

Understanding the essential elements of scientific experiments allows you to analyze any experimental setup and answer design questions systematically.

Hypothesis and Research Question

  • Research question: A broad inquiry like "How does temperature affect plant growth?" or "What factors influence reaction rate?" The research question identifies what the experiment investigates.
  • Hypothesis:
    • testable prediction answering the research question. "If temperature increases
    • then plant growth rate will increase" or "Higher enzyme concentration will increase reaction rate." Hypotheses predict a relationship between variables
  • Characteristics of good hypotheses: (a) Testablecan be supported or refuted by experiment. (b) Specificidentifies variables and predicted relationship. (c) Falsifiablecould potentially be proven wrong.
  • ACT questions might ask "What hypothesis was the experiment testing?" Look for statements predicting how changing one variable affects another. Or "Does the data support the hypothesis?" Compare predicted outcomes to actual results

If the hypothesis predicted X would increase Y, and data shows Y decreased as X increased, the hypothesis is not supported. (5) Key distinction: The hypothesis guides experimental design. All procedures should logically test the hypothesis.

If an experiment manipulates temperature but the hypothesis concerns pH, the design doesn't match the hypothesis.

Independent, Dependent, and Controlled Variables

Variables are the core of experimental design: (1) Independent variable (IV): The factor the experimenter deliberately changes or manipulates. This is the cause in a cause-effect relationship.

If testing how fertilizer amount affects plant height, fertilizer amount is the IV. Typically plotted on the x-axis of graphs. (2) Dependent variable (DV): The factor that responds to changes in the independent variable.

This is the effect being measured. In the fertilizer example, plant height is the DVit depends on fertilizer amount.

Typically plotted on the y-axis. (3) Controlled variables (constants): All other factors that could affect the dependent variable but are kept the same across all experimental groups. For the plant experiment: same type of plant, same light, same water amount, same soil type, same temperature, same pot size, etc

Controlling these prevents them from confounding results. (4) Why control matters: If you change fertilizer amount AND light intensity at the same time, you can't determine which factor caused observed changes in growth. Valid experiments change only the independent variable while holding everything else constant. (5) ACT questions: "What was the independent variable?" Identify what the experimenters intentionally varied. "What was the dependent variable?" Identify what was measured as the outcome. "What should be kept constant?" List factors that could influence results but weren't being tested

Recognizing these three variable types is fundamental to understanding any experiment.

Control Groups and Experimental Groups

Control groups provide a baseline for comparison: (1) Experimental group(s): Receive the treatment or manipulation. If testing a new drug, experimental groups receive different doses of the drug.

If testing temperature effects, experimental groups are exposed to different temperatures. (2) Control group: Does NOT receive the experimental treatment but is otherwise treated identically. For a drug test, the control receives a placebo (inert substance).

For temperature test, control is kept at room temperature or a standard baseline temperature. (3) Purpose of controls: (a) Establish what happens without the experimental treatment. (b) Demonstrate that observed effects are due to the independent variable, not other factors. (c) Provide a reference point for comparison. If the experimental group shows 50% improvement but the control shows 45% improvement, the treatment only added 5%much of the change was due to other factors. (4) Types of controls: (a) Negative controlexpected to produce no effect (placebo, no treatment). (b) Positive controlexpected to produce a known effect (standard treatment that works). (c) Baseline/standard condition control (like room temperature when testing heat effects). (5) ACT scenarios: Questions ask "What was the purpose of the control group?" Answer: to provide a comparison baseline showing what happens without treatment

Or "How could this experiment be improved?" If there's no control group, answer: add a control group receiving no treatment to compare against experimental groups. Understanding that experiments compare treated groups against untreated controls is essential.

Sample Size, Replication, and Statistical Validity

Good experiments use multiple samples and replicates: (1) Sample size: The number of subjects or units in each experimental group. Testing one plant per group is unreliable; testing 20 plants per group is better.

Larger samples reduce the impact of individual variation and outliers. (2) Replication: Repeating the entire experiment multiple times (multiple trials). If you run the experiment once and get results, repeating it three more times and getting similar results confirms findings.

Replication increases confidence that results weren't due to chance. (3) Why size and replication matter: Biological and physical systems have natural variability. One plant might grow unusually fast or slow due to factors unrelated to treatment.

Averaging results from many plants gives a more accurate picture. Multiple trials demonstrate consistency. (4) Statistical significance: Larger samples and multiple replicates allow statistical tests to determine if differences between groups are real or due to random chance.

The ACT doesn't require calculating statistics, but understands that "statistically significant" means results are unlikely due to chance. (5) ACT questions: "How could the experiment be improved?" Common answer: increase sample size (test more subjects per group) or increase number of trials (repeat experiment multiple times). "Why did researchers use 50 plants in each group?" Answer: larger sample size increases reliability and reduces effects of individual variation. Recognizing that more data (more subjects, more trials) makes experiments more reliable is a key concept.

Example: Identifying Experimental Components Experiment: Researchers tested whether different amounts of sunlight affect tomato plant growth. They placed 10 plants in full sun, 10 in partial shade, and 10 in full shade.

All plants were the same variety, planted in identical soil, watered with 200 mL daily, and kept at 22�C. After 4 weeks, average plant height in each group was measured.

Research Question: How does sunlight amount affect tomato plant growth? Hypothesis: Tomato plants receiving more sunlight will grow taller (implied) Independent Variable: Amount of sunlight (full sun, partial shade, full shade) Dependent Variable: Plant height after 4 weeks Controlled Variables: Plant variety, soil type, water amount (200 mL/day), temperature (22�C), time period (4 weeks), number of plants per group (10) Experimental Groups: Full sun group, partial shade group, full shade group Control Group: The "full sun" group could serve as a positive control (optimal normal growth), or "partial shade" could be considered the baseline. Alternatively, you could argue there's no true control since all groups receive a treatment levela pure control might be indoor plants with artificial standard lighting.

Sample Size: 10 plants per group (good, but could be improved by increasing to 20-30) Replication: Not explicitly statedthey could improve by repeating the entire experiment multiple times Potential ACT Questions: 1. What was the independent variable? � Sunlight amount 2.

What should be kept constant? � Plant variety, water, temperature, soil, time 3. How could this be improved? � Increase sample size or repeat experiment (add trials).

2. Common Experimental Methods and Procedures

Different research questions require different experimental approaches, each with specific strengths and considerations.

Controlled Experiments: Manipulating One Variable

  • Structure: The experimenter actively manipulates the independent variable (assigns subjects to different treatment levels) while controlling all other variables. This allows causation to be determinedchanges in the dependent variable are caused by changes in the independent variable.
  • Example:
    • To test if temperature affects enzyme activity
    • prepare enzyme solutions at 10�C

All solutions have the same enzyme concentration, same substrate concentration, same pH, same volume. Measure reaction rate at each temperature.

Because only temperature varies, any differences in reaction rate must be caused by temperature. (3) Random assignment: In experiments with living subjects, randomly assigning subjects to groups ensures groups are equivalent at the start, preventing bias. If healthier plants are all placed in the fertilized group, you can't determine if results are due to fertilizer or initial health. (4) Advantages: Can establish cause-and-effect relationships

High internal validity (results are due to what you think they're due to). Can isolate effects of single variables. (5) Limitations: Can be artificial (lab conditions don't match real-world conditions)

Can't be used for unethical manipulations (can't expose humans to toxins to study effects). Sometimes not feasible (can't manipulate earthquake magnitude to study effects). (6) ACT context: Most ACT experiments are controlled experiments.

Questions test whether you recognize proper control, whether variables are properly isolated, and whether conclusions about causation are justified.

Observational Studies: Measuring Without Manipulation

  • Structure:
    • Researchers measure variables in their natural state without intervening. For example
    • observing bird populations in different forest types
    • measuring pollution levels in various lakes
    • or recording star temperatures and luminosities
  • When used: (a) Manipulation is impossible (can't manipulate star temperature, can't change Earth's atmosphere composition). (b) Manipulation is unethical (can't expose people to carcinogens). (c) Studying natural phenomena in realistic settings (animal behavior in wild vs. lab).
  • Correlation vs. causation: Observational studies can identify correlations (two variables are associated) but cannot definitively prove causation because many uncontrolled variables might be involved

If you observe that lakes near farms have more algae, you can't be certain fertilizer runoff caused itmaybe those lakes are also shallower (confounding variable). (4) Advantages: Realistic, natural conditions. Can study phenomena that can't be manipulated.

Often less expensive and faster than controlled experiments. (5) Limitations: Cannot establish causation conclusively. Many confounding variables

Less control means more uncertainty about what caused observed patterns. (6) ACT questions: May ask you to identify studies as observational. "Can the researchers conclude that X caused Y?" If it's an observational study, the answer is noonly correlation can be established. Understanding that observation shows relationships but not definitive causation is important.

Comparative Experiments: Testing Multiple Levels

  • Purpose: To determine not just IF a variable has an effect, but HOW the effect changes across a range of values. Does the relationship increase linearly? Is there an optimal level? Does the effect plateau?
  • Example:
    • Instead of just testing "fertilizer vs. no fertilizer
    • and 20 g of fertilizer per plant

This reveals whether more is always better, or if there's an optimal amount beyond which additional fertilizer doesn't help (or harms). (3) Dose-response experiments: Common in medicine and toxicology. Test different doses of a drug or toxin to see how response varies with concentration

Reveals relationships like "low doses help, high doses harm" or "no effect until a threshold dose, then strong effect." (4) Advantages: Provides detailed understanding of the relationship between variables. Can identify optimal conditions, thresholds, or limits.

Generates data for graphs showing trends. (5) ACT context: Many ACT experiments test 3-5 levels of the independent variable. Tables and graphs show how the dependent variable changes across these levels.

Questions ask you to identify trends (linear increase, plateau, inverse relationship) or predict outcomes at untested levels (interpolation or extrapolation based on the trend). Understanding that multiple test levels reveal the shape of the relationship is key.

Factorial Designs: Testing Multiple Variables Simultaneously

  • Structure:
    • Test all combinations of levels of different variables. For example
    • test three light levels (low
    • high) combined with two water levels (dry
    • wet) for six total treatment combinations: low light-dry
    • low light-wet
    • medium light-dry
    • medium light-wet
    • high light-dry
    • high light-wet
  • Purpose: (a) Determine individual effects of each variable. (b) Determine if variables interact (the effect of one variable depends on the level of another)

For instance, fertilizer might help plants only when they also receive adequate waterfertilizer and water interact. (3) Interactions: If high fertilizer increases growth when water is high but decreases growth when water is low, that's an interaction. The effect of fertilizer depends on water level

Interactions are important biological and chemical phenomena. (4) Advantages: Efficientcan study multiple variables in one experiment. Reveals interactions that separate experiments would miss

Reflects real-world complexity where multiple factors act together. (5) Challenges: More complex design and analysis. Requires many groups (3 levels � 2 levels = 6 groups; 3 levels � 3 levels = 9 groups).

Can be confusing to interpret when interactions are present. (6) ACT context: Some passages present factorial experiments with tables showing results for all combinations. Questions might ask "What is the effect of temperature when pH is high?" requiring you to look at the subset of data where pH = high

Or "Do temperature and pH interact?" requiring you to see if temperature's effect differs at different pH levels. Recognizing factorial designs helps you navigate complex data tables.

  • Example:
    • Comparing Experimental Methods Scenario: Studying the effect of exercise on heart rate Controlled Experiment: Randomly assign 60 people to three groups: no exercise (control)
    • moderate exercise (20 min walking)
    • intense exercise (20 min running)
  • Measure heart rate after exercise. All participants same age range, same time of day, same environment. Result: Can conclude exercise intensity causes different heart rates.
  • Observational Study:
    • Survey 200 people about their typical exercise habits and measure their resting heart rate. Compare heart rates of self-reported non-exercisers
    • moderate exercisers
    • and intense exercisers
  • Result: Can identify correlation (exercisers have different heart rates) but can't prove causationmaybe people with naturally lower heart rates are more inclined to exercise.
  • Comparative Experiment:
    • Test 5 exercise durations: 5 min
    • 25 min of running. Measure heart rate after each duration
  • Result: Shows how heart rate changes with exercise durationreveals the dose-response relationship
  • Factorial Design:
    • Test 3 exercise types (walking
    • running) � 2 durations (15 min
    • 30 min) = 6 groups
  • Result:
    • Determines effects of both exercise type and duration
    • plus whether they interact (e.g
    • maybe duration matters more for walking than running).

3. Identifying Flawed Designs and Confounding Variables

ACT questions frequently ask you to identify problems in experimental design and suggest improvements.

Confounding Variables: When Multiple Factors Vary Together

  • Definition: A confounding variable is a factor that affects the dependent variable and varies systematically with the independent variable, making it impossible to determine which variable caused observed effects.
  • Example: Testing fertilizer effects by placing fertilized plants in a greenhouse and unfertilized plants outdoors. Temperature and light differ between locations
  • Common confounds:
    • (a) Time-related confoundsif you test treatment A in winter and treatment B in summer
    • season confounds treatment. (b) Location confoundsdifferent locations may have different light
    • temperature
    • etc. (c) Subject characteristicsif you test drug on adults and placebo on children
    • age confounds treatment
  • Impact: Confounding ruins internal validity. You cannot interpret results because alternative explanations exist

Any conclusion about the independent variable is questionable. (5) Prevention: Control variables by keeping them constant across all groups. Randomize assignment so confounds distribute evenly across groups

Use matched pairs (subjects similar in potential confounding variables) or statistical controls. (6) ACT questions: "What is a confounding variable in this experiment?" Identify factors that differ between groups other than the intended independent variable. "How could confounding be eliminated?" Answer: control that variable by making it the same across all groups, or randomize to distribute its effects evenly.

Lack of Control Group

  • Problem:
    • If you give all participants a drug and measure improvement
    • you don't know if improvement was due to the drug or other factors like natural recovery
    • placebo effect
    • or time. Without a control group receiving no drug (or placebo)
    • you have no reference point
  • Example: Testing a new fertilizer by applying it to 20 plants and measuring growth

Plants grow 15 cm on average. Is this good? You don't know without a control group receiving no fertilizer to compare against.

Maybe unfertilized plants would have grown 14 cm (fertilizer barely helped) or maybe 5 cm (fertilizer helped a lot). (3) Solution: Include a control group treated identically except for the experimental treatment. For drug studies, give a placebo.

For fertilizer studies, include unfertilized plants.

  • Types of no-control errors: (a) All groups receive treatmentno untreated baseline. (b) Comparing to historical data (last year's results) rather than a concurrent controltoo many factors change over time. (c) Assuming a theoretical baseline without empirical control measurement.
  • ACT questions: "What flaw exists in this experimental design?" Answer: no control group. "How could this experiment be improved?" Answer: add a control group receiving no treatment to provide a comparison baseline

Recognizing missing controls is one of the most common ACT experimental design questions.

Inadequate Sample Size or Replication

Too few subjects or trials reduce reliability: (1) Problem: Small sample sizes are vulnerable to individual variation and outliers. If you test only 2 plants per group, one unusually large plant drastically affects the average.

Results might not represent the true effect. (2) Single trial problem: Running an experiment once provides limited confidence. Maybe that particular trial had unusual conditions

Repeating the experiment and getting consistent results validates findings. (3) Statistical issues: Small samples reduce statistical powerability to detect real effects. Small samples increase the role of chance

Conclusions from small samples are less generalizable. (4) How much is enough?: Depends on variability in the system. High variability requires larger samples

  • Solution: Increase sample size (more subjects per group) and/or increase replication (more trials of the entire experiment).
  • ACT questions: "The experiment used 3 plants per group

What is a limitation of this design?" Answer: small sample size increases effects of individual variation, reducing reliability. "How could reliability be increased?" Answer: increase sample size or number of trials. Understanding that "more data is better" is a fundamental principle.

Measurement Issues and Bias

How measurements are made affects data quality: (1) Precision and accuracy: Measurements should be both precise (consistent, repeatable) and accurate (close to true value). Using a poorly calibrated instrument gives inaccurate data.

Inconsistent measurement technique gives imprecise data. (2) Subjective vs. objective measures: Objective measures (temperature with thermometer, mass with scale) are preferred because they're quantifiable and reproducible. Subjective measures (rating pain on 1-10 scale, judging color as "dark" or "light") are vulnerable to bias and inconsistency. (3) Observer bias: If experimenters know which group is which, they might unconsciously measure or record data differently

Blinding (keeping experimenters unaware of group assignments until after measurement) prevents this. Double-blind experiments (neither subjects nor experimenters know group assignments until the end) are ideal for human studies. (4) Timing of measurement: Measuring at inconsistent times introduces variability.

If you measure one group in the morning and another in the afternoon, circadian rhythms might affect results. Standardize measurement timing. (5) ACT questions: "What is a potential source of bias in this experiment?" Look for subjective measurements, knowledge of group assignments by experimenters, or inconsistent measurement protocols. "How could measurement be improved?" Answer: use objective instruments, standardize timing, blind observers to group assignments, calibrate instruments

Recognizing that measurement quality affects data validity is important for evaluating experiments.

Example: Identifying and Fixing Flawed Designs Flawed Experiment 1: Confounding Design: To test if a new teaching method improves test scores, researchers use the new method in School A and the old method in School B. After one semester, School A students score higher.

Problem: Schools confounded with teaching method. School A might have better funding, more experienced teachers, different student populations, etc.

Fix: Use both methods within the same school. Randomly assign half the classes to new method, half to old method.

This controls for school-level variables. Flawed Experiment 2: No Control Design: Test a weight loss supplement by having 30 people take it for 8 weeks while also exercising 3x/week.

Participants lose an average of 5 pounds. Problem: No control group.

Can't determine if weight loss was due to supplement or exercise. Fix: Add three groups: (1) supplement + exercise, (2) placebo + exercise, (3) placebo + no exercise.

Compare results to isolate effects of supplement. Flawed Experiment 3: Small Sample Design: Test if fertilizer affects plant growth using 2 plants with fertilizer and 2 without.

Problem: Only 2 plants per group. Individual variation dominates.

One unusually large or small plant skews results. Fix: Increase to 20-30 plants per group.

Average results will be more representative. Flawed Experiment 4: Measurement Bias Design: Researcher rates "health" of plants on a 1-5 scale, knowing which plants received treatment.

Problem: Subjective rating + observer knows treatment = potential bias. Researcher might unconsciously rate treated plants higher.

Fix: (1) Use objective measure (plant height, biomass). (2) If using ratings, have a blind observer who doesn't know which plants were treated.

4. Strategic Approaches to Experimental Design Questions

Systematic strategies help you efficiently analyze experimental setups and answer ACT design questions.

The Variable Checklist: Quickly Analyzing Any Experiment

  • What is being manipulated? Identify the independent variablewhat did experimenters change on purpose? This is usually clear in the methods section: "Plants were exposed to four different temperatures..." � IV is temperature.
  • What is being measured? Identify the dependent variablewhat outcome are they recording? "Growth rate was measured..." � DV is growth rate.
  • What is being held constant? List controlled variables mentioned in the passage:
    • "All plants were the same species
    • received 100 mL water daily
    • and were kept at pH 7."
  • Is there a control group? Look for an untreated or baseline group. If one level is "no treatment" or "room temperature" or "placebo," that's likely the control.
  • Are sample sizes adequate? Note how many subjects per group and whether multiple trials were conducted.
  • Are there obvious confounds? Look for variables that changed along with the IV but weren't controlled

Answering these six questions gives you a complete understanding of the experimental structure and prepares you for most design questions.

Matching Procedures to Hypotheses

  • Hypothesis specifies variables: "Increasing temperature will increase reaction rate" identifies temperature (IV) and reaction rate (DV). The experiment must manipulate temperature and measure reaction rate.
  • Check for alignment: Does the IV in the experiment match the variable mentioned in the hypothesis? Does the DV match the predicted outcome? If hypothesis concerns temperature but experiment manipulates pressure, there's a mismatch.
  • ACT question type: "Does this experiment test the stated hypothesis?" Analyze whether manipulated and measured variables match the hypothesis
  • Alternative designs: If asked "What experiment would better test this hypothesis?", propose a design that directly manipulates the variable in the hypothesis and measures the predicted outcome.
  • Common mismatch:
    • Hypothesis predicts a mechanism or process
    • but experiment only measures end results without testing the mechanism. "Fertilizer increases growth by improving nitrogen uptake" requires measuring nitrogen uptake
    • not just final growth. This logical connection between hypothesis and experimental design is testable on the ACT

Improving Experiments: Common Suggestions

  • Add a control group: If missing, this is the #1 improvement. "Include a group receiving no treatment to provide a comparison baseline."
  • Increase sample size: "Test more subjects per group to reduce effects of individual variation and increase reliability."
  • Add replication: "Repeat the experiment multiple times to confirm results are consistent and not due to chance."
  • Control confounding variables: "Keep [specific variable] constant across all groups to prevent it from confounding results." Or "Randomize assignment to distribute confounding variables evenly."
  • Improve measurement: "Use objective instruments instead of subjective ratings" or "Standardize measurement timing" or "Blind observers to group assignments to prevent bias."
  • Test more levels:
    • "Include additional values of the independent variable to better understand the relationship" (e.g
    • if only testing 0 and 100
  • Extend time: "Increase duration to observe long-term effects" (if the experiment is very short). These are the most common valid improvements on ACT questions

Recognizing which apply to a given experiment allows you to answer improvement questions confidently.

Evaluating Whether Conclusions Are Justified

Not all conclusions follow logically from experimental results: (1) Overgeneralization: Concluding more than the data support. If you test one plant species, concluding "all plants respond this way" is overgeneralization.

  • Claiming causation from correlation:
    • If the study was observational, causation cannot be claimed. "X and Y are correlated" is justified
    • "X causes Y" is not (unless it's a controlled experiment)
  • Ignoring alternative explanations:
    • If confounding variables exist
    • alternative explanations are possible. The conclusion should acknowledge this: "Results suggest X may cause Y
    • but further research controlling for Z is needed."
  • Extrapolating beyond tested range: If temperature was tested from 20-40�C, concluding what happens at 0�C or 100�C is extrapolation

It might be reasonable, but it's not directly supported by the data. (5) ACT questions: "Is this conclusion justified based on the experimental design?" Evaluate whether the conclusion matches what was actually tested and controlled. "What is a limitation of this conclusion?" Identify overgeneralizations, confounds, or assumptions not tested. (6) Good conclusions: Are specific to tested conditions, acknowledge limitations, distinguish correlation from causation (when appropriate), and avoid claims beyond the data. Training yourself to critique conclusions develops scientific thinking valued by the ACT.

Example: Strategic Analysis of an Experiment Passage Summary: Researchers hypothesized that caffeine improves memory.

  • Example: Strategic Analysis of an Experiment Passage Summary: Researchers hypothesized that caffeine improves memory
  • They gave 20 college students a memory test, then had them drink coffee, then retested memory 30 minutes later.
  • Average scores increased from 72% to 78%. Variable Checklist: 1. What's manipulated? � Caffeine (before/after drinking coffee) 2. What's measured? � Memory test scores 3.
  • What's controlled? � Same subjects (before/after design), same test timing (30 min after), college students 4. Control group? � NOno group that didn't drink coffee 5.
  • Sample size? � 20 subjects (moderate, could be improved) 6. Confounds? � Practice effect (second test might be higher just from taking test twice), expectation (students might try harder after coffee)
  • unknown Hypothesis Match: Hypothesis concerns caffeine � Experiment gives caffeine  Hypothesis concerns memory � Experiment measures memory  Match is reasonable, but design has flaws Potential Improvements: 1.
  • Add control group receiving decaf coffee (controls for practice effect, liquid, ritual) 2
  • Use double-blind design (students don't know if they got regular or decaf; scorer doesn't know which group is which) 3.
  • Increase sample size to 50-100 4. Randomize whether students get caffeine or decaf first (if using crossover design) Conclusion Evaluation: Stated conclusion: "Caffeine improves memory" Justified? � NO Problems: (a) No controlimprovement might be practice effect.
  • (b) Correlation onlystudents expected coffee to help, so they might have concentrated harder. (c) Limited generalizationonly college students tested. Better conclusion: "Memory test scores increased after coffee consumption, but further research with a control group is needed to determine if caffeine specifically caused the improvement." ACT Question Examples: Q: "What is a major flaw in this design?" A: "No control group to account for practice effects from taking the test twice" Q: "How could this experiment be improved?" A: "Include a control group receiving decaffeinated coffee" OR "Increase sample size" Q: "Is the conclusion that caffeine improves memory justified?" A: "No, because alternative explanations (practice effect, expectation) were not controlled".

.

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Independent variable (IV) is what experimenters manipulate; dependent variable (DV) is what they measure as the outcome
  • ✓Controlled variables must be kept constant across all groups to prevent confounding and ensure valid conclusions
  • ✓Control groups provide untreated baseline for comparison; without controls, you can't determine if treatment caused effects
  • ✓Larger sample sizes and multiple trials (replication) increase reliability and reduce impact of individual variation
  • ✓Controlled experiments can establish causation; observational studies show correlation but not definitive causation
  • ✓Confounding variables change along with IV and provide alternative explanations for results, ruining internal validity
  • ✓Common design flaws: no control group, confounding variables, inadequate sample size, subjective measurements, observer bias
  • ✓Standard improvements: add control group, increase sample size, add replication, control confounds, improve measurement objectivity
  • ✓Experimental procedures must align with hypothesisvariables manipulated and measured should match those stated in hypothesis
  • ✓Conclusions must be justified by dataavoid overgeneralization, claiming causation without controls, or extrapolating beyond tested conditions

lessons.title: Topic 7.1 - Trigonometry
lessons.content:
Mastering trigonometry is essential for achieving top scores on the ACT Math section. This lesson covers SOHCAHTOA (sine, cosine, tangent relationships), the unit circle, trigonometric identities, radian measure, and trigonometric graphs. Trigonometry questions appear in 4-6 problems per ACT test and separate high scorers from average performers. Understanding how angles relate to sides in triangles and how trig functions behave is crucial for success.

1. Right Triangle Trigonometry (SOHCAHTOA)

The foundation of trigonometry lies in right triangle relationships. The mnemonic SOHCAHTOA helps remember the three primary ratios: sine equals opposite over hypotenuse, cosine equals adjacent over hypotenuse, and tangent equals opposite over adjacent. These ratios are defined for any acute angle in a right triangle and provide powerful tools for finding unknown sides and angles. Understanding these fundamental relationships is essential before moving to more advanced trigonometry concepts.

The Three Primary Ratios

For an angle θ in a right triangle:

SOH: sin(θ) = Opposite / Hypotenuse
CAH: cos(θ) = Adjacent / Hypotenuse
TOA: tan(θ) = Opposite / Adjacent

Example: In a right triangle, the hypotenuse is 13, one leg is 5. Find sin(θ), cos(θ), and tan(θ) for the angle opposite the leg of length 5.

First, find the other leg using Pythagorean theorem:
5² + b² = 13²
25 + b² = 169
b² = 144
b = 12

Now identify sides relative to θ:
Opposite = 5
Adjacent = 12
Hypotenuse = 13

Calculate ratios:
sin(θ) = 5/13
cos(θ) = 12/13
tan(θ) = 5/12

Special Right Triangles

45-45-90 Triangle:
Sides in ratio 1 : 1 : √2
If legs = 1, then hypotenuse = √2

sin(45°) = 1/√2 = √2/2
cos(45°) = 1/√2 = √2/2
tan(45°) = 1/1 = 1

30-60-90 Triangle:
Sides in ratio 1 : √3 : 2
Short leg: Long leg: Hypotenuse

For 30° angle:
sin(30°) = 1/2
cos(30°) = √3/2
tan(30°) = 1/√3 = √3/3

For 60° angle:
sin(60°) = √3/2
cos(60°) = 1/2
tan(60°) = √3

Using Inverse Trigonometric Functions

When you know the ratio and need the angle:

sin⁻¹(x) or arcsin(x) gives the angle whose sine is x
cos⁻¹(x) or arccos(x) gives the angle whose cosine is x
tan⁻¹(x) or arctan(x) gives the angle whose tangent is x

Example: If sin(θ) = 0.6, find θ
θ = sin⁻¹(0.6) ≈ 36.87°

Example: In a right triangle, opposite = 7, adjacent = 24. Find the angle.
tan(θ) = 7/24
θ = tan⁻¹(7/24) ≈ 16.26°

Solving for Unknown Sides

Example: A ladder leans against a wall at a 70° angle with the ground. If the ladder is 20 feet long, how high up the wall does it reach?

Setup:
The ladder is the hypotenuse (20 ft)
The height is opposite the 70° angle
Use: sin(θ) = opposite / hypotenuse

sin(70°) = h / 20
h = 20 × sin(70°)
h ≈ 20 × 0.9397
h ≈ 18.79 feet

ACT Example 1: Right Triangle Trig

In a right triangle, one angle is 35° and the side adjacent to this angle is 10. What is the length of the hypotenuse?

  • A) 8.2
  • B) 10
  • C) 12.2
  • D) 14.3
  • E) 17.4
  • Solution:
  • We have: adjacent = 10, need hypotenuse
  • Use CAH: cos(35°) = adjacent / hypotenuse
  • cos(35°) = 10 / h
  • h = 10 / cos(35°) ≈ 10 / 0.8192 ≈ 12.2
  • Answer: C — Use cosine for adjacent/hypotenuse!

2. The Unit Circle and Radian Measure

The unit circle is a circle with radius 1 centered at the origin, providing a geometric interpretation of trigonometric functions for all angles, not just acute angles in right triangles. Radian measure is an alternative to degrees where angles are measured by arc length on the unit circle. Understanding the unit circle allows you to evaluate trig functions for any angle and recognize patterns in their values. The relationship between degrees and radians is fundamental: 180° = π radians.

Converting Between Degrees and Radians

Key relationship: 180° = π radians

To convert degrees to radians: multiply by π/180
To convert radians to degrees: multiply by 180/π

Common conversions:

30° = π/6 radians
45° = π/4 radians
60° = π/3 radians
90° = π/2 radians
180° = π radians
270° = 3π/2 radians
360° = 2π radians

Example: Convert 135° to radians
135° × (π/180) = 135π/180 = 3π/4 radians

Example: Convert 5π/6 to degrees
(5π/6) × (180/π) = (5 × 180)/6 = 900/6 = 150°

Unit Circle Coordinates

For any angle θ on the unit circle:
Point coordinates: (cos θ, sin θ)

This means:
x-coordinate = cos(θ)
y-coordinate = sin(θ)
tan(θ) = sin(θ) / cos(θ) = y / x

Key points on unit circle:
0° (0 radians): (1, 0) → cos(0) = 1, sin(0) = 0
90° (π/2): (0, 1) → cos(90°) = 0, sin(90°) = 1
180° (π): (-1, 0) → cos(180°) = -1, sin(180°) = 0
270° (3π/2): (0, -1) → cos(270°) = 0, sin(270°) = -1
360° (2π): (1, 0) → back to start

Reference Angles and All Quadrants

ASTC rule (All Students Take Calculus):
Quadrant I (0° to 90°): All trig functions positive
Quadrant II (90° to 180°): Sine positive, others negative
Quadrant III (180° to 270°): Tangent positive, others negative
Quadrant IV (270° to 360°): Cosine positive, others negative

Example: Find sin(150°)
150° is in Quadrant II (sine positive)
Reference angle: 180° - 150° = 30°
sin(150°) = sin(30°) = 1/2

Example: Find cos(240°)
240° is in Quadrant III (cosine negative)
Reference angle: 240° - 180° = 60°
cos(240°) = -cos(60°) = -1/2

Coterminal Angles

Coterminal angles differ by 360° (or 2π radians) and have the same trig values.

Examples:
30°, 390°, 750°, -330° are all coterminal
sin(30°) = sin(390°) = sin(750°) = sin(-330°) = 1/2

To find coterminal angles:
Add or subtract 360° (or 2π radians)

Example: Find a positive coterminal angle for -120°
-120° + 360° = 240°

ACT Example 2: Unit Circle

What is the value of sin(7π/6)?

  • F) -1/2
  • G) -√3/2
  • H) 0
  • J) 1/2
  • K) √3/2
  • Solution:
  • Step 1: 7π/6 = π + π/6 = 180° + 30° = 210°
  • Step 2: 210° is in Quadrant III (sine negative)
  • Step 3: Reference angle = 210° - 180° = 30°
  • Step 4: sin(210°) = -sin(30°) = -1/2
  • Answer: F — Use reference angle and quadrant sign!

3. Trigonometric Identities and Equations

Trigonometric identities are equations that are true for all values of the variables. The most important are the Pythagorean identity, reciprocal identities, and quotient identities. These identities allow you to simplify expressions, solve equations, and transform between different trig functions. Understanding how to manipulate and apply these identities is crucial for advanced trigonometry problems on the ACT.

Fundamental Identities

Pythagorean Identity:
sin²θ + cos²θ = 1
(Most important identity!)

Variations:
sin²θ = 1 - cos²θ
cos²θ = 1 - sin²θ
1 + tan²θ = sec²θ
1 + cot²θ = csc²θ

Quotient Identities:
tan θ = sin θ / cos θ
cot θ = cos θ / sin θ

Reciprocal Identities:
csc θ = 1 / sin θ
sec θ = 1 / cos θ
cot θ = 1 / tan θ

Using Identities to Simplify

Practice Problem: If sin θ = 3/5 and θ is in Quadrant I, find cos θ Use Pythagorean identity: sin²θ + cos²θ = 1 (3/5)² + cos²θ = 1 9/25 + cos²θ = 1 cos²θ = 1 - 9/25 = 16/25 cos θ = ±4/5 Since θ is in Quadrant I (where cosine is positive): cos θ = 4/5 Example 2: Simplify (1 - sin²x) / cos x Use identity sin²x + cos²x = 1: 1 - sin²x = cos²x So: (1 - sin²x) / cos x = cos²x / cos x = cos x

Solving Trigonometric Equations

Example: Solve 2sin θ - 1 = 0 for 0° ≤ θ < 360°

Step 1: Isolate sin θ
2sin θ = 1
sin θ = 1/2

Step 2: Find angles where sin θ = 1/2
Reference angle: 30° (since sin 30° = 1/2)

Step 3: Sine is positive in Quadrants I and II
Quadrant I: θ = 30°
Quadrant II: θ = 180° - 30° = 150°

Solutions: θ = 30° or θ = 150°

Double-Angle and Sum Formulas

Double-Angle Formulas:
sin(2θ) = 2sin θ cos θ
cos(2θ) = cos²θ - sin²θ = 2cos²θ - 1 = 1 - 2sin²θ
tan(2θ) = 2tan θ / (1 - tan²θ)

Sum/Difference Formulas:
sin(A + B) = sin A cos B + cos A sin B
cos(A + B) = cos A cos B - sin A sin B

Example: If sin θ = 3/5 and cos θ = 4/5, find sin(2θ)
sin(2θ) = 2sin θ cos θ = 2(3/5)(4/5) = 24/25

ACT Example 3: Identities

Which of the following is equivalent to (sin²x)(csc²x) - 1?

  • A) -1
  • B) 0
  • C) 1
  • D) sin²x
  • E) cos²x
  • Solution:
  • Step 1: Use reciprocal identity: csc x = 1/sin x
  • So csc²x = 1/sin²x
  • Step 2: (sin²x)(csc²x) = (sin²x)(1/sin²x) = 1
  • Step 3: 1 - 1 = 0
  • Answer: B — Reciprocal functions multiply to 1!

4. Graphs of Trigonometric Functions

Understanding the graphs of trig functions helps visualize their periodic behavior and identify key features. The amplitude measures the height of oscillation, the period is the length of one complete cycle, and the phase shift indicates horizontal translation. Vertical shifts move the midline up or down. Recognizing transformations of parent functions y = sin x, y = cos x, and y = tan x is essential for analyzing trig graphs on the ACT.

Parent Function: y = sin x

Properties of y = sin x:
• Domain: all real numbers
• Range: [-1, 1]
• Period: 2π (or 360°)
• Amplitude: 1
• Starts at origin (0, 0)
• Maximum at π/2, minimum at 3π/2

Key points in one period:
(0, 0), (π/2, 1), (π, 0), (3π/2, -1), (2π, 0)

Parent Function: y = cos x

Properties of y = cos x:
• Domain: all real numbers
• Range: [-1, 1]
• Period: 2π (or 360°)
• Amplitude: 1
• Starts at maximum (0, 1)
• Zero crossings at π/2 and 3π/2

Key points in one period:
(0, 1), (π/2, 0), (π, -1), (3π/2, 0), (2π, 1)

Relationship: cos x = sin(x + π/2)
Cosine is sine shifted left by π/2

Transformations: y = A sin(Bx - C) + D

A: Amplitude = |A| (vertical stretch/compression)
If A is negative, graph reflects over x-axis

B: Period = 2π/|B| (horizontal stretch/compression)
Larger B means shorter period (more cycles)

C: Phase shift = C/B (horizontal shift)
Positive C/B shifts right, negative shifts left

D: Vertical shift (moves midline up/down)

Example: y = 3sin(2x - π) + 1
Amplitude = 3
Period = 2π/2 = π
Phase shift = π/2 (right)
Vertical shift = 1 (up)
Range: [1-3, 1+3] = [-2, 4]

Parent Function: y = tan x

Properties of y = tan x:
• Domain: all real numbers except π/2 + πn (where n is any integer)
• Range: all real numbers
• Period: π (not 2π!)
• No amplitude (unbounded)
• Vertical asymptotes at x = π/2 + πn
• Passes through origin (0, 0)

Key feature: Repeats every π radians
Increases from -∞ to +∞ between consecutive asymptotes

ACT Example 4: Trig Graphs

What is the period of the function y = sin(4x)?

  • F) π/4
  • G) π/2
  • H) π
  • J) 2π
  • K) 4π
  • Solution:
  • Formula: For y = sin(Bx), period = 2π/B
  • Here: B = 4
  • Period = 2π/4 = π/2
  • Interpretation: The function completes 4 cycles in 2π (so one cycle in π/2)
  • Answer: G — Larger B means shorter period!

.

Key Takeaways

  • ✓SOHCAHTOA: sin = opp/hyp, cos = adj/hyp, tan = opp/adj for right triangles
  • ✓Special triangles: 30-60-90 (1:√3:2) and 45-45-90 (1:1:√2) give exact trig values
  • ✓Radian conversion: 180° = π radians; multiply by π/180 or 180/π to convert
  • ✓Unit circle: point at angle θ has coordinates (cos θ, sin θ) on radius-1 circle
  • ✓ASTC rule: QI=All positive, QII=Sine positive, QIII=Tangent positive, QIV=Cosine positive
  • ✓Pythagorean identity: sin²θ + cos²θ = 1, the most important trig identity
  • ✓Reciprocals: csc = 1/sin, sec = 1/cos, cot = 1/tan
  • ✓Sine and cosine have amplitude 1, period 2π, and range [-1, 1]
  • ✓For y = A sin(Bx - C) + D: amplitude |A|, period 2π/B, phase shift C/B, vertical shift D
  • ✓Tangent has period π (not 2π) and vertical asymptotes at odd multiples of π/2

lessons.title: Topic 7.2 - Complex Numbers
lessons.content:
Understanding complex numbers expands the number system beyond real numbers to include imaginary numbers. The imaginary unit i is defined as √(-1), allowing us to take square roots of negative numbers. Complex numbers have the form a + bi where a is the real part and b is the imaginary part. This lesson covers operations with complex numbers, the complex plane, and powers of i. While complex numbers appear in only 1-2 ACT questions, understanding them is essential for students targeting scores above 32.

1. Introduction to Imaginary and Complex Numbers

The imaginary unit i is defined by the property i² = -1, which means i = √(-1). This definition allows us to work with square roots of negative numbers. A pure imaginary number is a number of the form bi where b is a real number. A complex number combines a real part and an imaginary part: z = a + bi. Understanding the fundamental properties of i and how to simplify powers of i is the foundation for all complex number operations.

The Imaginary Unit i

Definition: i = √(-1), which means i² = -1

Powers of i follow a pattern that repeats every 4:

i¹ = i
i² = -1
i³ = i² × i = -1 × i = -i
i⁴ = i² × i² = -1 × -1 = 1
i⁵ = i⁴ × i = 1 × i = i (pattern repeats)
i⁶ = i⁴ × i² = 1 × -1 = -1
i⁷ = i⁴ × i³ = 1 × -i = -i
i⁸ = i⁴ × i⁴ = 1 × 1 = 1

To find iⁿ for any n:
Divide n by 4 and use the remainder:
• Remainder 0 → iⁿ = 1
• Remainder 1 → iⁿ = i
• Remainder 2 → iⁿ = -1
• Remainder 3 → iⁿ = -i

Simplifying Square Roots of Negative Numbers

Rule: √(-a) = √(a) × √(-1) = i√a (where a > 0)

Example 1: Simplify √(-16)
√(-16) = √(16) × √(-1) = 4i

Example 2: Simplify √(-50)
√(-50) = √(50) × √(-1) = √(25 × 2) × i = 5i√2

Example 3: Simplify √(-12)
√(-12) = √(12) × i = √(4 × 3) × i = 2i√3

Standard Form of Complex Numbers

Standard form: a + bi
where a is the real part and b is the imaginary part (both a and b are real numbers)

Examples:
3 + 4i → real part = 3, imaginary part = 4
-2 + 7i → real part = -2, imaginary part = 7
5 → real part = 5, imaginary part = 0 (pure real number)
-3i → real part = 0, imaginary part = -3 (pure imaginary number)
0 → real part = 0, imaginary part = 0

Note: Real numbers are complex numbers with b = 0
Imaginary numbers are complex numbers with a = 0

Equality of Complex Numbers

Two complex numbers are equal if and only if their real parts are equal AND their imaginary parts are equal.

a + bi = c + di if and only if a = c and b = d

Example: If 2x + 3yi = 8 + 12i, find x and y
Real parts: 2x = 8 → x = 4
Imaginary parts: 3y = 12 → y = 4
Solution: x = 4, y = 4

ACT Example 1: Powers of i

What is the value of i⁴⁷?

  • A) -i
  • B) -1
  • C) 1
  • D) i
  • E) 47
  • Solution:
  • Step 1: Divide 47 by 4: 47 = 4(11) + 3
  • Step 2: Remainder is 3, so i⁴⁷ = i³
  • Step 3: i³ = -i
  • Answer: A — Powers of i cycle every 4!

2. Operations with Complex Numbers

Complex numbers can be added, subtracted, multiplied, and divided using algebraic rules similar to working with binomials. The key is to treat i as a variable initially, then simplify using i² = -1. Addition and subtraction combine like terms (real with real, imaginary with imaginary). Multiplication uses the distributive property, and division requires multiplying by the complex conjugate to eliminate i from the denominator.

Adding and Subtracting Complex Numbers

Rule: Add or subtract the real parts and imaginary parts separately
(a + bi) + (c + di) = (a + c) + (b + d)i
(a + bi) - (c + di) = (a - c) + (b - d)i

Practice Problem: (3 + 4i) + (2 + 5i) = (3 + 2) + (4 + 5)i = 5 + 9i Example 2: (7 + 2i) - (3 + 8i) = (7 - 3) + (2 - 8)i = 4 + (-6)i = 4 - 6i Example 3: (6 - 3i) + (-2 + 7i) = (6 - 2) + (-3 + 7)i = 4 + 4i

Multiplying Complex Numbers

Use FOIL or distributive property, then simplify using i² = -1

Practice Problem: (2 + 3i)(4 + 5i) First: 2 × 4 = 8 Outer: 2 × 5i = 10i Inner: 3i × 4 = 12i Last: 3i × 5i = 15i² = 15(-1) = -15 Combine: 8 + 10i + 12i + (-15) = -7 + 22i Example 2: (1 + 2i)(3 - 4i) = 1(3) + 1(-4i) + 2i(3) + 2i(-4i) = 3 - 4i + 6i - 8i² = 3 - 4i + 6i - 8(-1) = 3 - 4i + 6i + 8 = 11 + 2i Example 3: i(5 + 2i) = 5i + 2i² = 5i + 2(-1) = -2 + 5i

Complex Conjugates

Definition: The complex conjugate of a + bi is a - bi
(Change the sign of the imaginary part)

Notation: If z = a + bi, then z̄ = a - bi (z-bar)

Examples:
Conjugate of 3 + 4i is 3 - 4i
Conjugate of 2 - 5i is 2 + 5i
Conjugate of 6i is -6i
Conjugate of 7 is 7

Key property: (a + bi)(a - bi) = a² + b² (always a real number!)

Proof:
(a + bi)(a - bi) = a² - abi + abi - b²i²
= a² - b²(-1)
= a² + b²

Dividing Complex Numbers

Strategy: Multiply numerator and denominator by the conjugate of the denominator

Practice Problem: Simplify (3 + 2i) / (1 + 4i) Step 1: Conjugate of denominator is 1 - 4i Step 2: Multiply top and bottom by 1 - 4i = [(3 + 2i)(1 - 4i)] / [(1 + 4i)(1 - 4i)] Step 3: Expand numerator (3 + 2i)(1 - 4i) = 3 - 12i + 2i - 8i² = 3 - 12i + 2i + 8 = 11 - 10i Step 4: Expand denominator (1 + 4i)(1 - 4i) = 1² + 4² = 1 + 16 = 17 Step 5: Final answer = (11 - 10i) / 17 = 11/17 - (10/17)i Example 2: Simplify 6 / (2 - 3i) = [6(2 + 3i)] / [(2 - 3i)(2 + 3i)] = (12 + 18i) / (4 + 9) = (12 + 18i) / 13 = 12/13 + (18/13)i

ACT Example 2: Complex Multiplication

What is (3 - 2i)(3 + 2i)?

  • F) 5
  • G) 9 - 4i
  • H) 13
  • J) 5 + 12i
  • K) 9 + 4i²
  • Solution:
  • Recognize: These are complex conjugates!
  • Use formula: (a + bi)(a - bi) = a² + b²
  • (3 - 2i)(3 + 2i) = 3² + 2² = 9 + 4 = 13
  • Or use FOIL: 9 + 6i - 6i - 4i² = 9 + 4 = 13
  • Answer: H — Conjugates multiply to give real number!

3. The Complex Plane

The complex plane (also called the Argand diagram) provides a geometric representation of complex numbers. The horizontal axis represents the real part, and the vertical axis represents the imaginary part. Each complex number a + bi corresponds to the point (a, b). The modulus (or absolute value) of a complex number is its distance from the origin, calculated as |a + bi| = √(a² + b²).

Plotting Complex Numbers

To plot a + bi:
• Move a units along the real (horizontal) axis
• Move b units along the imaginary (vertical) axis
• Mark the point (a, b)

Examples:
3 + 4i → point (3, 4)
-2 + 3i → point (-2, 3)
5 - 2i → point (5, -2)
-4 - 3i → point (-4, -3)
6 → point (6, 0) on real axis
4i → point (0, 4) on imaginary axis

Absolute Value (Modulus) of Complex Numbers

Formula: |a + bi| = √(a² + b²)
This is the distance from the origin to the point (a, b)

Practice Problem: Find |3 + 4i| |3 + 4i| = √(3² + 4²) = √(9 + 16) = √25 = 5 Example 2: Find |5 - 12i| |5 - 12i| = √(5² + (-12)²) = √(25 + 144) = √169 = 13 Example 3: Find |-6 + 8i| |-6 + 8i| = √((-6)² + 8²) = √(36 + 64) = √100 = 10 Note: This is the same as the Pythagorean theorem—finding the hypotenuse of a right triangle with legs a and b.

Properties of Absolute Value

Key properties:

1. |z| ≥ 0 for all complex numbers z
2. |z| = 0 if and only if z = 0
3. |z̄| = |z| (conjugate has same modulus)
4. |z₁ × z₂| = |z₁| × |z₂|
5. |z₁ / z₂| = |z₁| / |z₂| (if z₂ ≠ 0)
6. |z|² = z × z̄ = a² + b² (for z = a + bi)

Example: Verify |3 + 4i|² = (3 + 4i)(3 - 4i)
Left side: |3 + 4i|² = 5² = 25
Right side: (3 + 4i)(3 - 4i) = 9 + 16 = 25 ✓

Geometric Interpretation of Operations

Addition: Vector addition (parallelogram rule)
To add z₁ and z₂, form a parallelogram with z₁ and z₂ as adjacent sides
The sum is the diagonal from the origin

Subtraction: Vector from second point to first
z₁ - z₂ is the vector from z₂ to z₁

Multiplication by i: Rotates 90° counterclockwise
i × (a + bi) = ai + bi² = -b + ai
Point (a, b) rotates to point (-b, a)

Complex conjugate: Reflection across real axis
Point (a, b) reflects to (a, -b)

ACT Example 3: Absolute Value

What is the absolute value of 8 - 6i?

  • A) 2
  • B) 6
  • C) 8
  • D) 10
  • E) 14
  • Solution:
  • Formula: |a + bi| = √(a² + b²)
  • |8 - 6i| = √(8² + (-6)²)
  • = √(64 + 36)
  • = √100 = 10
  • Answer: D — Use Pythagorean theorem!

4. Applications and Advanced Concepts

Complex numbers have important applications in solving quadratic equations with negative discriminants, understanding polynomial factorization, and working with complex roots. The Fundamental Theorem of Algebra states that every polynomial of degree n has exactly n complex roots (counting multiplicities). Complex conjugate pairs always appear together as roots of polynomials with real coefficients, which is essential for factoring and solving equations.

Solving Quadratic Equations with Complex Solutions

When discriminant b² - 4ac < 0, solutions are complex

Example 1: Solve x² + 4x + 13 = 0

Using quadratic formula:
x = [-4 ± √(16 - 52)] / 2
x = [-4 ± √(-36)] / 2
x = [-4 ± 6i] / 2
x = -2 ± 3i

Solutions: x = -2 + 3i or x = -2 - 3i (complex conjugate pair)

Example 2: Solve x² - 2x + 5 = 0
x = [2 ± √(4 - 20)] / 2
x = [2 ± √(-16)] / 2
x = [2 ± 4i] / 2
x = 1 ± 2i

Complex Conjugate Root Theorem

Theorem: If a polynomial has real coefficients and a + bi is a root, then a - bi is also a root.

Example: If 2 + 3i is a root of a polynomial with real coefficients, then 2 - 3i must also be a root.

Application: Find a quadratic with real coefficients having root 3 + 2i

Step 1: Other root must be 3 - 2i

Step 2: Quadratic is:
[x - (3 + 2i)][x - (3 - 2i)] = 0

Step 3: Expand
= x² - (3 - 2i)x - (3 + 2i)x + (3 + 2i)(3 - 2i)
= x² - 6x + (9 + 4)
= x² - 6x + 13

Simplifying Complex Expressions

Practice Problem: Simplify (1 + i)⁴ Method 1: Expand step by step (1 + i)² = 1 + 2i + i² = 1 + 2i - 1 = 2i (1 + i)⁴ = [(1 + i)²]² = (2i)² = 4i² = -4 Example 2: Simplify (2 - i)³ (2 - i)² = 4 - 4i + i² = 4 - 4i - 1 = 3 - 4i (2 - i)³ = (2 - i)(3 - 4i) = 6 - 8i - 3i + 4i² = 6 - 11i - 4 = 2 - 11i

Complex Numbers in Equations

Example: If z = 2 + i, find z² + 3z + 5

Step 1: Calculate z²
z² = (2 + i)² = 4 + 4i + i² = 4 + 4i - 1 = 3 + 4i

Step 2: Calculate 3z
3z = 3(2 + i) = 6 + 3i

Step 3: Add all terms
z² + 3z + 5 = (3 + 4i) + (6 + 3i) + 5
= 14 + 7i

ACT Example 4: Complex Division

What is 10 / (3 - i) in standard form a + bi?

  • F) 3 + i
  • G) 3 - i
  • H) 30/10 + 10i/10
  • J) 3 + i/10
  • K) 3 + i
  • Solution:
  • Step 1: Multiply by conjugate 3 + i
  • [10(3 + i)] / [(3 - i)(3 + i)]
  • = (30 + 10i) / (9 + 1)
  • = (30 + 10i) / 10
  • = 3 + i
  • Answer: K — Multiply by conjugate to eliminate i from denominator!

.

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Imaginary unit: i = √(-1), so i² = -1; powers of i cycle every 4 (i, -1, -i, 1)
  • ✓Standard form a + bi: a is real part, b is imaginary part (both real numbers)
  • ✓Add/subtract complex numbers by combining real parts and imaginary parts separately
  • ✓Multiply using FOIL or distributive property, then simplify using i² = -1
  • ✓Complex conjugate of a + bi is a - bi; they multiply to give a² + b² (real number)
  • ✓Divide by multiplying numerator and denominator by conjugate of denominator
  • ✓Absolute value: |a + bi| = √(a² + b²), distance from origin in complex plane
  • ✓Complex plane: plot a + bi as point (a, b) with real axis horizontal, imaginary vertical
  • ✓Quadratics with negative discriminant have complex conjugate pair solutions
  • ✓Complex conjugate roots: if polynomial has real coefficients and root a+bi, then a-bi also root

lessons.title: Topic 7.3 - Matrices
lessons.content:
Understanding matrices provides powerful tools for organizing data and solving systems of equations. A matrix is a rectangular array of numbers arranged in rows and columns. This lesson covers matrix operations (addition, subtraction, multiplication), determinants, inverse matrices, and using matrices to solve systems of equations. While matrices appear infrequently on the ACT (1-2 questions), understanding them is important for advanced mathematics and demonstrates mathematical sophistication.

1. Matrix Basics and Operations

A matrix is denoted by its dimensions: an m×n matrix has m rows and n columns. The entries or elements are the individual numbers in the matrix, typically denoted aᵢⱼ where i is the row and j is the column. Matrix addition and subtraction require matrices of the same dimensions, while multiplication follows special rules based on matching inner dimensions.

Matrix Notation and Terminology

A 2×3 matrix (2 rows, 3 columns):

A = [a₁₁ a₁₂ a₁₃]
    [a₂₁ a₂₂ a₂₃]

Example:
A = [1 2 3]
    [4 5 6]

Element a₁₂ = 2 (row 1, column 2)
Element a₂₃ = 6 (row 2, column 3)

Special matrices:
• Square matrix: Same number of rows and columns (n×n)
• Row matrix: 1×n matrix (single row)
• Column matrix: m×1 matrix (single column)
• Zero matrix: All entries are zero
• Identity matrix I: Square matrix with 1s on main diagonal, 0s elsewhere

Matrix Addition and Subtraction

Rule: Add or subtract corresponding elements. Matrices must have the same dimensions.

Practice Problem: Addition A = [1 2] B = [5 6]     [3 4] [7 8] A + B = [1+5 2+6] = [6 8]         [3+7 4+8] [10 12] Example 2: Subtraction A - B = [1-5 2-6] = [-4 -4]         [3-7 4-8] [-4 -4] Properties: • A + B = B + A (commutative) • (A + B) + C = A + (B + C) (associative) • A + 0 = A (zero matrix is additive identity)

Scalar Multiplication

Rule: Multiply each element by the scalar (number)

Example: If A = [2 -1], find 3A
                         [4 5]

3A = [3·2 3·(-1)] = [6 -3]
     [3·4 3·5] [12 15]

Properties:
• k(A + B) = kA + kB
• (k + m)A = kA + mA
• k(mA) = (km)A
• 1·A = A

Matrix Multiplication

Rule: For A(m×n) × B(n×p), result is C(m×p). Element cᵢⱼ = sum of (row i of A) × (column j of B)
Key: Number of columns in A must equal number of rows in B

Example: Multiply A(2×3) × B(3×2)

A = [1 2 3] B = [7 8]
    [4 5 6] [9 10]
                        [11 12]

Calculate AB (will be 2×2):

Entry (1,1): (1)(7) + (2)(9) + (3)(11) = 7 + 18 + 33 = 58
Entry (1,2): (1)(8) + (2)(10) + (3)(12) = 8 + 20 + 36 = 64
Entry (2,1): (4)(7) + (5)(9) + (6)(11) = 28 + 45 + 66 = 139
Entry (2,2): (4)(8) + (5)(10) + (6)(12) = 32 + 50 + 72 = 154

AB = [58 64]
     [139 154]

Important: Matrix multiplication is NOT commutative!
Generally AB ≠ BA

ACT Example 1: Matrix Operations

If A = [2 3] and B = [1 -1], what is 2A + B?
       [4 5]         [2 3]

  • A) [3 2]
  •       [6 8]
  • B) [5 5]
  •       [10 13]
  • C) [5 7]
  •       [10 11]
  • D) [4 5]
  •       [10 13]
  • E) [6 7]
  •       [12 16]
  • Solution:
  • Step 1: Calculate 2A = [4 6]
  •                                 [8 10]
  • Step 2: Add B: [4+1 6+(-1)] = [5 5]
  •                    [8+2 10+3]     [10 13]
  • Answer: B — Scalar multiply first, then add!

2. Determinants and Special Properties

The determinant is a special number calculated from a square matrix that provides important information about the matrix. Denoted det(A) or |A|, the determinant determines whether a matrix is invertible (det ≠ 0) or singular (det = 0). For 2×2 matrices, the determinant formula is straightforward. Determinants are essential for finding inverse matrices and solving systems of equations using Cramer's Rule.

Determinant of 2×2 Matrices

Formula: For A = [a b], det(A) = ad - bc
                           [c d]

Practice Problem: Find det([3 2])                                [1 4] det = (3)(4) - (2)(1) = 12 - 2 = 10 Example 2: Find det([5 -2])                                [-3 1] det = (5)(1) - (-2)(-3) = 5 - 6 = -1 Example 3: Find det([6 3])                                [4 2] det = (6)(2) - (3)(4) = 12 - 12 = 0 (This matrix is singular—not invertible)

Determinant of 3×3 Matrices

Method: Expand along first row (or any row/column)

For A = [a b c], use:
             [d e f]
             [g h i]

det(A) = a·det([e f]) - b·det([d f]) + c·det([d e])
                     [h i]           [g i]           [g h]

= a(ei - fh) - b(di - fg) + c(dh - eg)

Example: Find det([2 1 3])
                               [0 4 1]
                               [5 2 0]

= 2·det([4 1]) - 1·det([0 1]) + 3·det([0 4])
             [2 0]           [5 0]           [5 2]

= 2(0 - 2) - 1(0 - 5) + 3(0 - 20)
= 2(-2) - 1(-5) + 3(-20)
= -4 + 5 - 60 = -59

Properties of Determinants

Key properties:

1. det(I) = 1 (identity matrix)
2. det(AB) = det(A) × det(B)
3. det(A^T) = det(A) (transpose has same determinant)
4. det(kA) = k^n × det(A) for n×n matrix
5. If det(A) = 0, matrix has no inverse (singular)
6. If det(A) ≠ 0, matrix is invertible
7. Swapping two rows multiplies determinant by -1
8. If two rows are identical, determinant = 0
9. Multiplying a row by k multiplies determinant by k

Identity Matrix and Matrix Powers

Identity matrix I: When multiplied by any matrix, leaves it unchanged

2×2 identity: I = [1 0]
                             [0 1]

3×3 identity: I = [1 0 0]
                             [0 1 0]
                             [0 0 1]

Property: AI = IA = A

Matrix powers:
A² = A × A
A³ = A × A × A
A⁰ = I (by definition)

ACT Example 2: Determinants

What is the determinant of [4 3]?
                                   [2 5]

  • F) 6
  • G) 9
  • H) 14
  • J) 20
  • K) 26
  • Solution:
  • Formula: det = ad - bc
  • det = (4)(5) - (3)(2)
  • = 20 - 6 = 14
  • Answer: H — Multiply main diagonal minus other diagonal!

3. Inverse Matrices

The inverse of a matrix A, denoted A⁻¹, is the matrix that when multiplied by A gives the identity matrix: AA⁻¹ = A⁻¹A = I. Not all matrices have inverses—only square matrices with non-zero determinants are invertible. The inverse is useful for solving matrix equations and systems of linear equations. For 2×2 matrices, there's a straightforward formula. Inverse matrices satisfy the property (AB)⁻¹ = B⁻¹A⁻¹ (note the reversed order).

Finding the Inverse of a 2×2 Matrix

Formula: If A = [a b], then A⁻¹ = (1/det(A)) × [d -b]
                           [c d]                                   [-c a]
(Swap a and d, negate b and c, divide by determinant)

Practice Problem: Find the inverse of A = [3 2]                                                  [1 4] Step 1: Find determinant det(A) = (3)(4) - (2)(1) = 12 - 2 = 10 Step 2: Apply formula A⁻¹ = (1/10) × [4 -2]                    [-1 3] = [4/10 -2/10] = [0.4 -0.2]   [-1/10 3/10] [-0.1 0.3] Verify: AA⁻¹ should equal I [3 2] × [0.4 -0.2] = [1 0] ✓ [1 4] [-0.1 0.3] [0 1]

When Does an Inverse Exist?

A matrix A has an inverse if and only if:
1. A is square (same number of rows and columns)
2. det(A) ≠ 0

Example of non-invertible matrix:
A = [2 4]
    [3 6]

det(A) = (2)(6) - (4)(3) = 12 - 12 = 0
Since det(A) = 0, this matrix has no inverse (singular matrix)

Why? The rows are proportional (second row = 1.5 × first row)

Properties of Inverse Matrices

Key properties:

1. AA⁻¹ = A⁻¹A = I
2. (A⁻¹)⁻¹ = A (inverse of inverse is original)
3. (AB)⁻¹ = B⁻¹A⁻¹ (order reverses!)
4. (A^T)⁻¹ = (A⁻¹)^T
5. det(A⁻¹) = 1/det(A)
6. If A is invertible, then A⁻¹ is unique
7. I⁻¹ = I (identity is its own inverse)

Using Inverses to Solve Matrix Equations

To solve AX = B for X:
Multiply both sides by A⁻¹ on the left:
A⁻¹(AX) = A⁻¹B
(A⁻¹A)X = A⁻¹B
IX = A⁻¹B
X = A⁻¹B

Example: Solve [2 1]X = [5]
                         [3 4]     [6]

First find A⁻¹ where A = [2 1]
                                  [3 4]
det(A) = 8 - 3 = 5
A⁻¹ = (1/5)[4 -1]
               [-3 2]

X = A⁻¹B = (1/5)[4 -1] × [5] = (1/5)[14] = [14/5]
                  [-3 2] [6]        [-3] [-3/5]

ACT Example 3: Inverse Matrices

Which of the following is the inverse of [5 2]?
                                                     [2 1]

  • A) [1 -2]
  •       [-2 5]
  • B) [1/5 2/5]
  •       [2/5 1/5]
  • C) [5 2]
  •       [2 1]
  • D) [-5 -2]
  •       [-2 -1]
  • E) [1/1 -2/1]
  •       [-2/1 5/1]
  • Solution:
  • Step 1: det = (5)(1) - (2)(2) = 5 - 4 = 1
  • Step 2: A⁻¹ = (1/1) × [1 -2] = [1 -2]
  •                              [-2 5]    [-2 5]
  • Answer: A — Swap diagonal, negate off-diagonal, divide by det!

4. Matrices and Systems of Equations

Matrices provide a powerful method for representing and solving systems of linear equations. A system can be written in matrix form as AX = B, where A is the coefficient matrix, X is the variable matrix, and B is the constant matrix. When A is invertible, the solution is X = A⁻¹B. This method is particularly efficient for solving multiple systems with the same coefficients but different constants. Understanding matrix representation connects algebra, geometry, and linear transformations.

Writing Systems in Matrix Form

System of equations:
2x + 3y = 7
4x + 5y = 11

Matrix form AX = B:
[2 3] × [x] = [7]
[4 5] [y] [11]

Where:
A = [2 3] (coefficient matrix)
    [4 5]

X = [x] (variable matrix)
    [y]

B = [7] (constant matrix)
    [11]

Solving Using Matrix Inverses

Example: Solve the system above using matrices

Step 1: Find det(A)
det(A) = (2)(5) - (3)(4) = 10 - 12 = -2

Step 2: Find A⁻¹
A⁻¹ = (1/-2) × [5 -3]
                  [-4 2]

= [-5/2 3/2]
  [2 -1]

Step 3: Calculate X = A⁻¹B
X = [-5/2 3/2] × [7]
    [2 -1] [11]

= [(-5/2)(7) + (3/2)(11)]
  [(2)(7) + (-1)(11)]

= [-35/2 + 33/2] = [-2/2] = [-1]
  [14 - 11] [3] [3]

Solution: x = -1, y = 3

Augmented Matrix and Row Operations

Augmented matrix [A|B]: Combine coefficient and constant matrices

For system: 2x + 3y = 7
              4x + 5y = 11

Augmented matrix: [2 3 | 7]
                       [4 5 | 11]

Row operations (preserve solutions):
1. Swap two rows
2. Multiply a row by nonzero constant
3. Add multiple of one row to another

Goal: Transform to [I|X] where X is the solution

Interpreting Solutions

Three possibilities for a system:

1. Unique solution: det(A) ≠ 0
Lines intersect at exactly one point
Matrix A is invertible

2. No solution: det(A) = 0 and system is inconsistent
Lines are parallel (never intersect)
No solution exists

3. Infinitely many solutions: det(A) = 0 and system is dependent
Lines are identical (overlap completely)
Infinitely many points satisfy both equations

ACT Example 4: Systems and Matrices

The system 3x + 2y = 8 and x + y = 3 can be written as AX = B. What is matrix A?

  • F) [3 1]
  •       [2 1]
  • G) [3 2]
  •       [1 1]
  • H) [8 3]
  •       [3 1]
  • J) [x y]
  •       [x y]
  • K) [8]
  •       [3]
  • Solution:
  • Matrix A contains the coefficients:
  • First equation 3x + 2y = 8 → coefficients [3 2]
  • Second equation x + y = 3 → coefficients [1 1]
  • A = [3 2]
  •      [1 1]
  • Answer: G — Use coefficients of variables in order!

.

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Matrix dimensions m×n mean m rows and n columns; element aᵢⱼ is in row i, column j
  • ✓Add/subtract matrices by combining corresponding elements; must have same dimensions
  • ✓Multiply A(m×n) × B(n×p) to get C(m×p); inner dimensions must match
  • ✓Matrix multiplication is NOT commutative: generally AB ≠ BA
  • ✓For 2×2 matrix [a b; c d], determinant = ad - bc (main diagonal minus other diagonal)
  • ✓Matrix is invertible if and only if determinant ≠ 0 (non-singular)
  • ✓For 2×2 inverse: swap diagonal, negate off-diagonal, divide by determinant
  • ✓Inverse property: AA⁻¹ = A⁻¹A = I (identity matrix)
  • ✓System AX = B has solution X = A⁻¹B when A is invertible
  • ✓Coefficient matrix A contains coefficients of variables from each equation as rows

lessons.title: Topic 7.4 - Vectors
lessons.content:
Understanding vectors provides powerful tools for representing quantities with both magnitude and direction. Unlike scalars (numbers with only magnitude), vectors are essential for describing displacement, velocity, and force. This lesson covers vector operations (addition, subtraction, scalar multiplication), component form, and the dot product. While vectors appear infrequently on the ACT (0-1 questions), mastering them demonstrates advanced mathematical thinking and prepares you for college-level physics and engineering.

1. Vector Basics and Notation

A vector is a quantity with both magnitude (size) and direction. Vectors are typically represented by arrows, where the length represents magnitude and the arrow direction represents the direction. In component form, a 2D vector is written as ⟨a, b⟩ or as ai + bj, where a is the horizontal component and b is the vertical component. The magnitude (or length) of vector v is denoted |v| or ||v||.

Vector Notation and Representation

Common notations for vectors:

• Bold lowercase: v, u, w
• Arrow notation: v⃗, u⃗, w⃗
• Component form: ⟨3, 4⟩ or 3i + 4j
• Column matrix: [3]
                      [4]

Position vector: Vector from origin to point (a, b)
Position vector to (3, 4) is ⟨3, 4⟩

Zero vector: ⟨0, 0⟩ has magnitude 0 and no specific direction

Unit vector: Vector with magnitude 1
Standard unit vectors: i = ⟨1, 0⟩ (horizontal), j = ⟨0, 1⟩ (vertical)

Finding Vector Components

Given initial point A(x₁, y₁) and terminal point B(x₂, y₂):
Vector AB⃗ = ⟨x₂ - x₁, y₂ - y₁⟩

Example 1: Find vector from A(1, 2) to B(5, 7)
AB⃗ = ⟨5 - 1, 7 - 2⟩ = ⟨4, 5⟩

Example 2: Find vector from C(-3, 4) to D(2, -1)
CD⃗ = ⟨2 - (-3), -1 - 4⟩ = ⟨5, -5⟩

Example 3: Find vector from origin to P(6, -8)
OP⃗ = ⟨6 - 0, -8 - 0⟩ = ⟨6, -8⟩

Magnitude (Length) of a Vector

Formula: For v = ⟨a, b⟩, magnitude |v| = √(a² + b²)
This is the distance formula/Pythagorean theorem

Practice Problem: Find |⟨3, 4⟩| |v| = √(3² + 4²) = √(9 + 16) = √25 = 5 Example 2: Find |⟨-5, 12⟩| |v| = √((-5)² + 12²) = √(25 + 144) = √169 = 13 Example 3: Find |⟨6, -8⟩| |v| = √(6² + (-8)²) = √(36 + 64) = √100 = 10 Note: These are the 3-4-5, 5-12-13, and 6-8-10 Pythagorean triples!

Direction Angle of a Vector

Direction angle θ: Angle measured counterclockwise from positive x-axis

Formula: tan(θ) = b/a for vector ⟨a, b⟩
So θ = tan⁻¹(b/a)

Example: Find direction angle of ⟨3, 3⟩
tan(θ) = 3/3 = 1
θ = tan⁻¹(1) = 45°

Important: Must consider quadrant!
• Quadrant I: θ as calculated
• Quadrant II: θ = 180° - |calculated angle|
• Quadrant III: θ = 180° + |calculated angle|
• Quadrant IV: θ = 360° - |calculated angle|

ACT Example 1: Vector Components

What is the magnitude of the vector from point (2, -3) to point (8, 5)?

  • A) 6
  • B) 8
  • C) 10
  • D) 14
  • E) 100
  • Solution:
  • Step 1: Find vector components
  • v = ⟨8 - 2, 5 - (-3)⟩ = ⟨6, 8⟩
  • Step 2: Find magnitude
  • |v| = √(6² + 8²) = √(36 + 64) = √100 = 10
  • Answer: C — Use distance formula for magnitude!

2. Vector Operations

Vectors can be added, subtracted, and multiplied by scalars. Vector addition follows the parallelogram rule or tip-to-tail method geometrically, and component-wise algebraically. Scalar multiplication changes the magnitude and potentially reverses the direction (if scalar is negative) without changing the orientation. Understanding these operations is essential for physics applications and geometric transformations.

Vector Addition

Component-wise addition: ⟨a₁, b₁⟩ + ⟨a₂, b₂⟩ = ⟨a₁ + a₂, b₁ + b₂⟩

Practice Problem: ⟨3, 4⟩ + ⟨2, -1⟩ = ⟨3 + 2, 4 + (-1)⟩ = ⟨5, 3⟩ Example 2: ⟨-2, 5⟩ + ⟨7, -3⟩ = ⟨-2 + 7, 5 + (-3)⟩ = ⟨5, 2⟩ Geometric interpretation (tip-to-tail): Place tail of second vector at tip of first vector The sum vector goes from tail of first to tip of second Properties: • Commutative: u + v = v + u • Associative: (u + v) + w = u + (v + w) • Identity: v + 0 = v • Inverse: v + (-v) = 0

Vector Subtraction

Component-wise subtraction: ⟨a₁, b₁⟩ - ⟨a₂, b₂⟩ = ⟨a₁ - a₂, b₁ - b₂⟩

Practice Problem: ⟨7, 8⟩ - ⟨3, 2⟩ = ⟨7 - 3, 8 - 2⟩ = ⟨4, 6⟩ Example 2: ⟨-1, 4⟩ - ⟨5, -2⟩ = ⟨-1 - 5, 4 - (-2)⟩ = ⟨-6, 6⟩ Alternative: u - v = u + (-v) Subtract by adding the opposite vector Geometric interpretation: u - v is the vector from tip of v to tip of u (When both start at same point)

Scalar Multiplication

Multiply each component by scalar: k⟨a, b⟩ = ⟨ka, kb⟩

Practice Problem: 3⟨2, -4⟩ = ⟨3·2, 3·(-4)⟩ = ⟨6, -12⟩ Example 2: -2⟨5, 3⟩ = ⟨-2·5, -2·3⟩ = ⟨-10, -6⟩ Effect on magnitude: |kv| = |k| · |v| Scalar multiplication scales the magnitude by |k| Effect on direction: • k > 0: Same direction as original • k < 0: Opposite direction • k = 0: Zero vector (no direction) Properties: • k(u + v) = ku + kv • (k + m)v = kv + mv • k(mv) = (km)v • 1v = v

Unit Vectors

Unit vector: Vector with magnitude 1

To find unit vector in direction of v:
u = v / |v| = (1/|v|) · v

Example: Find unit vector in direction of ⟨3, 4⟩

Step 1: Find magnitude
|v| = √(3² + 4²) = √25 = 5

Step 2: Divide by magnitude
u = (1/5)⟨3, 4⟩ = ⟨3/5, 4/5⟩

Verify: |u| = √((3/5)² + (4/5)²) = √(9/25 + 16/25) = √(25/25) = 1 ✓

Standard unit vectors:
i = ⟨1, 0⟩ (points right)
j = ⟨0, 1⟩ (points up)
Any vector ⟨a, b⟩ = ai + bj

ACT Example 2: Vector Operations

If u = ⟨4, -3⟩ and v = ⟨-1, 5⟩, what is 2u - v?

  • F) ⟨7, -11⟩
  • G) ⟨9, -11⟩
  • H) ⟨7, -1⟩
  • J) ⟨9, -1⟩
  • K) ⟨3, 2⟩
  • Solution:
  • Step 1: Calculate 2u
  • 2u = 2⟨4, -3⟩ = ⟨8, -6⟩
  • Step 2: Subtract v
  • 2u - v = ⟨8, -6⟩ - ⟨-1, 5⟩ = ⟨8-(-1), -6-5⟩ = ⟨9, -11⟩
  • Answer: G — Scalar multiply first, then subtract components!

3. Dot Product and Angles

The dot product (or scalar product) of two vectors produces a scalar (number) rather than another vector. Written as u · v, it equals the sum of products of corresponding components. The dot product has important geometric interpretations: it equals |u||v|cos(θ) where θ is the angle between vectors. This allows us to find angles between vectors, test for perpendicularity (dot product = 0), and find projections.

Calculating the Dot Product

Formula: ⟨a₁, b₁⟩ · ⟨a₂, b₂⟩ = a₁a₂ + b₁b₂

Practice Problem: ⟨3, 4⟩ · ⟨2, 5⟩ = (3)(2) + (4)(5) = 6 + 20 = 26 Example 2: ⟨-1, 6⟩ · ⟨4, 2⟩ = (-1)(4) + (6)(2) = -4 + 12 = 8 Example 3: ⟨5, -3⟩ · ⟨2, -7⟩ = (5)(2) + (-3)(-7) = 10 + 21 = 31 Note: The dot product is a scalar, not a vector!

Properties of the Dot Product

Key properties:

1. Commutative: u · v = v · u
2. Distributive: u · (v + w) = u · v + u · w
3. Scalar multiplication: (ku) · v = k(u · v) = u · (kv)
4. With itself: v · v = |v|²
5. Zero vector: 0 · v = 0
6. Unit vectors: i · i = 1, j · j = 1, i · j = 0

Example using property 4:
v = ⟨3, 4⟩
v · v = (3)(3) + (4)(4) = 9 + 16 = 25 = |v|²
So |v| = √25 = 5 ✓

Geometric Interpretation and Angles

Angle formula: u · v = |u||v|cos(θ)
Therefore: cos(θ) = (u · v) / (|u||v|)

Example: Find angle between u = ⟨3, 4⟩ and v = ⟨0, 5⟩

Step 1: Calculate dot product
u · v = (3)(0) + (4)(5) = 0 + 20 = 20

Step 2: Find magnitudes
|u| = √(9 + 16) = 5
|v| = √(0 + 25) = 5

Step 3: Apply formula
cos(θ) = 20 / (5 · 5) = 20/25 = 4/5 = 0.8
θ = cos⁻¹(0.8) ≈ 36.87°

Perpendicular (Orthogonal) Vectors

Perpendicular vectors have dot product = 0
(Because cos(90°) = 0)

Test: u ⊥ v if and only if u · v = 0

Example 1: Are ⟨2, 3⟩ and ⟨-6, 4⟩ perpendicular?
Dot product: (2)(-6) + (3)(4) = -12 + 12 = 0 ✓
Yes, they are perpendicular!

Example 2: Are ⟨1, 2⟩ and ⟨3, -1⟩ perpendicular?
Dot product: (1)(3) + (2)(-1) = 3 - 2 = 1 ≠ 0
No, they are not perpendicular

Finding perpendicular vector:
If v = ⟨a, b⟩, then ⟨-b, a⟩ and ⟨b, -a⟩ are perpendicular to v
Example: ⟨3, 4⟩ ⊥ ⟨-4, 3⟩ (verify: 3(-4) + 4(3) = -12 + 12 = 0 ✓)

ACT Example 3: Dot Product

Vectors u = ⟨6, 8⟩ and v = ⟨-4, 3⟩. Are these vectors perpendicular?

  • A) Yes, because their dot product is 0
  • B) Yes, because their dot product is 1
  • C) No, because their dot product is 0
  • D) No, because their dot product is not 0
  • E) Cannot be determined
  • Solution:
  • Calculate dot product:
  • u · v = (6)(-4) + (8)(3) = -24 + 24 = 0
  • Since dot product = 0, vectors are perpendicular
  • Answer: A — Dot product = 0 means perpendicular!

4. Applications of Vectors

Vectors have numerous practical applications in physics, engineering, and computer graphics. Force vectors combine to produce net force, velocity vectors describe motion with both speed and direction, and displacement vectors represent changes in position. Understanding how to resolve vectors into components, combine multiple vectors, and use vectors to model real-world situations demonstrates deep mathematical understanding and prepares you for STEM fields.

Resolving Vectors into Components

Given magnitude |v| and direction angle θ:
Horizontal component: vₓ = |v| cos(θ)
Vertical component: vᵧ = |v| sin(θ)
Vector: v = ⟨|v| cos(θ), |v| sin(θ)⟩

Example: A force of 50 N acts at 30° above horizontal. Find components.

Horizontal component:
Fₓ = 50 cos(30°) = 50 · (√3/2) ≈ 43.3 N

Vertical component:
Fᵧ = 50 sin(30°) = 50 · (1/2) = 25 N

Vector form: F ≈ ⟨43.3, 25⟩ N

Combining Multiple Vectors

Problem: Three forces act on an object:
F₁ = 10 N east
F₂ = 15 N north
F₃ = 5 N west
Find the net (resultant) force.

Solution using components:
Use east as positive x, north as positive y

F₁ = ⟨10, 0⟩
F₂ = ⟨0, 15⟩
F₃ = ⟨-5, 0⟩

Net force:
F_net = F₁ + F₂ + F₃
= ⟨10, 0⟩ + ⟨0, 15⟩ + ⟨-5, 0⟩
= ⟨5, 15⟩ N

Magnitude: |F_net| = √(5² + 15²) = √(25 + 225) = √250 ≈ 15.8 N
Direction: tan(θ) = 15/5 = 3, so θ = tan⁻¹(3) ≈ 71.6° north of east

Navigation and Displacement

Problem: A ship sails 30 km east, then 40 km north. What is the ship's displacement from its starting point?

First leg: d₁ = ⟨30, 0⟩ km
Second leg: d₂ = ⟨0, 40⟩ km

Total displacement:
d = d₁ + d₂ = ⟨30, 0⟩ + ⟨0, 40⟩ = ⟨30, 40⟩ km

Distance from start:
|d| = √(30² + 40²) = √(900 + 1600) = √2500 = 50 km

Direction:
tan(θ) = 40/30 = 4/3
θ = tan⁻¹(4/3) ≈ 53.1° north of east

Note: This is a 3-4-5 Pythagorean triple scaled by 10!

Velocity and Relative Motion

Problem: A plane flies at 200 mph heading due north. A wind blows from the west at 50 mph. What is the plane's actual velocity?

Plane velocity (in still air): v_plane = ⟨0, 200⟩ mph
Wind velocity: v_wind = ⟨50, 0⟩ mph (from west means toward east)

Actual velocity:
v_actual = v_plane + v_wind = ⟨0, 200⟩ + ⟨50, 0⟩ = ⟨50, 200⟩ mph

Ground speed:
|v_actual| = √(50² + 200²) = √(2500 + 40000) = √42500 ≈ 206.2 mph

Actual heading:
tan(θ) = 200/50 = 4
θ = tan⁻¹(4) ≈ 76.0° from east (or 14.0° east of north)

ACT Example 4: Vector Applications

A person walks 12 meters north, then 5 meters east. How far is the person from the starting point?

  • F) 7 meters
  • G) 13 meters
  • H) 17 meters
  • J) 119 meters
  • K) 144 meters
  • Solution:
  • Displacement vector: d = ⟨5, 12⟩ meters
  • Distance from start:
  • |d| = √(5² + 12²) = √(25 + 144) = √169 = 13 meters
  • Answer: G — Use Pythagorean theorem (5-12-13 triple)!

.

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Vectors have both magnitude and direction; scalars have only magnitude
  • ✓Component form: v = ⟨a, b⟩ or ai + bj where a is horizontal, b is vertical
  • ✓Magnitude: |⟨a, b⟩| = √(a² + b²) using Pythagorean theorem
  • ✓Add/subtract vectors component-wise: ⟨a₁, b₁⟩ ± ⟨a₂, b₂⟩ = ⟨a₁ ± a₂, b₁ ± b₂⟩
  • ✓Scalar multiplication: k⟨a, b⟩ = ⟨ka, kb⟩ scales magnitude by |k|
  • ✓Unit vector in direction of v: u = v/|v| has magnitude 1
  • ✓Dot product: ⟨a₁, b₁⟩ · ⟨a₂, b₂⟩ = a₁a₂ + b₁b₂ (produces a scalar)
  • ✓Perpendicular vectors: u ⊥ v if and only if u · v = 0
  • ✓Angle between vectors: cos(θ) = (u · v) / (|u||v|)
  • ✓Applications: combine forces/velocities by adding vectors; find resultant magnitude using Pythagorean theorem

lessons.title: Topic 7.5 - Word Problems
lessons.content:
Mastering word problems is essential for ACT Math success.
