lessons.title: Topic 3.2 - Cannot Be Determined
lessons.content:
• recognize when data is insufficient: to answer a question
  • identify what information is missing: from figures or passages
  • distinguish between answerable and unanswerable questions: based on given data, and
  • avoid making assumptions beyond what the data supports:
    • . Unlike standard questions where you extract specific values or identify trends from available data
    • these questions specifically assess whether you understand the limitations of the provided information and can recognize when extrapolation
    • assumptions
    • or additional data would be required
  • This lesson teaches you how to identify when "cannot be determined" is the correct answer, explains common scenarios where data is insufficient despite appearing complete, provides strategies for distinguishing between difficult-to-find information and genuinely missing information, and shows you how to avoid incorrectly selecting "cannot be determined" when the answer is actually present in the figures or passage.

1. Understanding When Information Is Genuinely Missing

Cannot-be-determined scenarios occur when the data provided is legitimately insufficient to answer the question, regardless of how carefully you analyze the figures or passage.

Scenario 1: Data Outside the Measured Range

  • Example:
    • A graph shows data from 0-100°C. Question asks: "What would the pressure be at 150°C?" Since 150°C is beyond the measured range and you don't know if the trend continues linearly
    • exponentially
    • or changes direction entirely
    • you cannot determine the answer from the given data
  • Why it's undeterminable: Extrapolation beyond measured data requires assumptions about how trends continue, which may or may not be valid

Without additional information confirming the trend continues, you cannot definitively answer. (3) Key distinction: Questions asking for reasonable estimates within a small extension of the range may be answerable ("Based on the trend, which is most likely at 110°C?"), but questions far outside the range or asking for exact values beyond the data cannot be determined. (4) Red flags: Questions mentioning values clearly outside all measured ranges, asking about conditions not tested, or requesting information about experimental setups not described.

Scenario 2: Variables Not Measured or Reported

  • Example: Passage describes measuring temperature and pressure but doesn't mention volume. Question asks: "What was the volume at t=30 min?" Since volume was never measured or reported, you cannot determine it.
  • Subtle variations: Sometimes a variable is mentioned in the passage but data for it isn't provided in figures

The passage might say "Students also noted the color" but no figure shows color data.

  • Indirect measurement questions: "What was the pH?" when only temperature and pressure are graphed, and no formula or relationship is provided to calculate pH from those variables.
  • How to verify: Check all figures and tables

If the variable mentioned in the question doesn't appear in any axis label, column header, or data row, it likely cannot be determined.

Scenario 3: Ambiguous or Unlabeled Data

When data exists but isn't clearly identified, determination may be impossible: (1) Example: A graph shows three unlabeled lines. Passage mentions Trial 1, 2, and 3 but doesn't specify which line corresponds to which trial, and there's no way to deduce it from the data patterns.

  • Missing legends or keys: Symbols, colors, or abbreviations used in figures without explanation and not defined in the passage.
  • Check carefully:
    • Before concluding data is ambiguous
    • thoroughly check figure captions
    • passage text
    • and pattern clues. Sometimes the identification is subtle but present

Only if truly no identification exists is it undeterminable. (4) ACT typically provides identifiable data, so this scenario is rarer than the others, but it's worth recognizing.

Scenario 4: Questions Requiring Unknown Intermediate Steps

  • Example:
    • Question asks "What was the density?" but the data only provides mass
    • not volume (and density = mass/volume). Without volume
    • you cannot calculate density
  • Missing formulas or constants: "Calculate the energy" when energy formula isn't provided and data doesn't directly show energy values.
  • Missing conversion factors:
    • Data in one unit
    • question asks for answer in different unit
    • but conversion factor isn't provided
  • Important note: Basic scientific formulas and common conversions are sometimes assumed knowledge (like °F to °C conversion), but obscure or complex calculations requiring specific constants won't be required without data

If the question seems to require advanced calculations with missing components, "cannot be determined" is likely correct.

  • Scenario 1 (Outside Range):
    • : Data provided: Temperature measured from 0-100°C, pressure values from 1-5 atm Question: "What would pressure be at 200°C?" Analysis: 200°C is far outside the measured range (0-100°C) Conclusion: Cannot be determined
    • would require assumptions about trend continuation
  • Scenario 2 (Variable Not Measured):
    • : Data provided: Figure 1 shows temperature vs time, Figure 2 shows pressure vs time Question: "What was the volume at t=30 min?" Analysis: Volume never measured or reported anywhere in passage or figures Conclusion: Cannot be determined
    • volume data doesn't exist
  • Scenario 3 (Ambiguous Data):
    • : Data provided: Three unlabeled lines on a graph Passage: Mentions Trial A, B, C but doesn't specify which line is which Question: "What was the value for Trial B at t=20?" Analysis: Can't identify which line corresponds to Trial B Conclusion: Cannot be determined
    • line identification missing
  • Scenario 4 (Missing Intermediate Data):: Data provided: Mass values for different samples Question: "What was the density of Sample 1?" Analysis: Density = mass/volume
  • only mass is provided, not volume Conclusion:
    • Cannot be determined
    • missing volume data needed for calculation

2. Distinguishing "Cannot Be Determined" from "Difficult to Find"

A critical skill is distinguishing between information that's genuinely absent versus information that's present but requires careful search or analysis to find.

Before Selecting "Cannot Be Determined," Exhaust All Sources

  • All figures and tables:
    • Check every graph
    • and diagram. The information might be in a figure you didn't initially think relevant
  • Figure captions and notes: Read small print, footnotes, and captions carefully

Critical information is sometimes tucked in these locations. (3) Passage text: Scan the passage for keywords from the question. Information might be stated in text rather than shown in figures. (4) Answer choices: Sometimes answer choices provide clues.

If three choices give specific values and one says "cannot be determined," check whether those specific values actually appear in the data. (5) Only after thoroughly checking all sources should you conclude the information is missing. Many students prematurely select "cannot be determined" when the information is actually present but requires more careful searching.

Information That Requires Integration or Calculation

  • Multi-figure integration:
    • If Figure 1 shows temperature at different times and Figure 2 shows pressure at different times, you CAN determine temperature and pressure at the same time by cross-referencing
    • it's not "cannot be determined" just because you need both figures
  • Simple calculations:
    • If data provides initial and final values and the question asks for the change, you CAN calculate change by subtraction
    • this is determinable
  • Using provided formulas:
    • If the passage provides a formula and all variables in that formula have values in the data, you CAN calculate the result
    • it's determinable
  • Don't confuse "complex" with "undeterminable." If the information exists (even if finding it requires multiple steps), it CAN be determined. Only select "cannot be determined" when data is genuinely absent, not when the solution is multi-step.

Information That Can Be Inferred or Deduced

  • Pattern deduction:
    • If Figure 1 shows that Trial 1 always has the highest values across all measurements
    • and the question asks which trial had the highest value at a specific point
    • you can infer Trial 1 even if that exact point isn't explicitly labeled
  • Logical elimination:
    • If the passage says three trials were run (A
    • C) and two are clearly identified in a figure
    • the unlabeled third line must be the remaining trial
  • Interpolation:
    • Values between measured points can be reasonably estimated by interpolation
    • this is determinable, not "cannot be determined."
  • Boundary: Reasonable inference is acceptable. Wild speculation is not

If inference requires multiple assumptions or logical leaps, it may genuinely be undeterminable. But straightforward deductions from available data don't qualify as "cannot be determined."

Common Student Errors Leading to False "Cannot Be Determined"

Students sometimes incorrectly select "cannot be determined" when: (1) They didn't search carefully enough. The information is present but in a different figure or in passage text, not where they expected. (2) They gave up too quickly.

  • They confused unfamiliarity with impossibility. The question asks about a concept or variable they don't understand, so they think it can't be answered, when actually the data is there.
  • They misread what's being asked

They looked for the wrong variable or checked the wrong conditions. To avoid these errors: Always do a thorough, systematic search before selecting "cannot be determined." Treat it as a last resort, not a first response to difficulty.

If you're considering "cannot be determined," ask yourself: "Have I checked every figure? Every table? The passage text? Figure captions?" Only if the answer is yes and you still haven't found the information should you select it.

  • Example:
    • Distinguishing Difficult from Impossible Difficult but CAN Be Determined: Question: "What was the temperature when pressure was 2.5 atm?" Figure 1: Shows temperature vs time Figure 2: Shows pressure vs time Process: Find t when P=2.5 atm in Figure 2 (say t=25 min), then find temperature at t=25 in Figure 1 Conclusion: CAN be determined
    • requires two-figure integration but data exists Appears Difficult but CAN Be Determined: Question: "What was the increase in volume from t=10 to t=30?" Table shows: V=20 mL at t=10
  • V=45 mL at t=30 Process:
    • Calculate 45-20=25 mL Conclusion: CAN be determined
    • simple calculation from available data Actually CANNOT Be Determined: Question: "What was the pH at t=30 min?" Figures show: Temperature vs time, pressure vs time Passage: Never mentions pH or provides any relationship between pH and the measured variables Process: Check all figures
    • pH not shown
  • Check passage—pH not mentioned. No way to derive it. Conclusion:
    • CANNOT be determined
    • pH data genuinely absent The key difference: In the first two, all necessary data exists and can be found or calculated
  • In the third, the data simply doesn't exist anywhere..

3. Strategic Approaches for "Cannot Be Determined" Questions

Systematic strategies help you accurately identify when "cannot be determined" is correct versus when the answer is present but challenging to find.

The Systematic Elimination Checklist

  • Identify exactly what the question asks. What variable? At what condition?
  • Check Figure 1: Does it show this variable or provide data to calculate it?
  • Check Figure 2, Figure 3, etc.: Systematically check each figure.
  • Check any tables: Look for the variable in column or row headers.
  • Read passage text: Scan for keywords related to the question

The information might be stated in words rather than shown in data. (6) Check if it can be calculated: Do you have all components needed for a calculation or formula? (7) Check if it can be inferred: Can you deduce it from patterns or elimination? (8) Only if all checks fail, select "cannot be determined." This systematic approach ensures you don't miss information that's present but not where you expected.

Recognizing "Cannot Be Determined" Answer Choice Patterns

  • If three choices are specific values (20, 40, 60) and one is "cannot be determined," check whether those specific values actually appear in or can be derived from the data. If they can, "cannot be determined" is likely wrong.
  • If "cannot be determined" is an option, the question is testing whether you recognize data limitations

Be extra careful to verify whether information is truly missing.

  • most questions are designed to be answerable from the data. Don't assume it's correct just because a question seems hard. (4) When it IS correct, it's usually clearly correct
  • the data is obviously missing, not subtly absent

If you're debating whether information is available, it probably is available and you just haven't found it yet. Use the presence of "cannot be determined" as a signal to search extra carefully, not as an easy way out of a difficult question.

Time Management Strategy for These Questions

  • Spend 30-45 seconds searching before considering "cannot be determined." Check all major sources systematically.
  • If after thorough search you haven't found the information, assess whether the data genuinely seems missing. If the variable isn't in any figure, isn't mentioned in the passage, and doesn't appear derivable, it probably is undeterminable.
  • Don't waste 2+ minutes desperately searching for information that may not exist

If systematic searching for 45 seconds reveals no information and the data genuinely appears absent, select "cannot be determined" and move on. (4) Mark for review if unsure. If you're truly uncertain whether information is missing or just hard to find, mark the question and return to it if time permits

Fresh eyes on the second pass might spot information you missed initially. Balance between thoroughness (don't give up too easily) and efficiency (don't waste excessive time on a question designed to test recognition of missing data).

Practicing Recognition of Data Limitations

  • When reviewing practice passages, after answering normal questions, ask yourself: "What questions COULDN'T be answered from this data? What variables weren't measured? What ranges weren't covered?"
  • Develop awareness of data boundaries: What's the minimum and maximum x-value? What variables are shown versus not shown? What relationships are demonstrated versus assumed?
  • Compare passages that provide complete data versus those with gaps. Notice the difference between comprehensive experiments and limited studies.
  • Build confidence in distinguishing "I can't find it" from "it's not there." This skill improves with practice and reduces anxiety when encountering these questions on test day

The goal is developing intuition for what data supports and what it doesn't.

  • Question:: "What was the conductivity of Solution A at 50°C?"
  • Systematic Checklist:
    • : ✓ Figure 1: Shows temperature vs volume for Solutions A
    • C → No conductivity ✓ Figure 2: Shows pH vs time for Solutions A
    • C → No conductivity ✓ Table 1: Shows initial concentrations of A
  • B, C → No conductivity ✓ Passage text: Scan for "conductivity" → Not mentioned anywhere ✓ Can it be calculated? No formula relating conductivity to measured variables ✓ Can it be inferred? No patterns or relationships suggest conductivity values
  • Conclusion:: After systematic check, conductivity was never measured or discussed
  • Answer:: Cannot be determined
  • Time spent:: 40 seconds (efficient, systematic search)
  • Contrast with:: Question: "What was the volume of Solution A at 50°C?" Systematic check: Figure 1 shows temperature vs volume → Find 50°C on x-axis, trace to Solution A line
  • read volume from y-axis → CAN be determined The difference: Volume data exists and is findable. Conductivity data genuinely doesn't exist anywhere. Systematic checking reveals which scenario applies.

4. Common Traps and Advanced Considerations

Understanding subtle traps and advanced scenarios helps you navigate these questions with greater accuracy and confidence.

Trap #1: Confusing "Not Directly Shown" with "Cannot Be Determined"

  • Example trap:
    • "What was the ratio of Variable A to Variable B at t=20?" Figure 1 shows Variable A
    • Figure 2 shows Variable B. Students think "I don't see a ratio anywhere" and select "cannot be determined." But you CAN determine it by reading A from Figure 1
    • reading B from Figure 2
    • and calculating A/B
  • Avoiding the trap: If all components needed for an answer are available (even if in different places or requiring calculation), it CAN be determined

Only select "cannot be determined" if one or more necessary components are truly absent. (3) Mental shift: Think of data as building blocks. If you have all the blocks needed to construct the answer (even if assembly required), it's determinable.

Only if a block is missing is it undeterminable. Don't confuse "requires work" with "impossible."

Trap #2: Assuming Extrapolation Equals "Cannot Be Determined"

  • Small, reasonable extrapolation: If data goes from 0-100 and the question asks about 110 "based on the trend," you can reasonably extend the line slightly and estimate. This is determinable as an approximation.
  • Large or extreme extrapolation: If data goes from 0-100 and the question asks about 500, this is too far beyond the measured range for reasonable prediction

This likely cannot be determined. (3) Question wording matters: "Based on the trend, which value would most likely..." suggests approximation is acceptable (determinable). "What exactly would the value be..." for far extrapolation suggests impossibility (cannot be determined). (4) Use judgment: Small extensions of clear trends with "most likely" language are usually determinable. Large extensions or questions asking for precision beyond the data range are usually undeterminable

Context and question wording guide which applies.

Advanced Scenario: Partial Information That's Insufficient

  • Example:
    • Question asks "What was the final temperature of the mixture?" Passage says two liquids were mixed
    • one at 20°C and one at 40°C
    • but doesn't provide volumes
    • or heat capacities. You know initial temperatures but can't calculate final temperature without additional data
  • Another example:
    • Data shows several data points
    • but the question asks which mathematical model (linear
    • exponential
    • logarithmic) best fits
    • yet not enough data points are provided to distinguish between models statistically
  • Recognition: You have some relevant information but not all necessary information

It's tempting to guess or make assumptions, but if key data is missing, it cannot be determined. (4) Test skill: These scenarios test whether you recognize what information is sufficient versus insufficient for answering a question.

When to Trust Your Instinct vs. Keep Searching

  • Trust your instinct if:
    • After systematic searching
    • the variable isn't mentioned anywhere
    • isn't in any figure axis or table header
    • and you've checked all sources thoroughly. If it's obviously absent
    • trust that assessment
  • Keep searching if: The question seems very straightforward for a passage that otherwise provides detailed data
  • Context clues:
    • If the passage is clearly incomplete or limited (described as a "preliminary study" or "partial data")
    • missing information is more likely. If the passage describes a thorough experiment
    • comprehensive data is more likely
  • Balance: Don't be so determined to find information that you waste time searching for data that truly isn't there

But also don't give up so easily that you select "cannot be determined" when the information is present but requires effort to find. Experience and practice develop this balanced judgment.

  • Trap 1 - "Not Directly Shown" ≠ "Cannot Be Determined":: Question: "What was the change in temperature from t=10 to t=30?" Student thinking: "I don't see 'change' anywhere in the figures" Wrong: Selects "cannot be determined" Correct approach: Figure shows T=45°C at t=10, T=70°C at t=30 Calculate: 70-45=25°C change Answer: 25°C (CAN be determined through simple calculation)
  • Trap 2 - Extrapolation:
    • : Data range: 0-100°C Question 1: "Based on the trend, which value would most likely occur at 110°C: 15, 20, 25, 30?" Answer: Determinable
    • small extrapolation with "most likely" language and answer choices to guide Question 2: "What would the exact value be at 500°C?" Answer: Cannot be determined
    • far outside range, asking for exact value
  • Partial Information:
    • : Question: "What was the density of the mixture?" Data provided: Mass of component A, mass of component B Data missing: Volumes (density = mass/volume) Analysis: Have masses but not volumes needed for density calculation Answer: Cannot be determined
    • insufficient data for required calculation These examples show the nuances between genuinely missing data and data that requires some work to find or derive

.

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Select "cannot be determined" only when data is genuinely missing, not when it's difficult to find
  • ✓Common undeterminable scenarios: values outside measured range, variables never measured, missing calculation components
  • ✓Before selecting "cannot be determined," systematically check all figures, tables, captions, and passage text
  • ✓Information requiring multi-figure integration or simple calculations CAN be determined if all components exist
  • ✓Values that can be reasonably inferred, deduced, or interpolated CAN be determined
  • ✓Don't confuse "complex" or "multi-step" with "undeterminable"—difficulty doesn't equal impossibility
  • ✓ACT rarely uses "cannot be determined" as correct answers—treat it as a last resort after thorough searching
  • ✓Small, reasonable extrapolations with "most likely" language are usually determinable; large extrapolations often aren't
  • ✓Spend 30-45 seconds on systematic searching before concluding data is missing
  • ✓When "cannot be determined" IS correct, it's usually obviously correct—the data absence is clear, not subtle

lessons.title: Topic 2.5 - Words in Context Questions
lessons.content:
• Words in context questions on the ACT Reading test require you to determine the precise meaning of a word or phrase as used in a specific passage location
  • distinguishing between primary dictionary definitions and the particular contextual meaning the author intends.
  • These questions don't test vocabulary knowledge in isolation—they test your ability to use surrounding context clues, understand how words function differently in various situations
  • recognize that common words often carry specialized or figurative meanings beyond their typical definitions.
  • Rather than simply substituting dictionary definitions, successful students analyze the word's specific function in context, consider the passage's overall tone and subject matter
  • evaluate which answer choice best preserves the author's intended meaning while fitting grammatically and logically into the surrounding sentence structure.
  • This lesson teaches systematic approaches to contextual analysis, strategies for eliminating answers that represent common but incorrect meanings, techniques for handling multiple-meaning words
  • methods for verifying your selected definition by substituting it back into the passage to ensure seamless integration with the author's message..

1. Understanding Words in Context Question Structure

Words in context questions follow predictable formats and test specific skills. Understanding their structure helps you approach them systematically and avoid common traps.

Question Format and Identification

  • Words in context questions typically appear in these formats: "As it is used in line X, [word] most nearly means...", "In the context of the passage
  • [phrase] suggests...", or "The word [word] (line X) refers to..." These questions direct you to a specific line number and ask you to determine the meaning of a highlighted word or phrase in that particular context.
  • The key phrase "most nearly means" is important—it signals that you're looking for the closest synonym in this specific usage, not necessarily the word's most common meaning.
  • Most ACT Reading passages include 1-3 words in context questions, and they typically focus on: Common words with multiple meanings (like "address," "current," "interest
  • " "present"), Words used figuratively rather than literally ("the argument collapsed," "the theory illuminates"), Academic or formal vocabulary used in specific disciplinary contexts, and Words whose precise shade of meaning affects interpretation.
  • Identifying these questions is straightforward—look for line references and direct requests about word meaning..

What These Questions Actually Test

  • Words in context questions don't primarily test whether you know vocabulary words—they test whether you can determine meaning from context.
  • In fact, the ACT often selects familiar words precisely because students will default to common meanings without considering context
  • For example, if a passage says "The researcher's novel approach challenged conventional methods," the question might ask what "novel" means.
  • Many students will immediately think of "novel" as a book, but in this context it means "new" or "innovative." The test rewards students who: Read surrounding sentences to understand how the word functions in this specific situation
  • Consider the passage's subject and tone to determine which meaning makes sense, Evaluate grammatical function (Is it used as a noun, verb, adjective? What does it modify or describe?), and Test each answer choice by substituting it into the sentence to see which preserves the author's intended meaning.
  • These questions ultimately test reading comprehension—your ability to understand what you're reading—not isolated vocabulary knowledge..

Common Trap Patterns

ACT test writers deliberately include trap answers that exploit predictable student errors. The most common traps include:

  • The primary definition trap
  • offering the word's most common meaning even though the passage uses a less common meaning (e.g., asking about "interest" in "The historian's interest in the period extended beyond military conflicts" and offering "money paid on loans" as a trap). The associated word trap
  • including words thematically related to the passage topic but not actually synonymous with the target word (e.g.
  • if the passage discusses music and the word is "tempo," offering "melody" because it's music-related). The similar sound trap
  • occasionally including words that sound similar but have different meanings (though this is less common on the ACT). The extreme synonym trap
  • offering a word that's related but too strong/weak for the context (e.g., the passage says "criticized" and an answer offers "condemned," which is too extreme)
  • Being aware of these patterns helps you approach answer choices skeptically rather than selecting the first familiar option

Why Context Always Matters

  • The fundamental principle of words in context questions is that meaning is determined by usage, not by dictionary definitions alone.
  • Consider the word "run": it has dozens of meanings (to jog, to operate machinery, to compete in an election
  • to flow like water, to extend in space, etc.), and only context tells you which meaning applies.
  • If a passage says "The candidate decided to run in the upcoming election," "run" means "compete for office," not "jog." Similarly, abstract words carry different connotations in different contexts: "aggressive" can be negative (aggressive behavior that frightens others) or positive (aggressive pursuit of goals), depending on context.
  • Academic passages often use common words in specialized ways: in economics, "demand" and "supply" have specific technical meanings
  • in literary analysis, "voice" doesn't refer to speaking but to the distinctive style of a writer or character.
  • Never assume you know a word's meaning without reading the surrounding context carefully. The passage context—the subject matter
  • the author's tone, the grammatical structure, the surrounding vocabulary—provides the information you need to determine the precise meaning intended..
  • Example: Words in Context Question Structure: Passage excerpt: "The economic depression that followed the market crash was severe
  • lasting throughout the decade and affecting millions of families who lost their savings and employment." Question: "As it is used in line 15, 'depression' most nearly means:"
  • Trap Answer A:: "A psychological condition characterized by persistent sadness" (This is the primary/common meaning many students think of first, but context indicates economic, not psychological, discussion)
  • Trap Answer B:: "A disappointing situation" (Too weak/casual for the serious economic collapse described)
  • Associated Word Trap C:: "A recession" (Related economic term, but technically less severe than a depression—doesn't match "severe" and "lasting throughout the decade")
  • Correct Answer D:: "A prolonged period of economic decline" (Captures both the economic context and the severity/duration emphasized in the passage)

2. The Systematic Context Analysis Method

Rather than immediately looking at answer choices when you encounter a words in context question, use a systematic method to determine the word's meaning from context first, then evaluate which answer best matches your understanding.

Step 1: Read the Complete Sentence and Surrounding Context

  • When you see a words in context question, immediately return to the passage and read the complete sentence containing the target word, plus the sentences before and after it for additional context.
  • Don't try to answer based on the question alone—you need the full context
  • As you read, focus on: What topic is being discussed—this helps you understand the domain of meaning (scientific, economic, emotional, etc.).
  • What words surround the target—nearby adjectives, adverbs, and phrases often clarify meaning. What the author is arguing or describing—understanding the author's point helps you determine which meaning fits.
  • The tone and formality level—is this technical/academic language or casual/conversational? For example, if the question asks about "developed" in line 23, don't just look at line 23—read lines 22-24 to see the full context: "Over several decades
  • scientists developed a comprehensive theory that explained previously mysterious phenomena." This context tells you "developed" means "created" or "formulated," not "grew" or "matured.".

Step 2: Determine the Word's Grammatical Function

  • Identify how the word functions grammatically in the sentence—is it a noun, verb, adjective
  • or adverb? What does it modify or describe? This grammatical analysis eliminates impossible answers and narrows your options.
  • For example, if the passage says "The cold reception surprised the speaker," and the question asks about "cold," determine that it's an adjective modifying "reception." This tells you that answer choices should be adjectives that could describe a reception, not literal temperature references.
  • Similarly, if the word is a verb, make sure your chosen answer preserves the action being described.
  • If the passage says "The evidence supports the hypothesis," and you're asked about "supports," you need a verb that means "provides backing for" or "confirms," not a noun like "foundation" or "base" (which are related but grammatically incompatible).
  • Grammatical function also helps with words that can serve multiple roles: "present" can be a noun (a gift), verb (to show), or adjective (current).
  • Context and grammatical function together determine which role applies. Ask yourself: "What is this word doing in this sentence? What function does it serve?".

Step 3: Predict the Meaning Before Looking at Choices

  • Before examining answer choices, predict your own answer based on context. Try to think of a synonym or brief definition that captures the word's meaning in this specific usage.
  • This prediction serves as an anchor when you evaluate answer choices, protecting you from attractive but incorrect options
  • Your prediction doesn't need to be perfect or sophisticated—even a simple synonym works.
  • For example, if the passage says "The theory illuminates the relationship between diet and health," and you're asked about "illuminates
  • " you might predict "clarifies" or "explains" or "makes clear." Then when you look at answer choices, you can evaluate which best matches your prediction.
  • The prediction technique is particularly valuable because it forces you to engage with the context before being influenced by answer choices.
  • Without a prediction, you might see an answer like "brightens" (a common meaning of "illuminates") and think "yes, that's what illuminate means!" without considering whether it makes sense in context.
  • With your prediction of "clarifies," you'll recognize that "brightens" doesn't match, while "explains" does. If you can't formulate any prediction, reread the context more carefully until the meaning becomes clearer..

Step 4: Test Each Answer Through Substitution

  • After predicting the meaning, evaluate each answer choice by substituting it into the original sentence and checking whether the sentence still makes sense and preserves the author's intended meaning.
  • This substitution test is the most reliable verification method for words in context questions. Literally read the sentence aloud (in your head) with each answer choice replacing the original word, then ask: "Does this maintain the sentence's meaning? Does it fit grammatically? Does it preserve the author's tone and intent?" For example
  • if the sentence is "The scientist's novel approach challenged conventional methods," test each answer: "The scientist's new approach..." (works—maintains meaning), "The scientist's fictional approach..." (doesn't work—makes no sense in context), "The scientist's book approach..." (doesn't work—grammatically incorrect and meaningless).
  • The substitution test catches answers that are definitionally related to the target word but don't work in context
  • It also confirms that your selected answer seamlessly integrates into the passage without creating awkwardness or changing the meaning.
  • The correct answer should fit so naturally that a reader wouldn't notice the substitution..
  • Example: Systematic Context Analysis in Action Passage excerpt: "The architect's bold design departed from traditional styles, incorporating unexpected materials and asymmetrical forms that challenged viewers' expectations." Question: "As it is used in line 42, 'departed' most nearly means:" Step 1 - Full Context: The sentence discusses how the design related to traditional styles by using unexpected elements.
  • The surrounding context emphasizes innovation and difference from convention. Step 2 - Grammatical Function: "Departed" is a verb describing what the design did in relation to traditional styles.
  • Past tense action verb. Step 3 - Prediction: Based on context, "departed" means something like "differed from" or "broke away from" or "moved away from"—it indicates the design was different from tradition.
  • Step 4 - Test Answers: A. "left" - "The design left traditional styles" (awkward, doesn't quite work) B. "diverged from"
  • "The design diverged from traditional styles" (perfect—smooth and meaningful) C.
  • "exited" - "The design exited traditional styles" (doesn't make sense) D. "traveled from"
  • "The design traveled from traditional styles" (illogical) Answer: B (best matches prediction and works perfectly through substitution).

3. Handling Difficult Words and Multiple Meanings

Some words in context questions are particularly challenging because they involve unfamiliar vocabulary, words with many possible meanings, or subtle distinctions between similar concepts. Specialized strategies help you navigate these difficult cases.

When You Don't Know the Target Word

  • Occasionally you'll encounter a words in context question about a word you genuinely don't know. Don't panic—the context should provide enough information to determine meaning even without knowing the word.
  • Use these strategies: Analyze the sentence's logic—what kind of word would make sense here? If the sentence says "The proposal was so [word] that everyone immediately agreed," the logic suggests the word means something positive like "convincing" or "appealing." Look for contrast or parallel clues—words like "but," "however," "unlike" signal contrast (the unknown word means the opposite of what's compared), while words like "similarly," "also," "likewise" signal parallel meaning.
  • Check for definition clues—authors often define or explain unusual words in the surrounding text. Use answer choice elimination—test each answer by substituting it
  • eliminate those that create nonsense, then choose the best remaining option.
  • Remember: words in context questions are designed to be answerable from context alone, so all necessary information is present in the passage..

Distinguishing Between Close Synonyms

  • connotation, intensity, and precise meaning differences: . For example, "criticized," "condemned," "questioned," and "analyzed" all involve evaluating something, but they differ significantly: "criticized" implies negative judgment, "condemned" is even stronger, "questioned" is neutral inquiry
  • "analyzed" is objective examination. If the passage says "The reviewer criticized the film's plot inconsistencies," the right answer captures moderate negative evaluation ("criticized"), not extreme denunciation ("condemned") or neutral examination ("analyzed"). To distinguish close synonyms:
  • Assess intensity: —is the passage describing something mild, moderate, or extreme?
  • Consider connotation: —is it positive, negative, or neutral?
  • Check specificity: —does one answer capture more specific nuance than others?
  • Use substitution carefully: —which answer preserves the exact tone and strength of the original? The correct answer matches not just the basic meaning but also the precise degree and emotional coloring.

Recognizing Figurative and Extended Meanings

Many words in context questions involve figurative or metaphorical uses of common words. When a word is used figuratively, its literal meaning doesn't apply—you must understand the metaphorical meaning it conveys.

Common patterns include:.

  • Physical actions applied to abstract concepts
  • "the argument collapsed" (arguments can't physically collapse, so this means "failed" or "fell apart"), "the theory illuminates" (theories don't produce light
  • so this means "clarifies" or "explains"), "the evidence supports" (evidence doesn't physically hold things up, so this means "confirms" or "validates"). Concrete terms used abstractly
  • "cold reception" (not literally about temperature, but about unfriendliness), "sharp criticism" (not literally pointed, but harsh/severe), "heavy burden" (not necessarily physical weight, but emotional/responsibility weight). Extended meanings in academic contexts
  • "articulate" meaning "express clearly" not just "pronounce clearly," "nuanced" meaning "subtle and complex" not just "shaded." The key is recognizing when literal meaning doesn't fit the context, then determining what figurative meaning the author intends. The substitution test is particularly helpful here
  • literal meanings will create obvious nonsense when substituted, while correct figurative meanings will fit smoothly

Technical and Discipline-Specific Vocabulary

  • ACT Reading passages come from various disciplines—natural science, social science, humanities—and sometimes use common words in specialized ways specific to that field.
  • In economics, "capital" doesn't mean "capital city" but "financial resources"; in literature, "voice" doesn't mean "vocal sound" but "distinctive writing style"
  • in science, "theory" doesn't mean "guess" but "well-substantiated explanation." When encountering discipline-specific passages, be alert to technical vocabulary and don't assume common meanings apply.
  • The passage context should clarify specialized meanings—scientific passages define terms, social science passages explain concepts, humanities passages provide interpretive context.
  • Use the same strategies: read surrounding context, predict meaning based on how the word functions, test answers through substitution
  • Even if you're unfamiliar with a discipline's specialized vocabulary, the passage provides enough context to determine meaning.
  • For example, if an economics passage says "The country increased capital investment in infrastructure," context (investment, infrastructure) suggests "capital" relates to money/resources, not geography.
  • Trust the contextual clues the passage provides, and don't let unfamiliar subject matter intimidate you—the answers are always findable through careful context analysis..
  • Example: Handling Figurative Language: Passage excerpt: "The author's argument rests on two fundamental assumptions about human nature
  • If either assumption proves incorrect, the entire argument collapses." Question: "As it is used in line 28, 'collapses' most nearly means:"
  • Analysis:: "Collapses" is being used figuratively—arguments can't literally fall down - Context: If assumptions are wrong, something bad happens to the argument
  • The argument "rests on" assumptions, and if those fail, the argument fails - Need a word meaning "fails" or "falls apart" or "becomes invalid"
  • Answer Choices:: A. "folds" - Could work figuratively for failing B. "fails" - Direct match for "becomes invalid/unsuccessful" C. "falls down"
  • Too literal/physical D. "weakens" - Too mild; passage suggests complete failure, not just weakening
  • Correct Answer: B: "fails" best captures the complete invalidity implied by "collapses" in this context

4. Advanced Strategies and Common Pitfalls

Beyond basic context analysis, advanced strategies help you maximize accuracy on words in context questions while avoiding subtle traps that catch even careful readers.

Using Tone and Style as Context Clues

  • The passage's overall tone and writing style provide important context for word meaning. A formal, academic passage uses words differently than a personal narrative
  • a critical passage employs different language than a celebratory one.
  • Consider tone when evaluating answers: Match formality level—if the passage is highly formal and academic, the correct answer likely uses formal vocabulary rather than casual synonyms.
  • If the question asks about "commenced" in a formal passage, "began" might be technically correct but "initiated" or "started" in formal sense is better than casual "kicked off." Match emotional tone—if the passage is enthusiastic, neutral answer choices may not capture the energy; if it's critical, positive answer choices likely misrepresent the meaning.
  • Consider author's attitude—does the author approve, disapprove, or remain neutral toward the topic? This affects how evaluative words should be interpreted.
  • For example, if an author enthusiastically discusses an innovation, describing it as "aggressive," this likely means "bold" or "ambitious" (positive), not "hostile" or "combative" (negative).
  • Tone and attitude provide crucial context for determining which shade of meaning a word carries..

The Avoiding the "Sounds Good" Trap

One of the most common errors on words in context questions is selecting an answer that "sounds good" or seems sophisticated without verifying it actually matches the context. Students sometimes choose the most impressive-sounding vocabulary word or the longest answer, assuming complexity indicates correctness.

Resist this temptation. The correct answer is the one that most accurately captures the word's meaning in this specific context, regardless of whether it's simple or complex.

Sometimes the correct answer is a straightforward, simple word while wrong answers use unnecessarily complex vocabulary that sounds impressive but doesn't quite fit. For example, if the passage says "The scientist developed a theory," answers might include:.

  • "formulated" (correct
  • means developed in this context), "engendered" (sounds sophisticated but is wrong
  • too fancy and doesn't mean developed), "created" (acceptable but perhaps less precise than formulated), "established" (close but not quite right
  • you establish truth, not develop theory). Don't be seduced by sophisticated vocabulary. The question asks what the word "most nearly means," not which answer uses the most impressive language
  • Verify your answer through substitution and context matching, not through judging which word sounds smartest

Recognizing Context Clues in the Passage

  • context clues: that signal word meaning. Learning to spot these clues accelerates your analysis:
  • Definition clues: —the author directly defines or explains the word, often using "or," "that is," "in other words," or dashes/parentheses: "The hypothesis—a proposed explanation for the phenomenon—required testing."
  • Example clues: —the author provides examples that illustrate meaning: "Renewable sources, such as solar and wind power, offer alternatives to fossil fuels."
  • Contrast clues: —words like "but," "however," "unlike," "although" signal that the target word contrasts with something else: "Unlike his earlier tentative theories
  • his current position was definitive." (Definitive contrasts with tentative, suggesting "certain" or "conclusive").
  • Synonym clues: —the passage uses a synonym or similar word nearby: "The argument was compelling and persuasive."
  • Cause-effect clues: —understanding what causes or results from something reveals meaning: "The drought was severe
  • causing widespread crop failure." Actively search for these clues in surrounding sentences—they directly provide the information you need to determine meaning.

Time Management for Words in Context

Words in context questions should be among the quickest to answer because they require analyzing only a small portion of text rather than understanding entire passages or complex arguments. However, students sometimes overthink these questions or get stuck evaluating subtle distinctions.

Time management strategies include:.

  • Target 30-45 seconds per question
  • these should be faster than complex inference or main idea questions. If stuck between two choices, quickly substitute both into the sentence and choose whichever sounds more natural
  • trust your language intuition. Don't spiral into overthinking
  • if you've done context analysis and substitution testing and selected an answer that works, move on rather than second-guessing endlessly. Use these as "confidence builders"
  • words in context questions are often easier than other question types, so answering them correctly builds momentum. Don't let one difficult word consume too much time
  • if you genuinely can't determine the answer after reasonable effort, make your best guess and move on rather than sacrificing time needed for other questions
  • These questions should be scoring opportunities that boost your performance without excessive time investment
  • doesn't capture predictive aspect B. "accurate" - Close but not quite
  • describes the prediction, not the quality of foreseeing C. "prophetic" - Correct
  • means able to predict future events accurately D. "popular" - Contradicted by "initially dismissed" Correct Answer: C - "prophetic" matches the context clues indicating prediction and foresight

.

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Words in context questions test your ability to determine meaning from context, not vocabulary knowledge in isolation
  • ✓Always read the complete sentence containing the target word plus surrounding sentences for full context
  • ✓Predict the word's meaning based on context before looking at answer choices to avoid being misled by traps
  • ✓Test each answer choice by substituting it into the original sentence and checking whether meaning is preserved
  • ✓Beware of primary definition traps that offer common meanings when the passage uses specialized or figurative meanings
  • ✓Determine the word's grammatical function to eliminate incompatible answers and narrow your options
  • ✓Recognize figurative and metaphorical uses where literal meanings don't apply to abstract contexts
  • ✓Use passage tone and style to determine the appropriate formality and emotional connotation of the answer
  • ✓Look for explicit context clues like definitions, examples, contrasts, and synonyms in surrounding text
  • ✓Don't select answers just because they sound sophisticated—choose the one that best matches the contextual meaning

lessons.title: Topic 2.1 - Redundancy & Wordiness
lessons.content:
Redundancy and wordiness questions test whether you can identify and eliminate unnecessary repetition and verbose expressions on the ACT English Test. The ACT values clarity and conciseness—saying what needs to be said in the fewest necessary words. These questions appear 6-10 times per test and require you to recognize when information is repeated, when phrases can be shortened without losing meaning, and when "DELETE the underlined portion" is the best answer. Mastering redundancy means understanding that less is often more.

1. Identifying Redundancy

Redundancy occurs when a word, phrase, or idea is repeated unnecessarily. The repeated information adds no new meaning and should be eliminated.

Common Redundant Pairs

Certain word combinations are inherently redundant because both words convey the same meaning.

✗ Redundant: past history → ✓ history

  • ✗ Redundant: advance warning → ✓ warning
  • ✗ Redundant: end result → ✓ result
  • ✗ Redundant: repeat again → ✓ repeat
  • ✗ Redundant: return back → ✓ return
  • ✗ Redundant: combine together → ✓ combine

Information Already Stated

Watch for phrases that repeat information already present in the sentence or surrounding context.

✗ Redundant: The museum, which was founded in 1950, was established in 1950.

✓ Concise: The museum was founded in 1950.

Implied Meanings

Some words or phrases contain implied meanings that make additional qualifiers unnecessary.

✗ 12 noon → ✓ noon (noon always means 12) ✗ a true fact → ✓ a fact (facts are always true) ✗ completely eliminate → ✓ eliminate (eliminate means remove completely)

Visual or Descriptive Redundancy

Descriptions that are obvious from context should be omitted.

✗ Redundant: The round circle had a diameter of 10 feet.

→ Circles are always round

✓ Concise: The circle had a diameter of 10 feet.

2. Wordy Phrases and Expressions

Wordiness occurs when a phrase uses more words than necessary to convey an idea. The ACT prefers direct, concise language over verbose expressions.

Common Wordy Phrases and Concise Alternatives

✗ due to the fact that → ✓ because ✗ in spite of the fact that → ✓ although/despite ✗ at this point in time → ✓ now ✗ for the purpose of → ✓ to/for ✗ in the event that → ✓ if ✗ it is important to note that → ✓ [delete and state directly] ✗ what I mean to say is → ✓ [delete and state directly]

Unnecessary That/Who/Which Clauses

Sometimes relative clauses can be reduced to simpler structures.

✗ Wordy: The scientist who was responsible for the discovery won an award.

✓ Concise: The scientist responsible for the discovery won an award.

Passive Voice Wordiness

Active voice is often more concise than passive voice.

✗ Wordy (passive): The experiment was conducted by the students.

✓ Concise (active): The students conducted the experiment.

Strategy: Count the words. If one answer has 8 words and another has 4 words with the same meaning, choose the 4-word version.

3. When DELETE Is the Answer

One of the four answer choices for many ACT questions is "DELETE the underlined portion." This is correct more often than students expect—approximately 10-15% of the time it appears as an option.

When to Choose DELETE

Choose DELETE when the underlined portion adds no new or necessary information.

Choose DELETE when:

• The information repeats something already stated • The phrase is obvious or self-evident • The sentence is clearer and more direct without it • All other options are wordy or redundant

Example: DELETE in Action

Original: The ancient ruins, which are very old, attract many tourists.

Analysis: "Ancient" already means "very old." The underlined phrase is redundant.

✓ Best answer: DELETE the underlined portion.

Result: The ancient ruins attract many tourists.

When NOT to DELETE

Don't choose DELETE if removing the phrase makes the sentence unclear, changes the meaning, or creates a grammatical error.

4. ACT-Specific Redundancy Patterns

The ACT tests specific redundancy patterns repeatedly. Learning these common traps helps you spot errors quickly.

Numbers and Time Redundancy

✗ in the year of 2020 → ✓ in 2020 ✗ the month of January → ✓ January ✗ a period of three years → ✓ three years

Location and Direction Redundancy

✗ close proximity → ✓ proximity / close ✗ surround on all sides → ✓ surround

Action and Process Redundancy

✗ first begin → ✓ begin ✗ continue on → ✓ continue ✗ plan ahead → ✓ plan

Comparison Redundancy

✗ same identical → ✓ same / identical ✗ completely unique → ✓ unique ✗ each individual → ✓ each

ACT Strategy: If you can remove a word or phrase without changing the meaning or creating an error, remove it. The ACT almost always prefers the most concise grammatically correct option.

.

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Redundancy: Eliminate unnecessary repetition like "past history," "repeat again," "return back," and "combine together"; watch for information that's already stated elsewhere in the sentence or implied by other words
  • ✓Wordy phrases: Replace verbose expressions with concise alternatives—"due to the fact that" → "because"; "at this point in time" → "now"; "in the event that" → "if"
  • ✓DELETE option: Choose "DELETE the underlined portion" when the phrase repeats information, is self-evident, or makes the sentence clearer without it; DELETE is correct 10-15% of the time it appears
  • ✓Common ACT patterns: Watch for time/number redundancy ("in the year of 2020"), location redundancy ("close proximity"), action redundancy ("first begin," "continue on"), and comparison redundancy ("completely unique")
  • ✓General principle: When choosing between grammatically correct options, the ACT prefers the most concise version; if you can remove words without changing meaning or creating errors, do it

lessons.subject: math
lessons.title: Topic 1.1 - Working Backwards Strategy
lessons.content:
The working backwards strategy is one of the most powerful time-saving techniques on the ACT Math section, letting you test answer choices instead of solving algebraically. This strategy works on 8-12 questions per test—that's 13-20% of all math questions!

1. What Is Backsolving?

  • Backsolving means plugging answer choices into the problem to find which one works
    • Instead of setting up equations and solving for x, you test each choice
    • Transforms complex algebra into simple arithmetic
    • Works by substituting values until you find one that satisfies all conditions
  • Key advantages over traditional algebra:
    • Often faster than setting up and solving complex equations
    • Less likely to make calculation errors with concrete numbers
    • Can verify your answer immediately
    • Works even if you struggle with algebra

When to Use Backsolving

  • Problem asks for a specific numerical value
    • "What is x?" or "How many marbles does Sarah have?"
    • NOT: "Which expression represents...?" or "What is the equation for...?"
  • Answer choices are concrete numbers, not algebraic expressions
    • ✓ Numbers like 2, 6, 14, 18, 22
    • ✗ Expressions like "2x + 3" or "a²b"
  • Traditional algebra looks messy or time-consuming
    • Complex equations with multiple steps
    • Radical expressions or absolute values
    • Situations with high error potential

2. The Strategic Backsolving Process

Step 1: Strategic Starting

  • Use the middle value strategy to maximize efficiency
    • ACT always lists answer choices in ascending or descending order
    • Begin with choice B or C (middle values)
    • If C is too big, eliminate D and E as well
    • If C is too small, eliminate A and B as well
    • This lets you eliminate 2-3 choices with one test

Step 2: Test Your Chosen Answer

  • Substitute the value into all problem conditions
    • Check: Does it make the equation true?
    • Check: Does it satisfy all constraints?
    • Check: Does it produce the correct result?

Step 3: If It Works, You're Done

  • Bubble in your answer and move on
    • Don't waste time double-checking or testing other choices
    • ACT only has one correct answer per question

Step 4: Eliminate and Adjust

  • If the answer doesn't work, cross it off immediately
    • Determine if you need a larger or smaller value
    • Use systematic elimination to rule out other choices
    • Use logic to narrow down remaining options

Step 5: Repeat

  • Test remaining choices systematically
    • Continue until you find the answer that works
    • Remember: exactly one of the five choices must work

3. Perfect Scenarios for Backsolving

  • Radical equations and square roots
    • Algebraically isolating variables requires squaring both sides multiple times
    • Creates opportunities for calculation errors
    • backsolving lets you test values directly in the original equation
  • Complex word problems
    • Multiple steps or complicated variable relationships
    • Test each answer against the problem's conditions
    • Helpful when you understand the question but struggle with setup
  • Systems of equations
    • Two or three equations with multiple variables
    • Often faster than elimination or substitution methods
    • Plug answer choices into all equations to find which satisfies them all

4. When NOT to Backsolve

  • Answer choices are algebraic expressions
    • Can't plug expressions like "2x + 3" or "n²" back into the problem
    • Must use traditional algebra to simplify and solve
  • Traditional algebra is very simple
    • Problems like "2x + 3 = 11, solve for x"
    • One or two steps of basic algebra is faster than testing choices
  • Testing takes more work than solving directly
    • Occasionally plugging in values requires more calculation than algebra
    • Use whichever method gets you to the answer fastest
  • Multiple variables with complex relationships
    • Many interconnected variables become confusing to test
    • Need to calculate multiple dependent values for each choice
    • Setting up equations systematically is often clearer

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Backsolving works by testing answer choices instead of solving algebraically—use when choices are numbers and algebra looks complex
  • ✓Always start with choice B or C to eliminate 2-3 options with one test using the middle value strategy
  • ✓Perfect for radical equations, complex word problems, and systems where algebra gets messy or time-consuming
  • ✓Avoid when answer choices are expressions, when algebra is simple, or when testing requires more work than solving

lessons.subject: math
lessons.title: Topic 1.2 - Number Substitution Technique
lessons.content:
Number substitution is a powerful test-taking strategy that transforms variable-heavy questions into simple arithmetic by plugging in concrete numbers. This technique works on 10-15% of ACT Math questions and is especially useful when you see multiple variables with few or no actual numbers!

1. What Is Number Substitution?

  • Number substitution means replacing variables with simple numbers to solve problems using arithmetic instead of complex algebra
    • Do you prefer working with numbers or variables? Most students prefer numbers!
    • Instead of manipulating algebraic expressions, you work with concrete values
    • Transform intimidating variable problems into straightforward arithmetic
  • Why this strategy is so powerful:
    • Questions with many unknown variables and few numbers often intimidate students
    • Working with real numbers is faster and less error-prone than abstract algebra
    • You can verify your answer immediately by checking it against the original problem
    • Works even if you struggle with complex algebraic manipulation

2. The 4-Step Substitution Process

Step 1: Pick Numbers for Variables

  • Choose simple, easy-to-work-with numbers
    • Avoid 0 and 1 — these can lead to incorrect answers that seem to work
    • Use 2, 3, 4, or 5 — small numbers that are easy to calculate with
    • Special cases: Use 10 for percent problems, 10 or 20 for group size problems
  • Select different numbers for each variable
    • If a question has x and y, pick x = 2 and y = 3
    • Using different values prevents confusion and ensures accurate results
  • Follow any rules stated in the question
    • If x must be negative and even, pick x = -2
    • If y must be greater than x, make sure your chosen values satisfy this
    • Pay attention to constraints like "positive integers" or "odd numbers"

Step 2: Write Down Your Numbers

  • Record your chosen values clearly
    • Write them in your test booklet or scratch paper
    • This prevents mistakes when plugging into answer choices
    • You'll need to reference these values multiple times

Step 3: Solve Using Your Numbers

  • Work through the question using your chosen values
    • Replace all variables with the numbers you picked
    • Calculate step-by-step using basic arithmetic
    • Find your numerical answer to the question

Step 4: Test Answer Choices

  • Plug your numbers into each answer choice
    • The correct answer will match the numerical answer you found in Step 3
    • Only ONE answer choice will produce your target number
    • Once you find the match, you're done — bubble it in and move on!

3. When to Use Number Substitution

  • Question asks "which of the following" or "in terms of..."
    • Looking for an expression in terms of variables (m, n, x, y, etc.)
    • The question describes a situation with variables, not specific numbers
  • Answer choices contain variables or expressions
    • ✓ Choices like "0.7nm", "2x + 3", "5(x + 3)"
    • ✗ NOT for choices that are just numbers like 2, 5, 7, 10
  • Question has multiple variables with no concrete numbers
    • Problems like "n boxes with m items each"
    • Scenarios involving undefined quantities
  • The algebra looks messy or time-consuming
    • Setting up equations with variables would take too long
    • Substitution often provides a faster path to the answer

4. Common Question Types for Substitution

  • Percent problems with variables
    • Finding percentages of unknown quantities
    • Use 10 or 100 as your starting number for easy percent calculations
    • Example: "70% of n items" → pick n = 10, so 70% of 10 = 7
  • Geometry transformation problems
    • When shapes are scaled or modified
    • Example: "length is tripled, width is halved"
    • Pick simple dimensions like length = 3, width = 2
  • Trigonometry with unknown angles
    • Questions like "if cos(2x) = a, which must be true?"
    • Pick a simple angle value (like x = 10° or x = 30°)
    • Use calculator to find what a equals, then test answer choices
  • Number property questions
    • "If x is odd and y is even, which must be odd?"
    • Pick specific values: x = 3 (odd), y = 4 (even)
    • Test each answer choice with your values

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Number substitution replaces variables with simple numbers (avoid 0 and 1, use 2-5) to transform algebra into arithmetic
  • ✓Follow 4 steps: pick numbers, write them down, solve using your numbers, test answer choices to find the match
  • ✓Use when answer choices contain variables, question asks "in terms of," or has multiple variables with no concrete numbers
  • ✓Perfect for percent problems, geometry transformations, trigonometry with unknowns, and number property questions

lessons.title: Topic 2.6 - Tips for Comparing Passages Questions
lessons.content:
The ACT Reading section includes one paired passage set consisting of two shorter passages (Passage A and Passage B) addressing related topics from different perspectives. Master systematic strategies for reading efficiently, organizing information to prevent confusion, and approaching comparison questions methodically.

1. Understanding Paired Passage Structure and Question Types

Paired passages follow a predictable structure and generate specific question types that differ from single-passage questions.

The Paired Passage Format

The ACT consistently includes one paired passage set, typically in social science or humanities:

  • Passage A: Approximately 400-450 words
  • Passage B: Approximately 400-450 words
  • Combined total: Roughly 800-900 words (slightly shorter than single full passage)
  • 10 questions total: Same as single passages

Passages address related topics but present different perspectives, focus on different aspects, or argue different positions. Common relationships:

  • Contrasting perspectives: Same topic, different conclusions
  • Complementary focuses: Related aspects (historical/contemporary, theoretical/practical)
  • Different scopes: Broad overview vs. specific case study
  • Debate or dialogue: Opposing sides of argument or controversy

Three Categories of Questions

Paired passage questions fall into three distinct categories:

  • Passage A only (typically 2-3 questions): Ask exclusively about A, can answer without reading B
    • Stems: "According to Passage A..." or "The author of Passage A suggests..."
  • Passage B only (typically 2-3 questions): Ask exclusively about B
    • Stems: "In Passage B, the author argues..." or "According to Passage B..."
  • Comparison/synthesis (typically 4-5 questions): Require understanding both passages
    • Stems: "Both passages discuss..." "Unlike Passage A, Passage B..." "Both authors would agree..."

Common Comparison Question Patterns

  • Agreement: "Both authors would most likely agree that..."
  • Disagreement: "The authors disagree about..." or "Unlike A, B believes..."
  • Perspective: "How would B author respond to A's claim in lines 15-17?"
  • Relationship: "Passage B relates to Passage A by..."
  • Shared topic: "Both passages discuss..."
  • Unique focus: "Which is discussed in A but not in B?"

Why Students Find Paired Passages Challenging

  • Information confusion—mixing up which passage said what
  • Mental fatigue—reading and comprehending two passages requires sustained attention
  • Comparison complexity—analyzing relationships is cognitively demanding
  • Time pressure perception—two passages in 9 minutes creates anxiety
  • Reading inefficiency—reading both completely then having to reread extensively

2. The Strategic Reading Approach for Paired Passages

Unlike single passages where you read straight through, paired passages benefit from a strategic approach that organizes information and prevents confusion.

The Sequential Method: Read A, Answer A, Read B, Answer All

Most effective strategy for most students:

  • Step 1: Read Passage A completely with active reading strategies
  • Step 2: Answer all Passage A only questions (skip comparison questions)
  • Step 3: Read Passage B completely, noting how B relates to A
  • Step 4: Answer Passage B only questions, then tackle comparison questions

Advantages: Not holding both passages in memory simultaneously (reduces cognitive load), answer while passage details are fresh, read B with A in mind (makes comparison easier).

Active Notation to Prevent Confusion

Biggest challenge: remembering which passage said what. Combat through systematic notation:

  • Label key ideas with A or B—mark significant points to track source
  • Note main idea of each passage separately—quick phrase capturing central point
  • Mark points of clear agreement or disagreement
  • Highlight unique topics—if A discusses something B never mentions, mark as unique to A
  • Use different marking symbols—straight underlines for A, wavy for B

Identifying the Relationship While Reading

As you read Passage B, actively identify the relationship rather than treating them as independent texts. Ask:

  • Do they agree or disagree on main point?
  • Do they focus on different aspects of same topic?
  • Does one provide example or case study of what the other discusses generally?
  • Do they represent different perspectives or stakeholders?

By the time you finish B, you should articulate in one sentence how they relate: "A argues for X while B argues against X" or "Both support X but emphasize different reasons."

Example 1: Sequential Method in Action

Step 1 - Read Passage A: Discussion of how social media platforms affect political discourse, arguing they increase polarization.

  • Note main idea: "Social media increases polarization"
  • Mark key evidence with "A"

Step 2 - Answer Passage A Questions: Questions 21-23 ask about A only. Answer while A is fresh (takes ~2 minutes).

Step 3 - Read Passage B: Same topic but arguing social media can promote diverse viewpoints if used thoughtfully.

  • While reading, note: "B disagrees with A—says social media can reduce polarization with right approach"
  • Mark key evidence with "B"

Step 4 - Answer Remaining Questions: Questions 24-26 ask about B only—answer these. Questions 27-30 are comparison questions. Now you've engaged deeply with both and can tackle efficiently.

Advantage: Never holding both full passages in working memory simultaneously; answering while information is fresh; building understanding progressively.

3. Strategies for Comparison Questions

Comparison questions require synthesizing information from both passages and understanding their relationships. Specific strategies help you answer efficiently and accurately.

Agreement Questions: Finding Common Ground

When questions ask "Both authors would agree that..." or "Both passages discuss...", identify claims supported by both passages despite any differences.

Strategy:

  • Evaluate each answer against both passages—both must support it
  • Look for foundational agreements—even when disagreeing on conclusions, often agree on basic facts
  • Distinguish between agreement and emphasis—both might mention without equal emphasis
  • Beware partial agreement—wrong answers include claims one strongly supports but other only weakly mentions
  • Verify by pointing to specific locations in both passages

Disagreement Questions: Identifying Contrasts

Questions asking "The authors disagree about..." or "Unlike Passage A, Passage B..." require identifying genuine differences in position or emphasis.

Strategy:

  • Distinguish between disagreement and different focus—true disagreement means opposing positions on same issue
  • Look for explicit contrasts—clearest disagreements involve passages making opposite claims about same specific issue
  • Verify both sides—confirm A actually supports one position and B supports the opposite
  • Check for silence vs. opposition—if A discusses something B doesn't mention, that's not disagreement

Example: If A says "Policy X successfully reduced unemployment" and B says "Policy X failed to reduce unemployment," that's clear disagreement. But if A discusses unemployment while B discusses inflation, that's different focus, not disagreement.

Response Questions: Predicting Reactions

Questions like "How would the author of Passage B respond to the claim in Passage A?" require predicting reactions based on actual passage content.

Strategy:

  • Identify specific claim in referenced lines—what exactly is A saying?
  • Determine B author's relevant position—what does B say about this topic?
  • Predict response type—agree, disagree, qualify/nuance, or provide additional evidence?
  • Match tone and strength—if B takes strong positions, response should reflect that strength
  • Base responses on actual B content—don't speculate about what author might believe

Relationship Questions: Describing How Passages Connect

Questions asking "Passage B relates to Passage A by..." or "Compared to Passage A, Passage B..." require understanding structural or rhetorical relationship. Common relationships:

  • Opposing arguments: Opposite positions on debatable issue
  • Supporting through example: One provides specific example of general principle
  • Extending or elaborating: One provides additional information building on the other
  • Contrasting perspectives: Different viewpoints on same phenomenon
  • Problem and solution: One describes problem, other proposes solutions

Example 2: Comparison Question Types

Context: Passage A argues standardized testing improves educational accountability; Passage B argues standardized testing narrows curriculum and harms learning.

Agreement question: "Both authors would agree that..."

  • ❌ "Standardized testing has no place in education" (only B would agree)
  • ❌ "Standardized testing effectively measures student learning" (only A would agree)
  • ✓ "Standardized testing has significant effects on educational practices" (both discuss major impacts, even though they evaluate differently)

Disagreement question: "The authors disagree about..."

  • ✓ "Whether standardized testing ultimately benefits students" (A says yes, B says no—clear opposition)

Response question: "How would B author respond to A's claim that testing improves accountability?"

  • ❌ "By agreeing that accountability is important" (doesn't address testing claim)
  • ✓ "By arguing that accountability comes at the cost of educational quality" (acknowledges A's point but counters with B's concern)

4. Time Management and Advanced Tactics

Paired passages present unique time management challenges. Advanced strategies help you work efficiently without sacrificing accuracy.

Optimal Time Allocation

For paired passages, target approximately 8-9 minutes total (similar to single passages):

  • 2-2.5 minutes: Reading Passage A (shorter than full passages)
  • 1.5-2 minutes: Answering Passage A questions (typically 2-3 questions)
  • 2-2.5 minutes: Reading Passage B (noting relationships to A)
  • 2.5-3 minutes: Answering B and comparison questions (typically 5-7 remaining)

Paired passages shouldn't take significantly more time than single passages because total word count is similar.

Efficient Information Retrieval for Comparison Questions

Comparison questions often require verifying information in both passages. Strategies for efficient retrieval:

  • Use your margin notes—if you labeled key ideas with A or B, quickly locate without rereading
  • Remember the structure—each passage's main argument typically appears early (first 1-2 paragraphs)
  • Use process of elimination—if certain A doesn't support answer, eliminate without checking B
  • Leverage earlier questions—single-passage questions already answered reinforce understanding

When to Skip and Return

Some comparison questions are more difficult and time-consuming. Strategic skipping improves overall performance:

  • Skip questions requiring extensive passage searching—if requires rereading multiple paragraphs in both, skip temporarily
  • Skip questions where uncertain after reasonable effort—if thought about 45+ seconds and can't decide, guess, mark for review, move on
  • Return to skipped questions if time permits—after completing all others, may have 1-2 minutes remaining
  • Don't skip questions where making progress—if methodically working through and narrowing down, continue

Building Paired Passage Stamina

Paired passages require sustained focus to track two texts and analyze relationships. Building stamina through practice improves performance:

  • Practice paired passages specifically—regularly work through sets in official ACT materials
  • Analyze your errors—determine whether from misunderstanding one passage, confusing which said what, or misidentifying relationship
  • Time yourself—practice completing sets within 8-9 minutes
  • Experiment with notation systems—try different ways to find what works best
  • Review successful attempts—when you do well, reflect on what worked to replicate strategies

Example 3: Time Management in Practice

Paired Passage Timeline (9 minutes total):

0:00-2:15 - Read Passage A (450 words), noting main argument: "Urban gardens improve community health." Mark key evidence with "A" in margin.

2:15-3:45 - Answer Questions 11-13 (Passage A only). Q11: Main idea of A. Q12: Detail from A. Q13: Author's purpose in A. (1.5 minutes for 3 questions)

3:45-6:00 - Read Passage B (450 words), noting it discusses urban gardens but emphasizes environmental benefits over health benefits. Note: "B agrees gardens good but different focus—environment not health." Mark key evidence with "B."

6:00-7:15 - Answer Questions 14-16 (Passage B only). Q14: Main point of B. Q15: What B suggests. Q16: Detail from B. (1.25 minutes for 3 questions)

7:15-9:00 - Answer Questions 17-20 (Comparison). Q17: Both passages discuss... Q18: Unlike A, B emphasizes... Q19: How would B author respond to A's health claims? Q20: Passages relate by... (1.75 minutes for 4 questions)

Total: 9 minutes for 10 questions. Efficient notation and sequential method prevented confusion and excessive rereading.

.

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Use sequential method: read Passage A, answer A questions, read Passage B, answer remaining questions
  • ✓Label key ideas with "A" or "B" to prevent confusion about which passage said what
  • ✓Identify overall relationship between passages while reading B (opposing, complementary, different focus, etc.)
  • ✓For agreement questions, verify both passages actually support answer, not just one
  • ✓Distinguish between true disagreement (opposing positions) and different focus (discussing different aspects)
  • ✓For response questions, base predictions on actual Passage B content, not speculation
  • ✓Allocate approximately 8-9 minutes total for paired passages—similar to single passages
  • ✓Use margin notes and earlier questions to retrieve information efficiently without extensive rereading
  • ✓Recognize question categories immediately from stems to know whether you need one passage or both
  • ✓Skip time-consuming comparison questions requiring extensive searching and return if time permits
