lessons.title: Topic 2.3 - Transitions
lessons.content:
Transition questions test your ability to connect ideas logically across sentences and paragraphs on the ACT English Test. These questions require you to understand logical relationships between ideas—whether you're showing contrast, cause and effect, addition, or emphasis. Appearing 6-8 times per test, transition questions reward students who read actively for meaning and understand how sentences build on each other to develop ideas.

1. Types of Logical Relationships

Transitions signal specific relationships between ideas. Understanding these categories helps you select the appropriate transition word or phrase.

Addition and Continuation

Use these transitions when adding similar or supporting information.

Addition transitions: additionally, also, furthermore, moreover, in addition, likewise, similarly, as well

Contrast and Opposition

Use these transitions when presenting contrasting or opposing ideas.

Contrast transitions: however, nevertheless, nonetheless, on the other hand, in contrast, conversely, although, yet, but, despite, still

Cause and Effect

Use these transitions when showing that one idea results from or causes another.

Cause/effect transitions: therefore, thus, consequently, as a result, for this reason, because, since, so, accordingly, hence

Examples and Emphasis

Use these transitions when providing examples or emphasizing a point.

Example/emphasis transitions: for example, for instance, specifically, in particular, indeed, in fact, notably, especially

2. Choosing the Correct Transition

To select the right transition, you must understand the relationship between the ideas it connects. Always read the sentences before and after the transition.

Step 1: Identify the Logical Relationship

Read the sentence before the transition and the sentence with/after the transition. Ask: What's the relationship?

Example:

  • "The experiment was carefully planned. _____, the results were inconclusive."
  • Analysis: First sentence is positive (carefully planned). Second sentence is negative (inconclusive). This is a CONTRAST relationship.
  • ✓ Correct answer: However / Nevertheless / Despite this

Step 2: Eliminate Wrong Relationships

Once you've identified the relationship, eliminate transitions that signal different relationships.

In the example above, eliminate:

  • • "Therefore" → suggests cause/effect, not contrast
  • • "For example" → suggests illustration, not contrast
  • • "Additionally" → suggests addition, not contrast

Common ACT Transition Traps

The ACT loves to offer transitions that sound sophisticated but create illogical connections.

Watch out for:

  • • Using "however" when ideas don't actually contrast
  • • Using "therefore" when there's no cause-effect relationship
  • • Using "for example" when the second sentence isn't an example

3. Transition Placement and Punctuation

Transitions can appear at different positions in a sentence, and their punctuation varies by placement. Understanding these patterns helps you choose grammatically correct options.

Beginning of Sentence

Most transitions appear at the start of sentences, followed by a comma.

✓ Correct: However, the results were surprising.

✓ Correct: Therefore, we revised our approach.

Middle of Sentence

Some transitions can interrupt a sentence. Set them off with commas on both sides.

✓ Correct: The results, however, were inconclusive.

✓ Correct: This approach, in fact, proved successful.

No Transition Needed

Sometimes the best answer is no transition at all—when the logical connection is already clear or when adding a transition makes the writing awkward.

Important: If "DELETE the underlined portion" is an option and the sentences flow logically without the transition, consider choosing DELETE.

4. Advanced Transition Strategies

Beyond knowing transition words, successful students understand how to analyze passage flow and recognize subtle logical relationships that the ACT tests.

Reading for Relationship, Not Just Words

Don't just match transition words to categories. Understand what the sentences actually mean.

Strategy:

1. Read sentence before transition (understand its point) 2. Read sentence with/after transition (understand its point) 3. Ask: Are these ideas similar, opposite, or cause-effect?

4. Choose the transition that matches that relationship

Multiple Valid Transitions

Often several transitions could work logically. Choose the one that's most precise and fits the passage tone.

For contrast, all these could work:

• However (neutral, common) • Nevertheless (more formal, emphatic) • On the other hand (shows two sides) • In contrast (emphasizes difference) → Choose based on passage tone and emphasis

Paragraph-Level Transitions

Sometimes transitions connect entire paragraphs, not just sentences. These require understanding the main idea of each paragraph.

For paragraph transitions, ask:

• What was the main point of the previous paragraph?

• What's the main point of this paragraph?

• How do these main ideas relate?

.

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Four main relationship types: Addition (furthermore, moreover); Contrast (however, nevertheless); Cause/effect (therefore, consequently); Example/emphasis (for instance, indeed)
  • ✓Selection strategy: Read sentences before and after the transition; identify the logical relationship (similar, opposite, or cause-effect); eliminate transitions signaling different relationships; choose the most precise option
  • ✓Placement and punctuation: Transitions at sentence beginnings need comma after; transitions interrupting sentences need commas on both sides; sometimes DELETE is correct when logical connection is already clear
  • ✓Advanced strategies: Understand meaning, not just memorize words; when multiple transitions could work, choose the most precise one for passage tone; for paragraph transitions, consider main ideas of both paragraphs
  • ✓Common traps: Using "however" when ideas don't contrast; using "therefore" without cause-effect; using "for example" when second sentence isn't an example; always verify the logical relationship matches the transition

lessons.subject: math
lessons.title: Topic 2.1 - Understanding Angles & Lines
lessons.content:
Angles questions appear frequently on the ACT Math test, testing your understanding of vertical angles, parallel lines, and polygon properties. The key to solving these problems is labeling all known angles and using angle relationships to find unknown values.

1. Intersecting Lines and Vertical Angles

  • Vertical angles are angles that are opposite each other when two lines intersect
    • Vertical angles are always equal to each other
    • If you know one angle, you automatically know its vertical angle
  • Adjacent angles are angles that are next to each other and share a side
    • Adjacent angles are supplementary (they add up to 180°)
    • Example: If one angle is 60°, the adjacent angle is 120° (since 60° + 120° = 180°)
  • When two lines intersect, they create 4 angles
    • Opposite angles (vertical angles) are equal
    • Side-by-side angles (adjacent angles) are supplementary

2. Parallel Lines and Angle Relationships

  • When two parallel lines are crossed by another line (called a transversal), special angle relationships are created
  • The most important rule to remember:
    • There are two sets of identical angles
    • Any angle from the first set is supplementary to any angle from the second set
    • Example: If one angle is 60°, four angles will be 60° and four angles will be 120°
  • Specific angle relationships you should know:
    • Vertical angles are equal
    • Alternate interior angles are equal (angles on opposite sides of the transversal, between the parallel lines)
    • Corresponding angles are equal (angles in the same position at each intersection)
    • Opposite interior angles are supplementary (they add to 180°)
  • TIP: Extend parallel lines with your pencil
    • Sometimes parallel lines in diagrams don't extend all the way across
    • Draw them longer yourself to make angle relationships easier to see
    • Example: In a parallelogram, extend the sides to create full parallel lines

3. Interior Angles in Polygons

  • Every polygon has a specific sum of interior angles based on the number of sides
    • Triangle (3 sides): 180°
    • Quadrilateral (4 sides): 360°
    • Pentagon (5 sides): 540°
    • Hexagon (6 sides): 720°
  • The formula for any polygon:
    • Sum of Interior Angles = 180°(n − 2)
    • Where n is the number of sides
    • This formula works for any polygon, regardless of shape
  • How to use this formula on the ACT:
    • Count the number of sides of the polygon
    • Plug n into the formula: 180°(n − 2)
    • Set the sum equal to the given angles and solve
    • The shape doesn't matter—only the number of sides matters
  • Common polygon applications:
    • Finding a missing angle when other angles are given
    • Finding the value of x when angles are expressed as algebraic expressions
    • Verifying if given angle measurements are possible for a polygon

4. Test-Taking Tips for Angle Questions

  • Always label angles as you find them
    • Write angle measurements directly on the diagram
    • The more angles you label, the easier it becomes to find the angle you need
    • Use vertical angle and supplementary angle relationships to fill in values
  • Look for triangles within the figure
    • All angles in a triangle add to 180°
    • If you know two angles in a triangle, you can find the third
    • Sometimes you need to find angles in one triangle to solve another triangle
  • Watch for angle bisectors
    • An angle bisector cuts an angle exactly in half
    • If an angle is 72° and it's bisected, each half is 36°
    • Use this to find additional angles in the figure
  • Use what you know about parallel lines
    • If you see two parallel lines, look for the transversal
    • Identify which angles are equal and which are supplementary
    • Remember: there are two groups of identical angles

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Vertical angles are equal, adjacent angles are supplementary (add to 180°)
  • ✓Parallel lines create two sets of identical angles—any angle from one set is supplementary to any angle from the other set
  • ✓Sum of interior angles in any polygon = 180°(n − 2) where n is the number of sides
  • ✓Always label known angles on the diagram and use angle relationships to find unknown values

lessons.subject: math
lessons.title: Logarithms
lessons.content:
Logarithms appear 1-2 times per ACT Math test, usually testing your ability to convert between logarithmic form and exponential form. Understanding this conversion is the key to solving almost all logarithm questions on the ACT.

1. Basics of Logarithms (Converting Between Forms)

  • The fundamental relationship between logs and exponents:
    • log_a(b) = c is the same as a^c = b
    • Where a is the base, c is the exponent, and b is the result
    • Both equations describe the exact same relationship—just different notation
  • Examples of converting from logarithmic form to exponential form:
    • log₃(3) = 1 → 3¹ = 3
    • log₃(9) = 2 → 3² = 9
    • log₃(27) = 3 → 3³ = 27
    • The pattern: "log base 3 of 27 equals 3" means "3 to the 3rd power equals 27"
  • How to solve logarithm equations:
    • Step 1: Convert from logarithmic form to exponential form
    • Step 2: Solve the exponential equation using exponent rules
    • Example: When log₄(x) = 3, what is x?
    • Convert: 4³ = x
    • Solve: x = 64
  • CRITICAL strategy:
    • Almost ALL ACT logarithm questions are solved by converting to exponential form
    • If you can convert, you can solve the problem
    • Practice this conversion until it's automatic!

2. Using Your Calculator (Change of Base Rule)

  • The change of base rule lets you use a calculator:
    • log_b(a) = log(a) / log(b)
    • This converts ANY logarithm to base 10 (which calculators can compute)
    • Example: log₃(9) = log(9) / log(3) = 0.954 / 0.477 = 2
  • Using the change of base rule on your calculator:
    • To find log₃(9): Enter log(9) ÷ log(3) in calculator
    • To find log₂(8): Enter log(8) ÷ log(2) in calculator
    • This works for ANY base and ANY value
  • Some calculators have a built-in logbase function:
    • TI-83/84: Press MATH, scroll to LOGBASE
    • This allows direct entry: logbase(3, 9) = 2
    • Check if your calculator has this feature—it's faster!
  • Calculator method vs. algebraic method:
    • For simple bases (2, 3, 4, 5): Converting to exponential form is often faster
    • For complex problems with multiple logs: Use change of base rule
    • Example: 5(log₃(9) + log₂(8)) can be solved entirely with calculator

3. Logarithm Rules (For Advanced Questions)

  • Four logarithm rules you should know:
    • Product Rule: log_a(xy) = log_a(x) + log_a(y)
    • Quotient Rule: log_a(x/y) = log_a(x) - log_a(y)
    • Power Rule: log_a(x^n) = n·log_a(x)
    • Log of 1: log_a(1) = 0 (because a⁰ = 1)
  • When to use these rules:
    • These appear RARELY on the ACT (1-2 times per test, if at all)
    • Most often on the LAST 10 questions (hardest section)
    • Students aiming for 30+ should memorize these
    • Other students can skip—focus on conversion first!
  • Example using power rule:
    • If log₉(3^x) = 3/2, what is x?
    • Use power rule: x·log₉(3) = 3/2
    • Find log₉(3) using change of base: log(3)/log(9) = 1/2
    • Substitute: x·(1/2) = 3/2
    • Solve: x = 3
  • Shortcut - backsolving with calculator:
    • If answer choices are given, plug each one in
    • Use change of base rule to evaluate both sides
    • The correct answer makes both sides equal
    • This is often faster than using logarithm rules!

4. Natural Logarithms (ln)

  • Natural logarithms use base e (approximately 2.71828):
    • ln(b) = c is the same as e^c = b
    • The base "e" is invisible—it's always e for natural logs
    • ln is just shorthand notation for log_e
  • Natural logarithms appear VERY rarely:
    • Usually only in the last 5-10 questions (hardest section)
    • Students rushing through can skip this topic entirely
    • Students aiming for 30+ should learn the basics
  • Solving natural logarithm equations:
    • Example: If ln(x-1) = 3, then x = ?
    • Step 1: Convert to exponential form: e³ = x-1
    • Step 2: Solve for x: x = e³ + 1
    • Same conversion strategy as regular logarithms!
  • All logarithm rules work for natural logs too:
    • ln(xy) = ln(x) + ln(y)
    • ln(x/y) = ln(x) - ln(y)
    • ln(x^n) = n·ln(x)
    • ln(1) = 0

5. Test-Taking Tips for Logarithms

  • Master the conversion between logarithmic and exponential form
    • This is THE most important skill for ACT logarithm questions
    • Practice until you can convert instantly without thinking
    • Almost every logarithm question becomes easy once you convert
  • Use your calculator with the change of base rule
    • log_b(a) = log(a) / log(b) works for ANY logarithm
    • This lets you evaluate complex expressions quickly
    • Check if your calculator has a built-in logbase function
  • Backsolve when answer choices are given
    • Plug each answer choice into the original equation
    • Use change of base rule to evaluate on calculator
    • Often faster than using logarithm rules algebraically
  • Prioritize logarithm rules based on your target score
    • Target score below 28: Focus ONLY on conversion and change of base
    • Target score 28-32: Memorize the four logarithm rules
    • Target score 33+: Learn natural logarithms too
    • Don't waste time on rare topics if you need basics first!
  • Remember: logarithms are just another form of exponents
    • If you understand exponents well, logarithms become easier
    • The conversion is the bridge between the two
    • All logarithm rules mirror exponent rules

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Convert between forms: log_a(b) = c means a^c = b—this conversion solves almost all ACT logarithm questions
  • ✓Use change of base rule with calculator: log_b(a) = log(a) / log(b) to evaluate any logarithm quickly
  • ✓Memorize logarithm rules (product, quotient, power, log of 1) only if aiming for 30+—they appear rarely
  • ✓Natural logarithms (ln) use base e and follow the same conversion strategy: ln(b) = c means e^c = b

lessons.subject: math
lessons.title: Inequalities
lessons.content:
Inequalities appear 2-4 times per ACT Math test, testing your ability to solve algebraic inequalities and graph them on number lines or coordinate planes. The most important rule: flip the inequality sign when multiplying or dividing by a negative number.

1. Solving Algebraic Inequalities

  • Treat inequality signs (<, >, ≤, ≥) like an equals sign:
    • Use all normal algebra rules: add, subtract, combine like terms
    • Isolate the variable just like solving equations
    • The inequality sign stays the same for most operations
  • CRITICAL RULE: Flip the sign when multiplying or dividing by a negative
    • This is the #1 mistake students make with inequalities!
    • Example: -2x + 5 < 11
    • Subtract 5: -2x < 6
    • Divide by -2: x > -3 (sign flipped from < to >!)
  • When NOT to flip the sign:
    • ONLY flip when you multiply or divide BOTH SIDES by a negative
    • Don't flip just because you see a negative number somewhere!
    • Example: 3x + 6 > x - 4
    • Combine: 2x > -10
    • Divide by 2 (positive): x > -5 (sign stays the same!)
  • Step-by-step process:
    • Step 1: Move all variable terms to one side
    • Step 2: Move all number terms to the other side
    • Step 3: Combine like terms
    • Step 4: Divide to isolate variable (flip sign if dividing by negative!)

2. Graphing Inequalities on a Number Line

  • Two types of circles on number lines:
    • Open circle (○): Use for > and < (strict inequalities)
    • The endpoint is NOT included in the solution
    • Example: x > 3 has an open circle at 3
    • Solid circle (●): Use for ≥ and ≤ (inclusive inequalities)
    • The endpoint IS included in the solution
    • Example: x ≥ 3 has a solid circle at 3
  • Which direction to shade:
    • Greater than (> or ≥): Shade to the RIGHT
    • Example: x ≥ 10/3 → solid circle at 10/3, shade right
    • Less than (< or ≤): Shade to the LEFT
    • Example: x < -5 → open circle at -5, shade left
  • Quick memory trick:
    • The inequality sign "points" to the smaller values
    • So x > 3 means x is to the RIGHT of 3 (bigger values)
    • And x < 3 means x is to the LEFT of 3 (smaller values)

3. Graphing Linear Inequalities in the Coordinate Plane

  • Three-step process for graphing linear inequalities:
    • Step 1: Rearrange into y = mx + b form (slope-intercept)
    • Step 2: Plot the line (dashed or solid based on inequality)
    • Step 3: Shade the solution region (above or below the line)
  • Dashed vs. solid lines:
    • Dashed line: Use for > and < (strict inequalities)
    • Points ON the line are NOT part of the solution
    • Solid line: Use for ≥ and ≤ (inclusive inequalities)
    • Points ON the line ARE part of the solution
  • Where to shade:
    • Greater than (> or ≥): Shade ABOVE the line
    • Example: y ≥ 2x + 3 → solid line, shade above
    • Less than (< or ≤): Shade BELOW the line
    • Example: y < -x + 2 → dashed line, shade below
  • Example: Graph 2x + 3y ≥ 6
    • Step 1: Solve for y: 3y ≥ -2x + 6 → y ≥ (-2/3)x + 2
    • Step 2: Draw solid line (because of ≥)
    • Step 3: Shade above the line (because of ≥)

4. Systems of Inequalities and Advanced Graphing

  • Systems of inequalities (multiple inequalities on same graph):
    • Graph each inequality separately on the same coordinate plane
    • The solution is where the shaded regions OVERLAP
    • Example: y < 2x - 4 AND y > -(1/3)x - 2
    • Graph both lines, shade both regions, find the overlap
  • Parabola inequalities (follow same rules as lines):
    • Greater than (> or ≥): Shade ABOVE the parabola
    • Less than (< or ≤): Shade BELOW the parabola
    • Use dashed curve for > and <, solid curve for ≥ and ≤
  • Circle and ellipse inequalities (different shading rules):
    • Greater than (> or ≥): Shade OUTSIDE the circle/ellipse
    • Example: (x-2)² + (y-1)² > 4 → shade outside the circle
    • Less than (< or ≤): Shade INSIDE the circle/ellipse
    • Example: (x-2)²/4 + (y-1)²/9 ≤ 1 → shade inside the ellipse
  • When you'll see advanced inequalities:
    • Parabola/circle/ellipse inequalities appear in the LAST 10 questions
    • These are for students aiming for 30+ scores
    • Master linear inequalities first before worrying about these!

5. Test-Taking Tips for Inequalities

  • Write "FLIP SIGN" when dividing by negatives
    • This is the most common mistake on inequality questions
    • Circle any negative you're dividing by to remind yourself
    • Double-check the final sign before selecting your answer
  • Use test points to check your graph shading
    • Pick a point in the shaded region (like (0,0) if it's not on the line)
    • Plug it into the original inequality
    • If it makes the inequality true, you shaded correctly!
    • If false, you shaded the wrong side
  • Remember: Open vs solid circles/lines
    • < and > → open circle/dashed line
    • ≤ and ≥ → solid circle/solid line
    • ACT answer choices often differ only in this detail!
  • For systems, look for the overlap
    • The solution to a system is where ALL shaded regions overlap
    • This is usually the darkest shaded area on the graph
    • Test a point in the overlap to verify it satisfies all inequalities
  • Circle/ellipse shading is opposite of parabola/line shading
    • Lines/parabolas: > means shade above
    • Circles/ellipses: > means shade outside
    • This catches many students—don't mix them up!

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓FLIP the inequality sign when multiplying or dividing BOTH SIDES by a negative number—this is the #1 mistake students make
  • ✓Number lines: use open circles for > and <, solid circles for ≥ and ≤; shade right for greater than, left for less than
  • ✓Linear/parabola inequalities: > and ≥ shade above the line, < and ≤ shade below; use dashed for strict (<, >), solid for inclusive (≤, ≥)
  • ✓Circle/ellipse inequalities shade OPPOSITE: > and ≥ shade OUTSIDE, < and ≤ shade INSIDE

lessons.subject: math
lessons.title: Absolute Value
lessons.content:
1. What is Absolute Value? (Definition and Basic Operations)

  • Definition: Absolute value is the distance from zero on a number line
    • Distance is always positive, so absolute value is always positive or zero
    • |3| = 3 (3 is three units from zero)
    • |-3| = 3 (-3 is also three units from zero)
  • Order of Operations with Absolute Value:
    • Step 1: Complete all math INSIDE the absolute value bars first
    • Step 2: Take the absolute value (make positive)
    • Step 3: Complete remaining operations outside the bars
  • Example: |3 - 7| + 2
    • Step 1: Work inside bars: |3 - 7| = |-4|
    • Step 2: Take absolute value: |-4| = 4
    • Step 3: Complete outside: 4 + 2 = 6
  • Calculator Tip: Most calculators have an "abs(" function for absolute value
    • On TI calculators: MATH → NUM → abs(
    • You can use this to check your work quickly

2. Solving Absolute Value Equations with Variables

  • Key Concept: Absolute value equations with variables have TWO solutions
    • Why? Because both a positive and negative number can have the same absolute value
    • Example: |x - 3| = 5 means (x - 3) could equal 5 OR -5
  • Four-Step Process to Solve:
    • Step 1: Add/subtract any constants OUTSIDE the absolute value bars to move them to the other side
    • Step 2: Multiply/divide any coefficients directly IN FRONT of the absolute value bars
    • Step 3: Set the expression inside equal to BOTH the positive and negative value
    • Step 4: Solve both equations to get both solutions
  • Example: 3|2x + 1| - 6 = 45
    • Step 1: Add 6 to both sides → 3|2x + 1| = 51
    • Step 2: Divide by 3 → |2x + 1| = 17
    • Step 3: Set up two equations:
    • • 2x + 1 = 17 → 2x = 16 → x = 8
    • • 2x + 1 = -17 → 2x = -18 → x = -9
    • Solution set: {-9, 8}
  • Common Mistake: Only finding one solution
    • ALWAYS check answer choices - if they show two values, you need both solutions!
    • If you only find one solution, you probably forgot the negative case

3. Absolute Value Inequalities (The Most Difficult Type)

  • Key Concept: Absolute value inequalities have INTERVAL solutions (not just two numbers)
    • |x| < 3 means "all numbers less than 3 units from zero"
    • Solution: -3 < x < 3 (between -3 and 3)
  • Two Main Types:
    • Type 1: |x| < a or |x| ≤ a (Less than)
    • • Solution format: -a < x < a (or -a ≤ x ≤ a)
    • • One compound inequality
    • • Think: "close to zero" or "between two values"
    • Type 2: |x| > a or |x| ≥ a (Greater than)
    • • Solution format: x < -a AND x > a (or x ≤ -a AND x ≥ a)
    • • Two separate inequalities with "AND"
    • • Think: "far from zero" or "outside the interval"
  • Four-Step Process:
    • Step 1: Isolate the absolute value bars (move all terms outside to the other side)
    • Step 2: Determine the type (< means "between", > means "outside")
    • Step 3: Set up the inequality based on type
    • Step 4: Solve for the variable
  • Example 1: |x + 3| - 4 < 1 (Less than type)
    • Step 1: Add 4 to both sides → |x + 3| < 5
    • Step 2: This is "less than" type, so solution is between -5 and 5
    • Step 3: Set up: -5 < x + 3 < 5
    • Step 4: Subtract 3 from all parts: -8 < x < 2
  • Example 2: |½x + 2| > 3 (Greater than type)
    • Step 1: Already isolated
    • Step 2: This is "greater than" type, so solution is outside -3 and 3
    • Step 3: Set up two inequalities:
    • • ½x + 2 < -3 → ½x < -5 → x < -10
    • • ½x + 2 > 3 → ½x > 1 → x > 2
    • Step 4: Solution: x < -10 AND x > 2

4. Advanced Absolute Value Concepts

  • Absolute Value Properties You Must Know:
    • If |a| = -a, then a ≤ 0 (a must be zero or negative)
    • Why? The only way absolute value equals its negative is if the number is ≤ 0
    • For x > 0 and y < 0: |x| - |y| = x - (-y) = x + y
    • Positive number's absolute value = itself
    • Negative number's absolute value = its opposite
  • Comparing Absolute Values:
    • If a < b < c and c > 0:
    • • |c| is always the largest (furthest from zero on positive side)
    • • Can't determine which of |a| or |b| is larger without more info
    • Example: If a = -10, b = -2, c = 5:
    • • |a| = 10, |b| = 2, |c| = 5
    • • |a| > |c| even though a < c
  • Distance Interpretation:
    • |x - a| = d means "x is d units away from a"
    • Example: |x + 2| = 8 means "x is 8 units from -2"
    • Note: x + 2 = x - (-2), so we're measuring distance from -2
    • Solutions: x = 6 or x = -10 (both are 8 units from -2)
  • Equivalent Expressions:
    • |x - y - z| = |x - (y + z)|
    • This also equals |-x + y + z| (opposite signs for all terms)
    • Absolute value of opposites are equal: |a| = |-a|
  • Special Case: No Solution
    • If you end up with something like |-3x + 1| + 15 < 12:
    • Isolate: |-3x + 1| < -3
    • Absolute value can NEVER be negative, so NO SOLUTION!

5. Test-Taking Tips for Absolute Value

  • Tip #1: Look at answer choices first to determine what type of problem it is
    • Two numbers in braces like {-9, 8}? → Absolute value equation (2 solutions)
    • Compound inequality like -8 < x < 2? → Absolute value inequality (interval)
    • Two inequalities with AND? → Greater than type inequality
  • Tip #2: For equations, backsolve by plugging in answer choices
    • If the question asks for the solution to |2x - 4| = 10:
    • Try x = 7: |2(7) - 4| = |14 - 4| = |10| = 10 ✓
    • This is often faster than algebraic solving
  • Tip #3: Remember the critical patterns
    • |x| < a → between two values (one compound inequality)
    • |x| > a → outside two values (two separate inequalities with AND)
    • Memorize these patterns - they appear on EVERY ACT test!
  • Tip #4: Watch out for the "no solution" trap
    • If you isolate absolute value bars and get |something| < negative number → NO SOLUTION
    • If you isolate and get |something| = negative number → NO SOLUTION
    • This often appears as answer choice "No solution" or "The empty set"
✨ Key Takeaways
  • Absolute value equations with variables ALWAYS have two solutions - set the inside equal to both positive and negative values
  • For inequalities: |x| < a means -a < x < a (between), while |x| > a means x < -a AND x > a (outside)
  • Always isolate the absolute value bars first before setting up your equations or inequalities
  • Remember: absolute value can never be negative - if you get |something| < 0, the answer is "no solution"

lessons.subject: math
lessons.title: Areas, Volumes & Triangles
lessons.content:
Geometry questions involving areas, volumes, and triangles appear on every ACT Math test, accounting for approximately 15-20% of all questions. Success on these problems requires memorizing key formulas and knowing when to apply specific triangle rules like Pythagorean theorem and special right triangle ratios.

1. Area Formulas for Common Shapes

  • You MUST memorize these area formulas—they are NOT provided on the ACT:
    • Triangle: A = ½bh (where b = base, h = height)
    • Rectangle: A = lw (where l = length, w = width)
    • Square: A = s² (where s = side length)
    • Parallelogram: A = bh (base times height, NOT side lengths)
    • Trapezoid: A = ½(b₁ + b₂)h (average of the two bases times height)
    • Circle: A = πr² (where r = radius)
    • Kite: A = ½d₁d₂ (half the product of the diagonals)
  • Common mistakes to avoid:
    • For parallelograms, use the HEIGHT (perpendicular distance), not the slanted side length
    • For circles, make sure you have the radius, not the diameter (if given diameter, divide by 2)
    • For triangles, the height must be perpendicular to the base
  • Perimeter formulas you should know:
    • Rectangle: P = 2l + 2w
    • Square: P = 4s
    • Circle (circumference): C = 2πr or C = πd

2. Volume Formulas and Unit Conversions

  • Essential volume formulas to memorize:
    • Rectangular Prism (box): V = lwh
    • Cube: V = s³
    • Right Cylinder: V = πr²h
    • Any 3D shape: V = Bh (where B = area of base, h = height)
  • Surface area formulas (less common but important):
    • Rectangular Prism: SA = 2lw + 2lh + 2wh
    • Cube: SA = 6s²
  • CRITICAL: Unit conversions—The ACT frequently tests these, and students make costly mistakes:
    • Always convert units BEFORE calculating area or volume
    • 1 yard = 3 feet
    • 1 foot = 12 inches
    • 1 square yard = 9 square feet (not 3!)
    • 1 square foot = 144 square inches (not 12!)
    • 1 cubic yard = 27 cubic feet (not 3!)
    • 1 cubic foot = 1,728 cubic inches (not 12!)
  • Why you must convert FIRST:
    • Example: A field is 136 yards × 93 yards. To find area in square feet:
    • ✓ CORRECT: Convert to feet first: (136 × 3) × (93 × 3) = 408 × 279 = 113,832 ft²
    • ✗ WRONG: Calculate area then convert: 136 × 93 = 12,648, then × 9 = wrong answer!

3. Right Triangles and Pythagorean Theorem

  • The Pythagorean theorem applies ONLY to right triangles:
    • a² + b² = c²
    • Where a and b are the legs (the two shorter sides)
    • c is the hypotenuse (the longest side, opposite the right angle)
  • Pythagorean triples—memorize these to save time:
    • 3-4-5 triangle: If you see sides of 3 and 4, the hypotenuse is 5
    • 5-12-13 triangle: If you see sides of 5 and 12, the hypotenuse is 13
    • These can be scaled up: 6-8-10, 9-12-15, 10-24-26, etc.
    • If you recognize a Pythagorean triple, you can skip the calculation entirely
  • When to use Pythagorean theorem:
    • Finding the third side of a right triangle when you know two sides
    • Finding distances in coordinate geometry problems
    • Solving problems with rectangles (diagonals create right triangles)
    • Working with circles and tangent lines

4. Special Right Triangles (30-60-90 and 45-45-90)

  • 45-45-90 triangle (also called a right isosceles triangle):
    • Side ratio: x : x : x√2
    • The two legs are equal (both length x)
    • The hypotenuse is x√2 (one leg times √2)
    • If the leg is 5, the hypotenuse is 5√2
    • If the hypotenuse is 10, each leg is 10/√2 = 5√2
  • 30-60-90 triangle:
    • Side ratio: x : x√3 : 2x
    • Short leg (opposite 30°): x
    • Long leg (opposite 60°): x√3
    • Hypotenuse (opposite 90°): 2x
    • KEY RULE: The short leg is always half the hypotenuse
    • If the hypotenuse is 10, the short leg is 5, and the long leg is 5√3
  • How to recognize special right triangles:
    • Look for angle measurements (45°, 30°, 60°)
    • Look for the phrase "right isosceles triangle" (45-45-90)
    • Look for equilateral triangles split in half (creates 30-60-90)
    • If you see √2 or √3 in the answer choices, it's likely a special right triangle
  • When to use special right triangles instead of Pythagorean theorem:
    • When you see the special angles (30°, 45°, 60°)
    • When the answer choices contain √2 or √3
    • Special triangles are FASTER than using a² + b² = c²

5. Test-Taking Tips for Geometry Problems

  • Draw and label diagrams
    • If no diagram is provided, draw one yourself
    • Label all given measurements directly on the diagram
    • Mark right angles with a small square
    • Write formulas next to the shapes as you work
  • Look for Pythagorean triples first
    • Before using a² + b² = c², check if the sides are a Pythagorean triple
    • Common ones: 3-4-5, 5-12-13, 8-15-17, and their multiples
    • This saves time and prevents calculation errors
  • Use substitution for complex problems
    • If a problem uses variables (like "a field is l feet by w feet"), pick simple numbers
    • Example: Let l = 4 and w = 3, then solve with those specific values
    • This makes algebraic area/volume problems much easier to visualize
  • Convert units before calculating
    • NEVER calculate area in yards and then convert to square feet
    • ALWAYS convert the length and width first, then calculate
    • Write out the conversion as a separate step to avoid mistakes
  • Memorize formulas NOW, not the night before
    • Make flashcards for all area and volume formulas
    • Practice drawing and labeling 45-45-90 and 30-60-90 triangles from memory
    • Review Pythagorean triples until you can recognize them instantly

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Memorize all area and volume formulas—they are NOT provided on the ACT, and you must know them cold to save time
  • ✓Always convert units BEFORE calculating area or volume (1 square yard = 9 square feet, NOT 3)
  • ✓Recognize Pythagorean triples (3-4-5, 5-12-13) and special right triangles (45-45-90 ratio x:x:x√2, 30-60-90 ratio x:x√3:2x) to solve problems instantly
  • ✓For Pythagorean theorem, remember a² + b² = c² only works for right triangles, where c is always the hypotenuse (longest side)

lessons.subject: math
lessons.title: Lines
lessons.content:
Lines and linear functions appear frequently on the ACT Math test, testing your ability to calculate slope, write equations, and use coordinate geometry formulas. Mastering the different forms of linear equations and understanding parallel/perpendicular relationships is essential for scoring well on these questions.

1. Slope and Its Properties

  • Slope formula for any two points (x₁, y₁) and (x₂, y₂):
    • Slope = (y₁ - y₂) / (x₁ - x₂) = rise / run
    • Rise = change in y-coordinates
    • Run = change in x-coordinates
  • Understanding slope values:
    • Positive slope: Line goes up and to the right
    • Negative slope: Line goes down and to the right
    • Higher slope: Steeper line
    • Lower slope: Flatter line
    • Zero slope: Horizontal line
    • Undefined slope: Vertical line
  • Parallel lines: Same slope
    • If line A has slope 3, any line parallel to it also has slope 3
    • Parallel lines never intersect
  • Perpendicular lines: Slopes are negative reciprocals
    • To find the negative reciprocal: flip the fraction and change the sign
    • If line A has slope 2/3, a perpendicular line has slope -3/2
    • If line A has slope 4, a perpendicular line has slope -1/4
    • If line A has slope -5, a perpendicular line has slope 1/5
    • Perpendicular lines intersect at 90 degrees

2. Slope-Intercept Form (y = mx + b)

  • The most common and useful form of a linear equation:
    • y = mx + b
    • m = slope (steepness of the line)
    • b = y-intercept (where the line crosses the y-axis)
  • Reading information from the equation:
    • Example: y = 3x - 5 has slope 3 and y-intercept -5
    • Example: y = -2x + 7 has slope -2 and y-intercept 7
    • Example: y = (1/2)x + 4 has slope 1/2 and y-intercept 4
  • Reading information from a graph:
    • Find the y-intercept: where the line crosses the y-axis
    • Find the slope: pick two points and calculate rise/run
    • Or count: "up 2, right 1" means slope = 2/1 = 2
  • When to use slope-intercept form:
    • When you know the slope and y-intercept
    • When you need to quickly identify slope or y-intercept from an equation
    • When graphing a line

3. Point-Slope Form and Standard Form

  • Point-slope form: Use when you know a point and the slope
    • y - y₁ = m(x - x₁)
    • (x₁, y₁) is a point on the line
    • m is the slope
    • After plugging in values, solve for y to convert to slope-intercept form
  • Alternative method: Plug point into y = mx + b
    • If you know the slope m, write: y = mx + b
    • Plug in the (x, y) values of a point on the line
    • Solve for b to find the y-intercept
    • This often feels more intuitive than point-slope form
  • Standard form: Less common but sometimes useful
    • Ax + By = C
    • A, B, and C are constants (usually integers)
    • To find slope from standard form: slope = -A/B
    • To find y-intercept: set x = 0 and solve for y
    • To find x-intercept: set y = 0 and solve for x
    • Usually easier to convert to slope-intercept form first

4. Midpoint and Distance Formulas

  • Midpoint formula: Finds the point exactly halfway between two points
    • Midpoint = ((x₁ + x₂)/2, (y₁ + y₂)/2)
    • Average the x-coordinates, average the y-coordinates
    • Example: Midpoint of (2, 5) and (8, 13) = ((2+8)/2, (5+13)/2) = (5, 9)
  • Distance formula: Finds the straight-line distance between two points
    • Distance = √[(x₁ - x₂)² + (y₁ - y₂)²]
    • This is the Pythagorean theorem applied to coordinates
    • (x₁ - x₂) is the horizontal distance
    • (y₁ - y₂) is the vertical distance
    • Square both, add them, then take the square root
  • Relationship between distance and Pythagorean theorem:
    • The distance formula IS the Pythagorean theorem
    • The two points form a right triangle with legs (x₁ - x₂) and (y₁ - y₂)
    • The distance is the hypotenuse
    • Sometimes it's easier to draw the triangle and use a² + b² = c²

5. Test-Taking Tips for Line Questions

  • Always convert to y = mx + b when possible
    • Slope-intercept form is the easiest to work with
    • If given standard form, solve for y immediately
    • If given point-slope form, distribute and solve for y
  • For perpendicular lines, flip and negate the slope
    • Perpendicular slope = -1 / (original slope)
    • If slope is 2, perpendicular is -1/2
    • If slope is -3/4, perpendicular is 4/3
  • Use substitution to verify equations
    • If given a point and asked which equation represents the line, plug the point into each answer choice
    • The correct equation will make the point satisfy the equation
    • This can be faster than calculating slope and y-intercept
  • Draw quick sketches for visual problems
    • If given two points, plot them quickly on scratch paper
    • Visualize the slope (is it positive or negative? steep or flat?)
    • This helps catch sign errors and eliminate wrong answers
  • Memorize the formulas
    • Slope formula, midpoint formula, and distance formula must be memorized
    • They are NOT provided on the ACT
    • Practice writing them from memory until automatic

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Parallel lines have the same slope, perpendicular lines have negative reciprocal slopes (flip fraction and change sign)
  • ✓Always convert equations to y = mx + b form when possible—it makes finding slope and y-intercept immediate
  • ✓Memorize: slope = (y₁-y₂)/(x₁-x₂), midpoint = ((x₁+x₂)/2, (y₁+y₂)/2), distance = √[(x₁-x₂)² + (y₁-y₂)²]
  • ✓The distance formula is just the Pythagorean theorem applied to coordinates—sometimes it's easier to draw the right triangle

lessons.subject: math
lessons.title: Arcs and Sectors
lessons.content:
Arcs and sectors appear occasionally on the ACT Math test, usually 1-2 questions per test. These problems test your understanding of how parts of a circle relate to the whole circle using proportional reasoning with central angles.

1. Understanding Arcs

  • An arc is a portion of a circle's circumference
    • Think of it as a "slice" of the circle's edge
    • Arcs are measured in two ways: degree measure or arc length
  • Degree measure of an arc:
    • Equal to the measure of the central angle that intercepts it
    • A central angle is an angle whose vertex is at the center of the circle
    • Example: If the central angle is 90°, the arc measures 90°
  • Arc length (the actual distance along the curve):
    • Arc length is a portion of the total circumference
    • Use the proportion: arc length / circumference = angle / 360°
  • Arc length formula (MEMORIZE THIS):
    • Arc Length = (θ/360°) × 2πr
    • Where θ = central angle in degrees
    • r = radius of the circle
    • 2πr = circumference of the whole circle
  • Alternative form (same formula):
    • Arc Length / Circumference = θ / 360°
    • This proportion shows: arc is to whole circle as angle is to 360°
    • Useful when you need to solve for the angle or radius

2. Understanding Sectors

  • A sector is a "slice" of a circle (like a pizza slice)
    • Bounded by two radii and an arc
    • Sectors have area, just like the whole circle has area
  • Sector area formula (MEMORIZE THIS):
    • Sector Area = (θ/360°) × πr²
    • Where θ = central angle in degrees
    • r = radius of the circle
    • πr² = area of the whole circle
  • Alternative form (proportion):
    • Sector Area / Circle Area = θ / 360°
    • This shows: sector is to whole circle as angle is to 360°
  • Key pattern to recognize:
    • Arc length uses circumference (2πr)
    • Sector area uses circle area (πr²)
    • Both use the same proportion: (θ/360°)

3. Solving Arc and Sector Problems

  • Step-by-step approach for arc length:
    • Step 1: Identify the central angle (θ) and radius (r)
    • Step 2: Calculate the full circumference: 2πr
    • Step 3: Find the fraction: θ/360°
    • Step 4: Multiply: arc length = (θ/360°) × 2πr
  • Step-by-step approach for sector area:
    • Step 1: Identify the central angle (θ) and radius (r)
    • Step 2: Calculate the full circle area: πr²
    • Step 3: Find the fraction: θ/360°
    • Step 4: Multiply: sector area = (θ/360°) × πr²
  • Working backwards (finding angle or radius):
    • If given arc length and radius, solve for θ
    • If given sector area and angle, solve for r
    • Use algebra to isolate the unknown variable
  • Common question types:
    • Given angle and radius, find arc length or sector area
    • Given arc length and radius, find the central angle
    • Given sector area and angle, find the radius
    • Finding the difference between two arcs or sectors

4. Test-Taking Tips for Arcs and Sectors

  • Think in terms of proportions
    • The key insight: the arc/sector is a fraction of the whole circle
    • That fraction equals the central angle divided by 360°
    • Example: A 90° angle means 90/360 = 1/4 of the circle
  • Don't confuse arc length with sector area
    • Arc length is distance (1-dimensional) - uses circumference
    • Sector area is space (2-dimensional) - uses circle area
    • Read the question carefully to determine which one is asked
  • Memorize the formulas now
    • Arc length = (θ/360°) × 2πr
    • Sector area = (θ/360°) × πr²
    • These are NOT provided on the test
  • Use the proportion setup for complex problems
    • Arc/Circumference = Angle/360° is easier to manipulate algebraically
    • Especially useful when solving for the angle or radius
    • Cross-multiply to solve
  • Simplify the fraction θ/360° early
    • 90/360 = 1/4, 120/360 = 1/3, 180/360 = 1/2
    • This makes calculations much simpler
    • Example: (90/360) × 2π(12) = (1/4) × 24π = 6π

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Arc length = (θ/360°) × 2πr and Sector area = (θ/360°) × πr²—these formulas are NOT provided on the ACT
  • ✓The central angle determines what fraction of the circle you have: a 90° angle = 1/4 of the circle
  • ✓Arc length is 1-dimensional (uses circumference 2πr), sector area is 2-dimensional (uses circle area πr²)
  • ✓Think proportionally: arc/circumference = sector/circle = angle/360°—this relationship solves all arc and sector problems

lessons.subject: math
lessons.title: Circles, Ellipses, and Hyperbolas
lessons.content:
Conic sections (circles, ellipses, and hyperbolas) appear 1-3 times per ACT Math test, usually focusing on the equation of a circle in standard form. Understanding how to identify the center and radius from the equation is the most important skill for these questions.

1. Equation of a Circle

  • Standard form of a circle (MEMORIZE THIS):
    • (x - h)² + (y - k)² = r²
    • Center: (h, k)
    • Radius: r
  • Reading the center from the equation:
    • Example: (x - 3)² + (y + 5)² = 16 has center (3, -5)
    • Watch the signs! (x - h) means center x = +h, (y + k) means center y = -k
    • If (x - 3), the center x-coordinate is 3
    • If (y + 5), the center y-coordinate is -5 (opposite sign!)
  • Finding the radius:
    • r² is on the right side of the equation
    • Example: (x - 2)² + (y - 1)² = 25 has r² = 25, so r = 5
    • Example: (x + 1)² + (y - 3)² = 100 has r² = 100, so r = 10
    • Don't forget to take the square root!
  • Special case - circle centered at origin:
    • x² + y² = r²
    • Center: (0, 0)
    • Example: x² + y² = 49 is centered at origin with radius 7
  • Writing the equation when given center and radius:
    • Center (3, -2) and radius 5: (x - 3)² + (y + 2)² = 25
    • Center (-4, 7) and radius 6: (x + 4)² + (y - 7)² = 36
    • Remember to square the radius!

2. Completing the Square for Circles

  • Sometimes circle equations are given in expanded form:
    • Example: x² + 4x + y² - 8y + 5 = 0
    • This doesn't look like standard form!
    • You must complete the square to find center and radius
  • Steps to complete the square:
    • Step 1: Group x terms and y terms: (x² + 4x) + (y² - 8y) = -5
    • Step 2: For x terms, take half of coefficient of x, square it: (4/2)² = 4
    • Step 3: For y terms, take half of coefficient of y, square it: (-8/2)² = 16
    • Step 4: Add these to both sides: (x² + 4x + 4) + (y² - 8y + 16) = -5 + 4 + 16
    • Step 5: Factor: (x + 2)² + (y - 4)² = 15
    • Now you can read center (-2, 4) and radius √15
  • Quick formula for completing the square:
    • For x² + bx, add (b/2)²
    • This creates a perfect square: (x + b/2)²
    • Same process for y terms

3. Ellipses and Hyperbolas (Basic Recognition)

  • Ellipse standard form:
    • (x - h)²/a² + (y - k)²/b² = 1
    • Center: (h, k), just like a circle
    • Looks like a stretched or compressed circle
    • Both terms are added (+), both squared
    • Example: (x - 2)²/9 + (y + 1)²/4 = 1 is centered at (2, -1)
  • Hyperbola standard form:
    • (x - h)²/a² - (y - k)²/b² = 1 or (y - k)²/b² - (x - h)²/a² = 1
    • Center: (h, k)
    • Has two separate curved branches
    • Key difference: One term is subtracted (-)
    • Example: (x - 3)²/16 - (y + 2)²/9 = 1 is centered at (3, -2)
  • How to identify which conic section:
    • Circle: x² and y² have same coefficient, added together
    • Ellipse: x² and y² have different coefficients, added together
    • Hyperbola: x² and y² are subtracted
  • On the ACT:
    • Circles are tested most frequently
    • Ellipses and hyperbolas appear 0-2 times per test
    • Usually just need to identify center or general shape
    • Deep knowledge of ellipse/hyperbola properties rarely needed

4. Test-Taking Tips for Conic Sections

  • Master the circle equation first
    • (x - h)² + (y - k)² = r² is the most tested formula
    • Practice reading the center until automatic
    • Remember: opposite signs! (x - 3) means center x = 3
  • Watch for completing the square questions
    • If the equation isn't in standard form, you'll need to complete the square
    • Take half the coefficient, square it, add to both sides
    • Don't forget to move the constant to the other side first!
  • Use the signs to identify the conic
    • Both terms positive (+)? Circle or ellipse
    • One term negative (-)? Hyperbola
    • This quick check eliminates wrong answers fast
  • Radius is always positive
    • r² = 25 means r = 5 (not ±5)
    • Radius cannot be negative in geometry
  • Memorize the standard forms
    • Circle: (x-h)²+(y-k)²=r²
    • Ellipse: (x-h)²/a²+(y-k)²/b²=1
    • Hyperbola: (x-h)²/a²-(y-k)²/b²=1
    • These formulas are NOT provided on the test

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Circle equation (x-h)²+(y-k)²=r² with center (h,k) and radius r—watch the signs! (x-3) means center x=3, (y+5) means center y=-5
  • ✓To complete the square for x²+bx, add (b/2)² to create a perfect square (x+b/2)²
  • ✓Identify conics by signs: both terms positive = circle/ellipse, one term negative = hyperbola
  • ✓Focus on circles first—they appear most frequently on the ACT, while ellipses and hyperbolas are rare

lessons.subject: math
lessons.title: Algebra Skills
lessons.content:
Core algebra skills appear on almost every ACT Math question, from simple equation solving to complex multi-step problems. Mastering PEMDAS, negative numbers, and combining like terms is essential for avoiding careless mistakes and solving problems quickly.

1. PEMDAS (Order of Operations)

  • PEMDAS is the order you MUST follow when solving expressions:
    • P - Parentheses: Complete calculations inside parentheses first
    • E - Exponents: Next, complete any exponents or square roots
    • MD - Multiplication and Division: Work LEFT TO RIGHT
    • AS - Addition and Subtraction: Work LEFT TO RIGHT
  • CRITICAL: Work left-to-right for MD and AS
    • This is where the ACT tricks students most often!
    • Example: 16 ÷ 4 × 2 - 3
    • ✓ Correct: 16 ÷ 4 × 2 - 3 = 4 × 2 - 3 = 8 - 3 = 5
    • ✗ Wrong: Don't do 4 × 2 first! That gives 16 ÷ 8 - 3 = -1 (incorrect)
  • Calculator shortcut:
    • Your calculator is programmed to follow PEMDAS automatically
    • Enter the expression exactly as written and let the calculator solve it
    • This prevents order of operations mistakes
    • Make sure to use parentheses when needed!
  • Common PEMDAS mistakes to avoid:
    • Doing multiplication before division (or vice versa) instead of left-to-right
    • Forgetting to complete parentheses first
    • Doing exponents after multiplication/division

2. Working with Negative Numbers

  • The ACT LOVES negative number questions—these are prime mistake opportunities
    • Students make more careless errors with negatives than any other topic
    • Take extra care and write out every step
  • Subtracting negative numbers:
    • Subtracting a negative = adding a positive
    • Example: 2 - (-4) = 2 + 4 = 6
    • Think: "minus a minus is a plus"
  • Distributing negative signs (HUGE mistake area):
    • You MUST distribute the negative to ALL terms in parentheses
    • Example: 5x - (2x - 5)
    • ✓ Correct: 5x - 2x - (-5) = 5x - 2x + 5 = 3x + 5
    • ✗ Wrong: 5x - 2x - 5 = 3x - 5 (forgot to distribute to the -5!)
    • The negative sign affects BOTH the 2x AND the -5
  • Negative numbers and exponents (another huge trap):
    • -x² is NOT the same as (-x)²
    • -x²: Square x first, then make it negative → -x² = -(x²)
    • (-x)²: Square the entire negative x → (-x)² = (-x)(-x) = x²
    • Example: -2² = -(2²) = -4
    • Example: (-2)² = (-2)(-2) = 4
    • Calculator tip: ALWAYS use parentheses around negative numbers!

3. Combining Like Terms

  • Like terms have the same variable raised to the same power:
    • 3x and 5x are like terms → can be combined to 8x
    • 2x² and 4x² are like terms → can be combined to 6x²
    • 3x and 5x² are NOT like terms → cannot be combined
    • Constants (numbers without variables) can always be combined
  • Steps for combining like terms:
    • Step 1: Distribute any parentheses
    • Step 2: Group like terms together
    • Step 3: Add or subtract the coefficients
    • Step 4: Simplify the expression
  • Example: 2(3x - 6) + 3y = 6x - y + 8, solve for y:
    • Distribute: 6x - 12 + 3y = 6x - y + 8
    • The 6x terms cancel on both sides
    • Simplify: -12 + 3y = -y + 8
    • Combine: 4y = 20
    • Solve: y = 5
  • When to combine like terms:
    • Always simplify equations before solving
    • Combining like terms reduces the equation to its simplest form
    • This makes it easier to see what to do next

4. Cross-Multiplying Fractions

  • When two fractions are equal, you can cross-multiply:
    • If x/y = z/w, then xw = yz
    • Multiply the numerator of each fraction by the denominator of the other
    • This eliminates the fractions and gives you a simpler equation
  • Visual representation:
    • x/y = z/w
    • Cross-multiply diagonally: x × w and y × z
    • Result: xw = yz
  • Example: If x/4 = 6/7, solve for x:
    • Cross-multiply: 7x = 4(6)
    • Simplify: 7x = 24
    • Solve: x = 24/7
  • When to use cross-multiplication:
    • When you have one fraction equal to another fraction
    • This is the fastest way to eliminate fractions
    • Much faster than finding common denominators

5. Test-Taking Tips for Algebra Skills

  • Write out every step—do NOT do mental math
    • Careless errors happen when you skip steps
    • Writing forces you to be careful with negative signs
    • You can check your work if you write it out
  • Use your calculator strategically
    • For PEMDAS problems: enter the entire expression
    • ALWAYS use parentheses around negative numbers
    • Double-check your calculator entry matches the problem
  • Circle or underline negative signs
    • Makes them more visible so you don't forget them
    • Especially important when distributing
  • Test your answer with substitution
    • If you solved for x, plug your answer back into the original equation
    • Does it make the equation true? Then you're correct!
    • This catches algebra mistakes
  • Master the basics before moving to advanced topics
    • These fundamental skills appear in EVERY algebra problem
    • You cannot do advanced algebra without mastering these basics
    • Practice until negative numbers and PEMDAS are automatic

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Follow PEMDAS strictly, working LEFT TO RIGHT for multiplication/division and addition/subtraction—this is where most mistakes happen
  • ✓When distributing a negative sign, apply it to ALL terms: 5x - (2x - 5) = 5x - 2x + 5, not 5x - 2x - 5
  • ✓-x² ≠ (-x)²: without parentheses, square first then negate (-x² = -4 when x=2), with parentheses square the negative ((-x)² = 4)
  • ✓Write out every step and always use parentheses in your calculator for negative numbers—careless mistakes lose more points than not knowing the math

lessons.subject: math
lessons.title: Fractions
lessons.content:
Fractions appear frequently on the ACT Math test, both as standalone problems and within larger algebra questions. This chapter covers ALL the fundamental techniques you need to answer any fraction question quickly and efficiently—from combining fractions with variables to using your calculator to convert between fractions and decimals.

1. Combining Fractions (Adding and Subtracting)

  • To add or subtract fractions, you MUST have the same denominator:
    • You cannot add 1/2 + 2/5 directly—the denominators are different
    • First find the least common denominator (LCD)
    • Then add or subtract the numerators while keeping the denominator the same
  • Quick trick for finding the least common denominator:
    • Multiply the denominators together
    • Example: For 1/2 + 2/5, LCD = 2 × 5 = 10
    • This always works, even if it's not the smallest possible denominator
    • On the ACT, any common denominator is fine—you don't need the smallest one
  • Step-by-step process for combining fractions:
    • Example: 1/2 + 2/5
    • Step 1: Find LCD = 2 × 5 = 10
    • Step 2: Convert each fraction: 1/2 = 5/10, and 2/5 = 4/10
    • Step 3: Add numerators: 5/10 + 4/10 = 9/10
  • Fractions with variables in denominators (harder but same concept):
    • Example: 1/x + 3/(x-4)
    • LCD = x(x-4) [multiply the denominators]
    • Multiply first fraction by (x-4)/(x-4): (x-4)/[x(x-4)]
    • Multiply second fraction by x/x: 3x/[x(x-4)]
    • Add: (x-4+3x)/[x(x-4)] = (4x-4)/[x(x-4)]

2. Dividing Fractions ("Keep, Flip, Change")

  • The "Keep, Flip, Change" method for dividing fractions:
    • Keep the first fraction exactly as it is
    • Flip the second fraction (take the reciprocal)
    • Change the division sign to multiplication
    • Example: (2/3) ÷ (4/5) = (2/3) × (5/4) = 10/12 = 5/6
  • This works even when dividing a fraction by a whole number:
    • Example: (2/3) ÷ 3
    • Write 3 as 3/1, then flip to get 1/3
    • Result: (2/3) × (1/3) = 2/9
  • The reciprocal of a fraction:
    • Flip the numerator and denominator
    • Reciprocal of 3/4 is 4/3
    • Reciprocal of 5 is 1/5 (since 5 = 5/1)
    • Reciprocal of x/(x-2) is (x-2)/x
  • Why "keep, flip, change" works:
    • Dividing by a number is the same as multiplying by its reciprocal
    • Example: 10 ÷ 2 = 10 × (1/2) = 5
    • Same principle applies to fractions

3. Simplifying Fractions (Critical Rules!)

  • Rule: You can ONLY simplify if you can divide ALL terms by the same number
    • Example: (2x+10)/4 CAN be simplified (divide all by 2) → (x+5)/2
    • Example: (8x+3)/4 CANNOT be simplified (can't divide 3 by 4)
    • Common mistake: (2x+10)/4 ≠ (x+10)/2 ❌ (You MUST divide ALL terms!)
  • When you CANNOT simplify, split the fraction instead:
    • Example: (8x+3)/4 = 8x/4 + 3/4 = 2x + 3/4
    • You CAN split numerators: (a+b)/c = a/c + b/c ✓
    • You CANNOT split denominators: a/(b+c) ≠ a/b + a/c ❌
  • Simplifying with variables in the denominator:
    • Example: 3/(6x+30) CAN be simplified → 3/[3(2x+10)] → 1/(2x+10)
    • Example: 3/(6x+10) CANNOT be simplified (can't divide 10 by 3)
    • Same rule: ALL terms must be divisible by the same number
  • CRITICAL: You cannot split denominators!
    • 3/(6x+10) ≠ 3/6x + 3/10 ❌ WRONG!
    • This is one of the most common mistakes students make
    • When in doubt, leave the denominator together

4. Getting Rid of Fractions (Multiply by LCD)

  • For equations with only numbers in denominators, eliminate fractions:
    • Find the least common multiple (LCM) of all denominators
    • Multiply EVERY term by the LCM
    • All fractions will disappear, leaving only whole numbers
    • Then solve the equation normally
  • Example: (1/4)x + (1/2) = (3/8)x
    • LCM of 4, 2, and 8 is 8
    • Multiply all terms by 8: (1/4)x×8 + (1/2)×8 = (3/8)x×8
    • Simplify: 2x + 4 = 3x
    • Solve: x = 4
  • More complex example with subtraction:
    • Example: (3x/5) - (2x/6) - (1/2) = (x/10)
    • LCM of 5, 6, 2, and 10 is 30
    • Multiply all terms by 30: 18x - 10x - 15 = 3x
    • Simplify: 8x - 15 = 3x
    • Solve: 5x = 15, so x = 3
  • When to use this method:
    • If you struggle with fractions, ALWAYS use this method!
    • It turns difficult fraction problems into easy whole number problems
    • Works great when ALL denominators are numbers (not variables)

5. Calculator Strategies for Fractions

  • Strategy #1: Turn fractions into decimals
    • Example: (3/4)x - (2/5) = (1/2)x becomes 0.75x - 0.4 = 0.5x
    • Solve: 0.75x = 0.5x + 0.4 → 0.25x = 0.4 → x = 1.6
    • Then convert 1.6 back to a fraction if needed, or check answer choices
    • This avoids dealing with fractions entirely!
  • Strategy #2: Convert decimals to fractions using your calculator
    • TI-83/84: Enter decimal → Press MATH → Select "Frac" → Press ENTER
    • TI-30XS: Enter decimal → Press 2nd → Press PRB → Select F◂▸D → Press ENTER
    • If you have a different calculator, YouTube has tutorials for your model
  • Strategy #3: Use parentheses properly!
    • ALWAYS put the entire numerator in parentheses
    • ALWAYS put the entire denominator in parentheses
    • Example: To enter (2x+1)/(x-3), type: (2x+1)÷(x-3)
    • Without parentheses, calculator follows order of operations incorrectly
  • Strategy #4: Compare answer choices as decimals
    • If you solved to get x = 1.6 (decimal)
    • And answer choices are fractions like 8/5, 5/3, 13/10, etc.
    • Enter each fraction in calculator to see which equals 1.6
    • 8/5 = 1.6 ✓ That's your answer!
  • Strategy #5: Backsolving
    • If the question asks "what is the value of x?" with answer choices
    • Plug each answer choice back into the original equation
    • Use your calculator to check which one makes the equation true
    • This is often faster than solving algebraically!

6. Test-Taking Tips for Fractions

  • Use your calculator strategically
    • For numerical fractions: let calculator do the work
    • For algebraic fractions: write out steps carefully
    • Save mental energy for the hard problems
  • Use substitution for "equivalent" questions
    • If asked "which expression is equivalent," plug in a test value
    • Example: If the original has x, try x = 2
    • Calculate both expressions—they should give the same answer
    • This is often faster than algebraic manipulation
  • Remember the "cannot split denominators" rule
    • a/(b+c) ≠ a/b + a/c ❌ This is ALWAYS wrong!
    • But (a+b)/c = a/c + b/c ✓ Splitting numerators is OK
    • This mistake appears in wrong answer choices frequently
  • When in doubt, eliminate fractions
    • If all denominators are numbers, multiply by LCM
    • If dealing with fractions makes you nervous, turn them into decimals
    • Both methods turn hard problems into easy ones
  • Master "Keep, Flip, Change" for division
    • This simple rule handles ALL fraction division
    • Keep first, flip second, change to multiplication
    • Works every time, no exceptions

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓To combine fractions, multiply denominators to find LCD, convert all fractions, then add/subtract numerators—works for both numbers and variables
  • ✓You can ONLY simplify if you can divide ALL terms by the same number; you CAN split numerators (a+b)/c = a/c + b/c but you CANNOT split denominators
  • ✓To eliminate fractions from equations, multiply all terms by the LCM—this turns fraction problems into whole number problems
  • ✓Use your calculator to convert between fractions and decimals, backsolve with answer choices, and always use parentheses around numerators and denominators

lessons.subject: math
lessons.title: Exponents and Roots
lessons.content:
Exponents and roots appear frequently on the ACT Math test, testing your ability to apply exponent rules and simplify radicals. Mastering the seven exponent rules and understanding how to factor numbers under radicals will help you solve these problems quickly and accurately.

1. Exponent Rules (Memorize These!)

  • The seven essential exponent rules:
    • Product Rule: a^x × a^y = a^(x+y)
    • Example: 3³ × 3⁴ = 3⁷
    • When multiplying with the same base, add the exponents
  • Quotient Rule: a^x ÷ a^y = a^(x-y)
    • Example: 5⁷ ÷ 5² = 5⁵
    • When dividing with the same base, subtract the exponents
  • Power Rule: (a^x)^y = a^(xy)
    • Example: (2³)² = 2⁶
    • When raising a power to a power, multiply the exponents
    • CRITICAL: Distribute to ALL terms, including coefficients!
    • Example: (-2xy³)² = 4x²y⁶ (the -2 becomes 4!)
  • Negative Exponent Rule: a^(-x) = 1/a^x
    • Example: 2^(-3) = 1/2³ = 1/8
    • Negative exponents mean "reciprocal"
    • Trick: Moving a term from numerator to denominator (or vice versa) flips the sign of the exponent
    • Example: x^(-2)/y^(-3) = y³/x²
  • Zero Power Rule: a^0 = 1
    • Example: 139⁰ = 1
    • ANY number to the zero power equals 1 (except 0⁰ which is undefined)
  • One Power Rule: a^1 = a
    • Example: (-4)¹ = -4
    • Any number to the first power is itself
  • Fraction Power Rule: a^(x/y) = ʸ√(a^x)
    • Example: 8^(2/3) = ³√(8²) = ³√64 = 4
    • Or: 8^(2/3) = (³√8)² = 2² = 4
    • The denominator is the root, the numerator is the power

2. Solving Exponential Equations

  • When bases are the same, set exponents equal:
    • If 4^(3x+1) = 4^(-x+7), then 3x+1 = -x+7
    • Solve: 4x = 6, so x = 3/2
    • This works because equal exponential expressions with the same base must have equal exponents
  • When bases are different, make them the same:
    • Example: 9^(2x) = 27^(x+4)
    • Recognize that 9 = 3² and 27 = 3³
    • Rewrite: (3²)^(2x) = (3³)^(x+4)
    • Simplify: 3^(4x) = 3^(3x+12)
    • Set exponents equal: 4x = 3x+12, so x = 12
  • Calculator method - Backsolving:
    • If the question gives answer choices, plug them in!
    • Calculate both sides of the equation with each answer choice
    • The correct answer will make both sides equal
    • This is often faster than algebraic manipulation

3. Simplifying Radicals

  • To simplify a square root, factor and take out pairs:
    • Example: √50 = √(5×5×2) = 5√2
    • There's a pair of 5's, so take the 5 out front
    • The 2 is not part of a pair, so it stays under the radical
  • More complex example:
    • √108 = √(2×2×3×3×3) = (2×3)√3 = 6√3
    • We have a pair of 2's and a pair of 3's, so take both out
    • The third 3 is not part of a pair, so it stays under the radical
  • Going backwards - putting numbers back under the radical:
    • Take the number outside and square it under the radical
    • Example: 6√3 = √(6×6×3) = √108
    • This is useful when you need to combine radicals
  • Combining radicals (only like radicals can be combined):
    • Example: √45 + √20 = 3√5 + 2√5 = 5√5
    • First simplify each radical: √45 = √(3×3×5) = 3√5
    • And: √20 = √(2×2×5) = 2√5
    • Then combine like radicals by adding coefficients

4. Operations with Radicals

  • Multiplying and dividing radicals:
    • √x × √y = √(xy)
    • Example: √8 × √2 = √16 = 4
    • √x ÷ √y = √(x/y)
    • Example: √50 ÷ √2 = √(50/2) = √25 = 5
  • Solving radical equations:
    • Example: If √(2x) = 5√6, solve for x
    • Method #1: Move the 5 under the radical: √(2x) = √(6×5×5) = √150
    • Since the radicals are equal, the contents must be equal: 2x = 150, so x = 75
  • Alternate method - square both sides:
    • (√(2x))² = (5√6)²
    • 2x = 25 × 6
    • 2x = 150, so x = 75
  • Cube roots and higher roots follow the same rules:
    • ³√(xy) = ³√x × ³√y
    • Example: ³√16 = ³√(8×2) = ³√8 × ³√2 = 2³√2
    • For cube roots, take out groups of three instead of pairs

5. Test-Taking Tips for Exponents and Roots

  • Memorize all seven exponent rules COLD
    • You cannot skip any of them—all appear on the ACT
    • Practice until you can apply them instantly without thinking
    • The product, quotient, and power rules are tested most often
  • When distributing powers, distribute to EVERYTHING
    • Don't forget coefficients! (-2x)³ = -8x³, not -2x³
    • Don't forget ALL variables! (3xy²)² = 9x²y⁴, not 9xy⁴
    • This is the #1 mistake students make with exponents
  • Use your calculator to backsolve when possible
    • If the question gives answer choices, plugging in is often faster
    • Calculate both sides of the equation with each answer
    • This works great for exponential equations and radical equations
  • For radicals, factor methodically
    • Break numbers down into prime factors to find all pairs
    • Example: 72 = 2×2×2×3×3 → pairs of 2's and 3's → 6√2
    • Don't rush—missing a pair means getting the wrong answer
  • Look for common bases in exponential equations
    • Recognize that 4 = 2², 8 = 2³, 16 = 2⁴
    • Recognize that 9 = 3², 27 = 3³, 81 = 3⁴
    • Converting to the same base makes equations much easier to solve

Hidden Separator

Key Takeaways

  • ✓Master all seven exponent rules, especially product (a^x × a^y = a^(x+y)), quotient (a^x ÷ a^y = a^(x-y)), and power ((a^x)^y = a^(xy))—these are tested most frequently
  • ✓When distributing powers, apply to ALL terms including coefficients: (-2xy³)² = 4x²y⁶, not -2x²y⁶
  • ✓Simplify radicals by factoring and taking out pairs: √108 = √(2×2×3×3×3) = 6√3
  • ✓Use backsolving with your calculator when answer choices are given—often faster than algebraic manipulation for exponential and radical equations

Before we start this book, let’s begin by understanding the basic format of the ACT Math Test and general strategies you will need for success.

The ACT Math Test consists of one section: a 50-minute section with 45 questions. A calculator is allowed in this section, and you should use your calculator a lot! Even for simple mental math, use the calculator. This will help keep your mind fresh and avoid simple mistakes.

As you progress through the test, the difficulty of the questions increases. The first 5-10 questions in general will be much easier. As you move towards the later questions, the difficulty will increase slightly until around question 30, where the questions will quickly get much more difficult. The table below provides a general

breakdown of the difficulty of questions based on the question number.

By no means are the numbers exact (more advanced question can certainly appear before question 30 and easier questions can appear later in the test), but the trend is pretty consistent across most ACTs. In this book, the practice questions in each chapter will increase in difficulty just as they do on the ACT.

On average, you have just over 1 minute (1 minute and 6 seconds to be exact) to answer each question.

Some questions can be solved very quickly while others can take much longer to solve. In general, you should be solving the earlier questions in less than 60 seconds, as the later, more difficult questions will require more If you get to a question that you do not know how to solve, circle the number, bubble in an answer, and

move on. You can always come back to the questions that you circled at the end if you have time left. It is important to answer questions as quickly as possible but not to go so fast that you make simple mistakes.

Keep yourself moving through the section and find the questions that you know how to solve. Every question Depending on your math abilities, your precise strategy for managing time on this section will vary. High achieving math students aiming for top scores need to answer all 45 questions. This requires working quickly

through the first 25-30 questions and saving enough time to solve the most difficult questions at the end. On the other hand, if math is not your strength, focusing your time on answering as many of the first 30-35 questions correctly as you can and guessing on the questions you do not know how to solve to will help you

get your best score. Again, every question is worth the same one point, so it is better to spend your time crushing the easier/medium level questions rather than rushing to get to the hardest questions at the end. Every student is different, so it is up to you to take some practice ACTs to find the best strategy for you to maximize

There is no penalty for guessing. Make sure that you bubble in an answer for every single question. On a multiple-choice test, there is no best method for guessing, so look at the answer choices and pick the answer 6 Test Day Tips to Maximize Your Score

The 6 test-taking tips below will help you maximize your scores on test day.

Keep Moving. Do not get stuck on any one question for too long. We often see students make this mistake and run out of time before finishing all 45 questions. If you get stuck on a question, mark it, bubble in your best guess, and move on. You can come back to the question at the end if you have

time left over. Remember, there is no penalty for guessing.

Look For Questions You Know How To Solve If Time Is Running Out. For students who are not strong at math, running out of time is not unusual on the ACT Math. If you know that you are running low on time, start to look for questions that you know how to solve and questions that you can solve

Do Your Best To See All 45 questions. Remember, questions 30-45 are challenging but the questions do not necessarily keep increasing in difficulty as you get closer and closer to question 45.

For example, on one recent ACT, question 38 was the hardest question on the test but questions 42 and 45 were actually much easier. It is best to skip the hardest questions or questions that stump you and save them for last. Many students made the mistake of getting stuck on question 38 and ran out of

time before they even saw questions 42 and 45. If they instead skipped question 38 and had time to see questions 42 and 45, they could have answered those questions correctly and achieved a higher Memorize The Equations. In this book, the equations, formulas, and rules that you need to

memorize are in bold lettering. Having all of equations, formulas, and rules memorized for test day are critical to solving questions more quickly and maximizing your score.

Use The Calculator! Use your calculator as much as possible. Even for simple calculations, avoid mental math as much as possible, as mental math often leads to avoidable errors.

Practice Like Its Test Day. When working on practice ACT tests, set a timer and strictly follow the timer. The best way to get ready for test day is to treat your practice ACTs like it is the real thing.

In the first two chapters, you will learn two important test-taking techniques: backsolving and substitution. As you work through the rest of the book, use these techniques whenever you can to solve questions.

Backsolving is plugging the answer choices back into the question. On the ACT, you are given 4 answer choices for multiple choice questions, and one of those 4 choices must be correct. Rather than solving the question algebraically and determining whether your answer matches one of the answer choices, you can

guess-and-check with the answer choices to find which one is correct. Backsolving is often the fastest and easiest way to solve ACT questions, especially if you get stuck and cannot solve a question algebraically, so Backsolving can be done using five steps:

Start with B or C. Plug the value in the answer choice back into the question. The answer choices are always in order of smallest to largest or largest to smallest so starting in the middle saves you time.

Solve the question using this value. Find any other unknowns if necessary.

If this answer choice works correctly, you’re done! Bubble it in and move on.

If this answer choice does not work, cross it off. If you know the correct answer needs to be smaller or larger than the value you just tried, cross off any other incorrect answers.

Pick one of the remaining answer choices and plug it back into the question. Repeat this until you find the correct answer. Remember, one of the 5 answer choices must work!

The answer is A. If we plug in any other answer choices, the equation will not equal 0.

For questions with points in the question or answer choices, it is often effective to backsolve with points. For this method, we will use the point(s) to test which equation works correctly. Remember, if a point is on a graph, it must make the equation of the graph true.

For answer choice C: f(1) =4(1) +1 For answer choice D: f(1) = 2(1)+3 Answer choices A and B do not work, so we can eliminate those answer choices. Answer choices C and D both work, so we need to use a second point to test answer choices C and D. Let’s use the point (3, 9).

For answer choice C: f(3) = 4(3) For answer choice D: f(3) = 2(3)+3.

The answer is D. As you can see, we can solve this question by backsolving with points. This method is much easier than solving this question algebraically.

Do you prefer working with numbers or variables? We would guess your answer is numbers! On the ACT, some questions have many unknown variables and few or no numbers at all. Students often find these questions more difficult. If you prefer to work with numbers, let’s work with numbers! With substitution, we

substitute simple numbers in for variables and solve the question using numbers instead of relying on more complex algebra with variables.

Substitution can be done with these four steps:

Pick a number for the variable(s) in the question.

Pick easy numbers...avoid using 0 and 1. Use 2, 3, 4 or other easy numbers. Use 10 for percent problems, 10 or 20 for group size, etc.

Select different numbers for each variable. For example, if a question has an x and a y, pick Follow any rules in the question. For example, if a question says x is a number that is negative and even, pick x = —2.

Write down the number(s) that you have picked.

Use your number(s) to work your way through the question and find your answer.

Plug your number(s) into the answer choices. The correct answer will be the one that matches Substitution may seem a bit confusing just reading the steps, so let’s take a look at some example questions to see how useful this technique can be.

Example 1: Jeremy has n boxes of candy bars. Each box contains m bars of candy. Jeremy has to sell

70% of his candy bars to make enough money for rent. Which of the following expresses the number of candy bars Jeremy must sell in terms of m and n?

B. 70nm
D. 0.7nm
Solution:

let’s plug in numbers. We can say that Jeremy has 2 boxes of candy, so n = 2, and that each box contains 5 bars of candy, som = 5. With our numbers, Jeremy has a total of 10 candy bars. He needs to sell 70% to make enough money for rent, so we can find the total candy bars that he must sell by finding 70% of 10.

With our numbers, Jeremy must sell 7 candy bars, so our answer is 7. Now, we can plug in the values we selected for n and m into the answer choices and see which one is equal to 7. Here, we find that D works.

None of the other answer choices are equal to 7 when we plug in our values for n and m. No matter what numbers you pick for n and m, you will find that D is the answer.
